story:
Our Story

Fusing fun and reading, Rabbits for Reading is a napkin which folds into a Rabbit Puppet, a Rabbkin! Supporting the love of reading and donating 20% of profits to STAIR, a New Orleans tutoring group helping elementary school students succeed.


Education MATTERS: this is the launch of the second product by MATTER L3C, Design for Social Change, the initial product being BirdProject [www.birdproject.org]. For this new product for Social Change I am working with Cécile Thalmann and Adel Kassem, friends and designers based in Milano.


Recognizing the importance of children's education, upon seeing Cécile and Adel's beautiful rabbit concept, I had the idea of connecting it with the important need for raising the literacy rate in New Orleans, and thought this lovely bunny could help inspire children to read and fall in love with reading. We have been working together the past few weeks via skype and are excited to bring the Rabbkins to you!


Cécile's grandmother used to play with her using this napkin rabbit trick and Cécile has been sharing it with others ever since! It's such a delightful magic trick! The transformation of the napkin into the puppet helps spark a child's imagination and also becomes their reading buddy, wandering through books and lands of imagination.


Initially we will create these napkins or Rabbkins in New Orleans, 20% of the profits going to ST﻿AI﻿R. STAIR is a New Orleans tutoring group assisting elementary school students who need extra help in learning how to read. The students involved with STAIR are in danger of academic failure and need this extra help to succeed. New Orleans' literacy rate is startling at a rate near 50%, with 1 out of 10 students graduating high school.


Heart & soul is being put into improving the education system here in New Orleans post Katrina, which put a spotlight on the problems and large gaps in the system. Teachers here in dear NOLA are working so hard to help their students. Thank you teachers! Thank you tutors! Innovative programs are in development to re-think and build the successes of schools - including 4.0 Schools and Our School at Fair Grocery. [Please read founder Nat Turner's inspiring story here.]


We would like to help spread the joy of reading with the Rabbkin. Giving children extra support while in elementary school helps to give them a good start and opportunities for many successes ahead! STAIR is helping children across New Orleans learn to read and to stay in school. Their tutoring program is also spreading around the country by people who saw its success and started a STAIR site in their community. Thank you to the children seen in our video, members of STAIR's program, who helped test out the prototype and made for such a great reading of the Velveteen Rabbit : )


This round of funding is to create an initial herd of 500 Rabbkins here in New Orleans, being printed at Purple Monkey in the Bywater with eco-inks on fair trade cotton. If we go past our set goal, this funding will be used for creating the Rabbkins on Cécile and Adel's side of the ocean in Milano! The 20% of profit donation for the Milano Rabbits would also go to a correlating group in Italy. [European retailers please let us know if you are interested!]


Help us get this herd of Rabbits into the world and hopping around on children's hands and rabbit's noses in books for Easter! Afterall, this is the year of the RABBIT!


Thank you for your support and please enjoy your Rabbkin!!


Fan our cottontails on facebook! Follow us on twitter!


ps - We will be using the USPS prepaid shipping envelopes and boxes for your backer rewards which are Cradle to Cradle certified!

﻿﻿﻿﻿
story_txt:
Our Story

Fusing fun and reading, Rabbits for Reading is a napkin which folds 
into a Rabbit Puppet, a Rabbkin! Supporting the love of reading and 
donating 20% of profits to STAIR, a New Orleans tutoring group helping elementary school students succeed.

Education MATTERS: this is the launch of the second product by MATTER L3C, Design for Social Change, the initial product being BirdProject [www.birdproject.org].
 For this new product for Social Change I am working with Cécile 
Thalmann and Adel Kassem, friends and designers based in Milano.

Recognizing
 the importance of children's education, upon seeing Cécile and Adel's 
beautiful rabbit concept, I had the idea of connecting it with the 
important need for raising the literacy rate in New Orleans, and thought
 this lovely bunny could help inspire children to read and fall in love 
with reading. We have been working together the past few weeks via skype
 and are excited to bring the Rabbkins to you!

Cécile's 
grandmother used to play with her using this napkin rabbit trick and 
Cécile has been sharing it with others ever since! It's such a 
delightful magic trick! The transformation of the napkin into the puppet
 helps spark a child's imagination and also becomes their reading buddy,
 wandering through books and lands of imagination. 

Initially we will create these napkins or Rabbkins in New Orleans, 20% of the profits going to ST﻿AI﻿R. STAIR is a New Orleans tutoring group assisting elementary school students who need extra help in learning how to read. The students involved with STAIR
 are in danger of academic failure and need this extra help to succeed. 
New Orleans' literacy rate is startling at a rate near 50%, with 1 out 
of 10 students graduating high school. 

Heart & soul is being 
put into improving the education system here in New Orleans post 
Katrina, which put a spotlight on the problems and large gaps in the 
system. Teachers here in dear NOLA are working so hard to help their 
students. Thank you teachers! Thank you tutors! Innovative programs are 
in development to re-think and build the successes of schools - 
including 4.0 Schools and Our School at Fair Grocery. [Please read founder Nat Turner's inspiring story here.] 

We
 would like to help spread the joy of reading with the Rabbkin. Giving 
children extra support while in elementary school helps to give them a 
good start and opportunities for many successes ahead! STAIR is helping 
children across New Orleans learn to read and to stay in school. Their 
tutoring program is also spreading around the country by people who saw its success
 and started a STAIR site in their community. Thank you to the children 
seen in our video, members of STAIR's program, who helped test out the 
prototype and made for such a great reading of the Velveteen Rabbit : )

This round of funding is to create an initial herd of 500 Rabbkins here in New Orleans, being printed at Purple Monkey
 in the Bywater with eco-inks on fair trade cotton. If we go past our 
set goal, this funding will be used for creating the Rabbkins on Cécile 
and Adel's side of the ocean in Milano! The 20% of profit donation for 
the Milano Rabbits would also go to a correlating group in Italy. 
[European retailers please let us know if you are interested!]

Help
 us get this herd of Rabbits into the world and hopping around on 
children's hands and rabbit's noses in books for Easter! Afterall, this 
is the year of the RABBIT!

Thank you for your support and please enjoy your Rabbkin!!

Fan our cottontails on facebook! Follow us on twitter!

ps - We will be using the USPS prepaid shipping envelopes and boxes for your backer rewards which are Cradle to Cradle certified!

story:
During this historic time, we wish to impart a modern day vision for youth ministry that would help the Youth workers and leaders to take their ministry to the next level. We desire to see the participants leave this conference with:

1. Understand that youth ministry is not just another weekly service, but it is imperative ministry for their local church body.

2. Look for creative ways to make youth ministry relative for today’s youth and not just another boring church service.

3. Find culturally relevant ways to meet the needs of the youth, rather than just preaching

4. Discover some creative ways to get the youth to actively participate in the services

4. Discover some creative ways to get the youth to actively participate in the services

story:
The Pitch (and Poem)

Now this is a campaign geared to support
Morgyn in her quest to explore.
I'd like to tell my story, just read right on,
of the journey I have dreamed of almost my whole life-long.

In Western Mass, junior year of college,
I have soaked up nearly 20 years of knowledge. 
Readin' books, researchin', and workin' too,
Ihave gone through all the motions of the first two.
For my entire third year, I'll be living my dream:
studying in Spain, and certifying to teach.
I have one little dilemma: a lack of funds.
So I'm reaching out to the nation to show me some love.

Come September to Madrid I will fly, fly,
With eyes in the sky, hope in my heart, and you all on my mind.
And I'll think, 'Yo, well this is my shot.'
Y con ese en mente, I'll give Spain all I've got! 




The Nitty-Gritty

Travel Dates: September 1st, 2011 to May 25th, 2012
Reason for travel: Studying in Spain and Certifying to teach in Spain!

Ever since I was a child I have been interested in theatre, language, and people, particularly youth. (For example, as a child I quickly took to the stage, probed anyone Spanish-speaking to teach me words, and was ever-fascinated with any and all smaller beings.) In college these interests crystallized into a Sociology and Spanish double major with additional courses in Theatre. 

In my teenage years I would provide complimentary childcare for family members and friends (why would I want to be paid to play with children- aka to do something I loved?); in college I provided even more, now paid, childcare in addition to participating in teaching internships and summer programs (Urban Education Fellowship, placement in New York City; Exploration Summer Programs, through St. Mark's). My fascination is Theatre through Education, and Education through Theatre. That means that yes, I am loud and bubbly, while also focused, driven, and I believe that children wield an amazing power and sense of creativity that should be strengthened and focused into each and every one of their individual interests. 

I am, additionally, fascinated by how language shapes worlds. What is it like to live in a different language? Immensely different. In Spain I intend to become more fluent in Spanish, study, and collect research for a senior thesis and/or Fulbright attempt to compare and contrast communication through the Spanish and English languages (as it concerns western Spain and the United States). I will also become certified to teach in Spain through the TEFL program in Madrid, which is my primary interest for a future career post-grad. 

I have all of the ambition, motivation, and drive, with almost none of the funding necessary to support the three. Being my own, sole financier comes of great pride to me; however, the truth is that I am a 20-year old college student who has never had grave funds to finance. Any and all help will be, truly, a blessing. 


For You, A Thousand Times

The Spanish consulate states that students should have about $1,000 per month of study in Spain. Breaking down my September-May stay, that would amount to $8,000. A good amount, yes; feasible, no. I would love to raise, feasibly, $5,000- or $2,500 per semester. My goal is to raise half, or $2,500, on my own, and to depend on your grace for the rest (or more!). My listed goal states $2,750 to offset the percentage that Indiegogo collects from campaigns; I am excited and hopeful to achieve much higher than that though!


All contributions will be put towards financing my junior year of study abroad, which includes travel, survival (housing and food), courses, researching for a senior thesis/Fulbright application and finally a month-long TEFL certification course in Madrid to teach English as a Foreign Language once I graduate. With the US to Euro exchange rate of $1.40 USD to 1 Euro, more funds means less of an impact from the change in currency. I appreciate anything that you can contribute, with the hopes that you know I would do the same for you.

For your contributions you will assuredly receive the perks listed on the right, and not to mention a vacuum-sealed, mushy, and appreciative place en mi corazón. 


Que más... (What's more)

Please share my story (and/or sing my rap!) with everyone! Bonus points if you know where the tune comes from. Post it to your Wall on Facebook- tweet the link on Twitter- BBM it- there are a myriad of ways to get the word out, and I thank you for any and all of the ways that strike your fancy to help me out. Thank you!

For your contributions you will assuredly receive the perks listed on the right, and not to mention a vacuum-sealed, mushy, and appreciative place en mi corazón.

Please share my story (and/or sing my rap!) with everyone! Bonus points if you know where the tune comes from. Post it to your Wall on Facebook- tweet the link on Twitter- BBM it- there are a myriad of ways to get the word out, and I thank you for any and all of the ways that strike your fancy to help me out. Thank you!

story:
My name is Elizabeth Nott. I come from Venezuela and have been living in London since 1999. I re-engaged in music studies in 2003, this time focusing in 'world' music through Ethnomusicological studies at SOAS, University of London. From 2004 till 2006 I took Middle Eastern and North African percussion (mainly darbuka) as my main instrument under the tutelage of Ahmed Mukthar. After finishing my BA at SOAS I continued darabuka lessons with Tim Garside and Ibrahim Al-Miniawi, and also learnt to play other Middle Eastern percussions (mainly on my own) falling in the category of 'frame drums': the riq (Arabic tambourine), bendir (Snare frame drum in Morocco and without snare in Turkey) and Iranian/Kurdish daf (with chains of rings hanging from inside). For the last 3 years, these frame drums have been the focus of my life and the cause of my current MA research; I have been delving into the various new 'schools' and the techniques incorporated in the playing of this ancient instrument, mainly that developed by Glen Velez and Zohar Fresco.

Bands and artists I have previously played with include Khyam Allami (Oud), Magic Tombolinos (Balkan/punk/latin), Pocket Caravan (Eastern European/Brazilian originals), Ludomix (Rai/pop), SOAS Middle Eastern Ensemble and London Gypsy Orchestra.

Currently I am working with Turkish/Kurdish group 'Bayir ensemble', Sudanese/Italian singer Amira Kheir and Moroccan Oud player Soufian Saihi. Furthermore, I have been organising workshops in Middle Eastern and Latin percussion traditions since 2009 with UK and international artists.

Full information can be found in my website www.elizabethnott.co.uk and www.nottas.co.uk


Campaign

My campaign is about raising awareness (especially in the UK) of the frame drum tradition of the world and supporting my MA in Ethnomusicology project (City University London 2011-2013) which encompasses documenting in film and writing, researching and learning the new frame drumming tradition. It seeks to answer the following questions:

How are traditions re-interpreted and incorporated in contemporary music making and learning?
How is globalisation and migration shaping frame drumming techniques and its use in music making today?

This project will add and expand the academic study of music traditions in contemporary culture, in this case, that of the the frame drum; from its use in rural places for rituals and entertainment to its use in urban fusion bands; from its traditional way of playing to the incorporation of various techniques from many traditions 'into one'.

Through this project and your help you will be supporting my own development as a musician, as a percussionist of such a small- yet growing- frame drum tradition. You will help UK and the world to know more about the frame drum, its versatility as a percussion instrument and its use in various musical making activities, including healing.

 

What I Need & What You Get:

With my music making life and teaching jobs i can only just pay for my daily life expenses and can not save much money to pay for second year University fees and expenses for my MA project.

With your support and my own work I need to be able to pay for final year's fees, equipment needed for ethnographic film (digital camera, recording device) and travel expenses.

Fees are £2800 (Around £900 per trimester)

Equipment: £300 camera and £150 recording device.

Travel expenses: to USA £400 and to Greece £300

Tuition: in the USA £300 and in Greece £250

That sums up £4500, with is around 6000 dollars.

 

What you get (indicate what you want when making the donation):

You can get one of these if you donate $20, two of these if you donate $35 and all of them if you donate $60 onwards! :)

- A copy of my dissertation OR a copy (if possible. i still need to check it up with university and people involved in the film) of the Ethnographic film work DVD

- Free concert tickets to my performances (only once ;) )

- %15 discount for any workshop i organise in the UK (see my workshop history at www.nottas.co.uk)

- A 'Music in Stories 1' CD (Only 20 available. Sample audio in my website www.elizabethnott.co.uk)

If I do not reach my goal in October 15th this year,  I will still be using the money gained towards my studies and my development as a musician, including the purchase of a very good professional frame drum.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

- You can get the word out and 'make some noise' about my campaign.

- Use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Thank you!!!! :)

xx

story:
Note: to jump to video of Navar in action, click these links.

 

  • Video of Navar conversing in Japanese with native speakers (members of the group "Heavense." 
  • Video of Navar displaying some of his sword skills
  • Video of Navar performing an original spoken word piece in Japanese (with translation)

To view some of his artwork, click the "Gallery" tab above. Also in the Gallery tab are examples of his writings, in the "Files" section.

_____________________________________________________________________

 

Hello,

My name is Ashleigh Murray, I'm 25 years old and the second oldest of three children, but this campaign isn't about me; it’s about my remarkable little brother, Navar Clark. He’s 19 years old, a high school graduate, trilingual, and has Asperger’s Syndrome. He's the brightest, kindest, most eccentric person I've ever known. His biggest aspiration is to study in Japan and the best way for him to do that is by attending a college with a fierce study abroad program!

This past fall my mother and brother visited the campus of William Jewell College in Liberty, Missouri where they both fell in love with the institution. It wasn't the stunning grounds or high-end facilities that won them over, but the exceptionally stellar Japanese Studies department. Navar met with many of the faculty as well as the department's head. They were all equally impressed Navar's knowledge of Japanese culture as well as the language, especially since he taught himself how to read, write, and speak it in less than a year.

They finished up their tour of the campus in the financial aid office and that's where everything came to a screeching halt. The cost for the year was quoted at $42,790. That included tuition and room & board. Even with the grants, scholarships, and awards given him, there was a balance left of $4000. Sadly to say, my family couldn't afford to send him right away. My mother, doing her best to comfort Navar, assured him not to worry. We would try again to enroll him for the spring semester. Perhaps with the continuation of applying for scholarships and her attempting to find part-time employment, the monies would be available for him to attend in January. Even though this would be a daunting task, as my mother is disabled with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and on a fixed income, she was determined to help her youngest child realize his dream.

In November of 2012, my mother called me at work to say that she had spoken with the financial aid department at Jewell, and the balance due for Navar to attend college this January was about $800! You can imagine how ecstatic we were. I come from a lower-middle class family and just getting me through college was stressful enough.

Now, I am employed at a law firm here in New York City. While I don’t make loads of money, I get by. This year, we received Christmas bonuses, and so I decided that my gift to the family would be to give $500 to help make up most of the balance due. Sharing this news made for a joyous Christmas. My mother said she would try to find a way to make up the remainder. Navar was going to college!!

Last week, Mom called with will some unsettling news. She told me that the break down for the spring semester would be as follows:

  • $15,100 for tuition
  • $2,165 for housing
  • $1,715 for his meals
  • Total for the semester $18,980

Navar’s awards are the following:

Award

Description

Award Amount

Current Status

DLUSB

Federal Direct Loan (Unsubsidized)

$1,000.00

Accepted

NDSN

Federal Perkins Loan

$750.00

Pending

AMG

Access Missouri Grant

$1,175.00

Accepted

SCACH

Achiever Scholarship

$4,500.00

Accepted

CGND

WJC Cardinal Grant

$2,250.00

Accepted

CWSP

Federal Work Study

$1,000.00

Accepted

DLSUB

Federal Direct Loan (Subsidized)

$1,750.00

Accepted

PELL

Federal Pell Grant

$2,775.00

Accepted

DLUS2

Federal Direct Loan (Unsub)

$2,000.00

Accepted
 

Total for year

$17,200.00

  

Now, if you add the totals, the balance comes to $1780, not $800! So, where did the $800 figure come from? Well, the financial aid representative accidentally counted the work study amount twice when he quoted my mother the final balance. Once again, we found ourselves at an unreachable deficit. With my $500 gift, we are still $1280 short for his tuition, not including the $300 non-refundable deposit needed for housing. How could this be? It’s disheartening to think that such a small amount (in comparison to the total cost) is standing between my brother and a promising future. 

Navar is a very special young man who has overcome many obstacles in his young life. During the first 18 months of his life, he suffered from a total of 13 inner ear infections, which led to him getting tubes put in his ears at age 2. Because of these infections, he didn’t start talking until he was about 2 ½ years old. The doctors said this was because, during the first 18months, his hearing was muffled due to the fluid that was constantly in his ears. Once that issue was resolved, however, he began talking up a storm! His first clear word was “coffee.”  The day he first said it, we were all so happy and excited, praising him all day. Because of this praise, he ran around the house all day yelling, “Coffee! Coffee!”  Also, Navar’s favorite move at the time was The Lion King. He would watch it over and over for hours. The running joke in our house was that the Lion King taught him how to talk, because when he spoke, his tone and inflection mimicked that of Simba.

Navar faced many challenges throughout his school years, however he overcame each one. Although he had difficulty socializing and making friends, his level of intelligence and pragmatic, “little professor-type” speech endeared him to many. He began to develop a love for Japanese anime, which eventually led him to his passion for Japanese culture. He became so proficient in the language that, for his community service requirement for graduation, Navar taught a Japanese class after school once a week. His class consisted of fellow students and teachers. One of his students commented that Navar was one of the best teachers he’d ever had. 

Japan, however, is not his only passion. He loves learning all languages, as well as the arts. Not only did he teach himself Japanese, he also speaks French, having taken to the language so well that his instructor skipped him from French I to French III in his sophomore year in high school. By the time he graduated, he was in a class equivalent to first-year College French. Navar is an exceptional cartoonist, becoming quite proficient in anime, even to the point in creating his on characters. He loves music, and plays the trumpet, as well as teaching himself to play the piano. We were told by a music professor that he has perfect pitch. Due to his accomplishments in academics, he was nominated to serve as a National Scholar representing the state of Missouri at the National Young Leaders Conference (NYLC), which was held in Washington, D.C. during the summer 2011. He was personally selected by his physics teacher at Southwest Early College Campus, Mr. Grigori Saiyan, as an outstanding individual who has achieved academic excellence and possesses leadership potential.

Attending college is a huge step in his development, not just academically, but socially, as well. Because of the issues he has faced throughout his young life due to Asperger Syndrome, Navar struggled with his social development. He was constantly bullied in school by other students who didn't understand why or how he was different from them. However, Navar was steadfast in his efforts to fit in with his peers. He developed close friendships with certain students and teachers.  After a while, Navarre soon became a much loved person in the student populous.

Although technically, he is in the autism spectrum, Navar is what is considered extremely high-functioning. I feel comfortable in saying that Navar could be considered a genius. He is much like other famous geniuses who were/are thought to have Asperger's syndrome such as Bill Gates, Mozart, and Albert Einstein. I believe that, if given the chance, he could be one of the great contributors to human history.

The lengths of his talents reach farther than any website summary can muster, but allow me to leave you with some of his own words. One of Navar's favorite quotes about himself is, "There's no 'asp' in my burgers!"

I believe that says it all.
story_txt:
Note: to jump to video of Navar in action, click these links.
 

Video of Navar conversing in Japanese with native speakers (members of the group "Heavense." 
Video of Navar displaying some of his sword skills
Video of Navar performing an original spoken word piece in Japanese (with translation)
To view some of his artwork, click the "Gallery" tab above. Also in the Gallery tab are examples of his writings, in the "Files" section.
_____________________________________________________________________
 
Hello,
My name is Ashleigh Murray, I'm 25 years old and the second oldest of three children, but this campaign isn't about me; it’s about my remarkable little brother, Navar Clark. He’s 19 years old, a high school graduate, trilingual, and has Asperger’s Syndrome. He's the brightest, kindest, most eccentric person I've ever known. His biggest aspiration is to study in Japan and the best way for him to do that is by attending a college with a fierce study abroad program!
This past fall my mother and brother visited the campus of William Jewell College in Liberty, Missouri where they both fell in love with the institution. It wasn't the stunning grounds or high-end facilities that won them over, but the exceptionally stellar Japanese Studies department. Navar met with many of the faculty as well as the department's head. They were all equally impressed Navar's knowledge of Japanese culture as well as the language, especially since he taught himself how to read, write, and speak it in less than a year.
They finished up their tour of the campus in the financial aid office and that's where everything came to a screeching halt. The cost for the year was quoted at $42,790. That included tuition and room & board. Even with the grants, scholarships, and awards given him, there was a balance left of $4000. Sadly to say, my family couldn't afford to send him right away. My mother, doing her best to comfort Navar, assured him not to worry. We would try again to enroll him for the spring semester. Perhaps with the continuation of applying for scholarships and her attempting to find part-time employment, the monies would be available for him to attend in January. Even though this would be a daunting task, as my mother is disabled with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and on a fixed income, she was determined to help her youngest child realize his dream.
In November of 2012, my mother called me at work to say that she had spoken with the financial aid department at Jewell, and the balance due for Navar to attend college this January was about $800! You can imagine how ecstatic we were. I come from a lower-middle class family and just getting me through college was stressful enough.
Now, I am employed at a law firm here in New York City. While I don’t make loads of money, I get by. This year, we received Christmas bonuses, and so I decided that my gift to the family would be to give $500 to help make up most of the balance due. Sharing this news made for a joyous Christmas. My mother said she would try to find a way to make up the remainder. Navar was going to college!!
Last week, Mom called with will some unsettling news. She told me that the break down for the spring semester would be as follows:

$15,100 for tuition
$2,165 for housing
$1,715 for his meals
Total for the semester $18,980
Navar’s awards are the following:



Award


Description


Award Amount


Current Status




DLUSB


Federal Direct Loan (Unsubsidized)


$1,000.00


Accepted




NDSN


Federal Perkins Loan


$750.00


Pending




AMG


Access Missouri Grant


$1,175.00


Accepted




SCACH


Achiever Scholarship


$4,500.00


Accepted




CGND


WJC Cardinal Grant


$2,250.00


Accepted




CWSP


Federal Work Study


$1,000.00


Accepted




DLSUB


Federal Direct Loan (Subsidized)


$1,750.00


Accepted




PELL


Federal Pell Grant


$2,775.00


Accepted




DLUS2


Federal Direct Loan (Unsub)


$2,000.00


Accepted



 

Total for year


$17,200.00

 

Now, if you add the totals, the balance comes to $1780, not $800! So, where did the $800 figure come from? Well, the financial aid representative accidentally counted the work study amount twice when he quoted my mother the final balance. Once again, we found ourselves at an unreachable deficit. With my $500 gift, we are still $1280 short for his tuition, not including the $300 non-refundable deposit needed for housing. How could this be? It’s disheartening to think that such a small amount (in comparison to the total cost) is standing between my brother and a promising future. 
Navar is a very special young man who has overcome many obstacles in his young life. During the first 18 months of his life, he suffered from a total of 13 inner ear infections, which led to him getting tubes put in his ears at age 2. Because of these infections, he didn’t start talking until he was about 2 ½ years old. The doctors said this was because, during the first 18months, his hearing was muffled due to the fluid that was constantly in his ears. Once that issue was resolved, however, he began talking up a storm! His first clear word was “coffee.”  The day he first said it, we were all so happy and excited, praising him all day. Because of this praise, he ran around the house all day yelling, “Coffee! Coffee!”  Also, Navar’s favorite move at the time was The Lion King. He would watch it over and over for hours. The running joke in our house was that the Lion King taught him how to talk, because when he spoke, his tone and inflection mimicked that of Simba.
Navar faced many challenges throughout his school years, however he overcame each one. Although he had difficulty socializing and making friends, his level of intelligence and pragmatic, “little professor-type” speech endeared him to many. He began to develop a love for Japanese anime, which eventually led him to his passion for Japanese culture. He became so proficient in the language that, for his community service requirement for graduation, Navar taught a Japanese class after school once a week. His class consisted of fellow students and teachers. One of his students commented that Navar was one of the best teachers he’d ever had. 
Japan, however, is not his only passion. He loves learning all languages, as well as the arts. Not only did he teach himself Japanese, he also speaks French, having taken to the language so well that his instructor skipped him from French I to French III in his sophomore year in high school. By the time he graduated, he was in a class equivalent to first-year College French. Navar is an exceptional cartoonist, becoming quite proficient in anime, even to the point in creating his on characters. He loves music, and plays the trumpet, as well as teaching himself to play the piano. We were told by a music professor that he has perfect pitch. Due to his accomplishments in academics, he was nominated to serve as a National Scholar representing the state of Missouri at the National Young Leaders Conference (NYLC), which was held in Washington, D.C. during the summer 2011. He was personally selected by his physics teacher at Southwest Early College Campus, Mr. Grigori Saiyan, as an outstanding individual who has achieved academic excellence and possesses leadership potential.
Attending college is a huge step in his development, not just academically, but socially, as well. Because of the issues he has faced throughout his young life due to Asperger Syndrome, Navar struggled with his social development. He was constantly bullied in school by other students who didn't understand why or how he was different from them. However, Navar was steadfast in his efforts to fit in with his peers. He developed close friendships with certain students and teachers.  After a while, Navarre soon became a much loved person in the student populous.
Although technically, he is in the autism spectrum, Navar is what is considered extremely high-functioning. I feel comfortable in saying that Navar could be considered a genius. He is much like other famous geniuses who were/are thought to have Asperger's syndrome such as Bill Gates, Mozart, and Albert Einstein. I believe that, if given the chance, he could be one of the great contributors to human history.
The lengths of his talents reach farther than any website summary can muster, but allow me to leave you with some of his own words. One of Navar's favorite quotes about himself is, "There's no 'asp' in my burgers!"
I believe that says it all.

story: My name is Alex Mercer, and my friend Rob has been like a big brother to me ever since my parents died. I have always looked up to him and tried to follow in his footsteps. He has been working 2 jobs the past few years and juggling a full time school course load. He graduated from the University of Illinois with a Bachelors degree in Biomedical Engineering, and he has decided to continute on with his studies to get a Masters and eventually his Doctorate. The total expenses I am aware of are nearly $85k, but I plan to contribute as well, and he does have 2 jobs, so I don't want to be greedy. Any contributions made will be greatly appreciated. Keep in mind that 100% of this money is going to Rob for his tuition/boarding expenses. I honestly believe that he will help to make some significant advances in biomedicine and I need YOUR help to make his dream come true.

story:
UPDATE 12/14/13- WE RECEIVED DONOR MATCHING OF $1000!! Thank you so much to everyone who has donated so far and for helping us receive that donor matching as well! 

WHAT YOU GET IN RETURN

We’ve got a few fun perks for you in addition to the warm and fuzzy feeling you’ll get from helping some awesome kids! You can receive a handmade thank-you card from our students, recognition on our website and in the show playbills, a BBK tote bag, VIP tickets to the show, a private class from a professional teaching artist, a b-day party package, the chance to meet a Broadway performer and tickets to a Broadway Show! AND ITS TAX DEDUCTIBLE!


HELP US SPREAD THE WORD

Please share this with your friends! Facebook, tweet, email and tell strangers. Here are some samples that you can feel free to use!


it's #givingtuesday! Here is a great way to help kids and get yourself some warm and fuzzy feelings bit.ly/bwayboundkids #indiegogo #arts4kids

I just donated to @bwayboundkids to help provide FREE performing arts classes for kids bit.ly/bwayboundkids #indiegogo #arts4kids

join me in supporting Arts Education and @bwayboundkids bit.ly/bwayboundkids #indiegogo #arts4kids

Love the arts? Love kids? then donate to @bwayboundkids bit.ly/bwayboundkids #indiegogo #arts4kids

Help @bwayboundkids provide FREE performing arts classes for NYC kids bit.ly/bwayboundkids #indiegogo #arts4kids


Learn more about us at www.broadwayboundkids.org


THANK YOU FOR YOUR HELP! 


WE ARE A PROUD PART OF GIVING TUESDAY AND ARE THRILLED TO BE SPONSORED BY JETBLUE!

story:
I AM a Dream Doula, an Energy Shifter and a Lightworker and a Connector of Connectors. I am currently following my Divine Plan, my True Life Purpose, by studying to be an Angel Minister through Gateway University's Angel MInistry.  I have already graduated as an Angel Reader Certified (ARC) as part one of the three part Ordination Program which culminates, as SYNCHRONICITY would have it, on my birthday, or should I say my Rebirthday on April 11, 2013. 

My son and I have recently found ourselves homeless after my fiance who is suffering from alcoholism, broke off our engagment and asked me and my son to move out with no vehicle, no home or biological family to turn to and with only twenty cents in our pockets. I have been thinking a lot about how despite my fiances actions, I can continue to provide him with Uconditional Love and Support. He has never received this from anyone but me, and he is closing his Heart off to it. I know this is what is happening. Instead of Opening and Accepting my Light into his life, I AM Illuminating his dark places and he is terrified and closing the door.  I AM being a Conscious Observer of my life and my experiences and I AM opening my door and walking through this Gateway into a brand New World!

I AM Asking You, my Soul Brothers and Sisters and fellow Earth Angels, to shower me with your Unconditional Love and Support in allowing me the honor and the priviledge of continuing my Ministerial Studies.  

I consider myself a catalyst for transformation and a Rainbow Bridge to Spirit, helping others to create positive shifts and transformations in their lives. I AM both a student and a teacher. But, most importantly, I AM a Divine Human who is the perfect vessel to house my amazing Spirit.

It is part of my Life Purpose to Help people to become Aware of the blocks that are preventing them from Manifesting their Hearts' Desires by Shifting their Energy and raising their Vibration to Resonate with MORE, so that they can Create the life of their Dreams.

A Doula is a facilitator of the birthing process. As a Dream Doula, I accompany those who Connect with me on their Journey of Renewal and Rebirth, Shifting and Transforming negative Energy into Positive Channels of Peace, Love and Harmony.

As we Ride the Waves of Infinite Possibilities, we are Energizing and Enlivened. This process is never overwhelming. We learn that we have an Abundance of Unconditional Love and Support at any given moment, as we Discover that anyone can Open their Hearts and tap into the World of Spirit.

As a Dream Doula, think of me as an Earth Angel, a Beacon of Light, a Magical Sherpa, Guiding you to be your own Rainbow Bridge to Spirit. You will learn how to Recognize, tap into and make Strong, Intimate Connections with your Spirit Guides, Ascended and Cosmic Masters, Totem Animal Spirits and your own Team of Angels. These Incredible Beings of Light from the Celestial Realms are Delighted when you Connect with them and when you call to them and Ask for their Help. It is their job to respond to us with their Loving Assistance.

Together, with the Guidance of your Celestial Support Team, we will Help you to Clear the Clutter from your mind and your life so that you can have experiences of Healing, Release, Abundnace and Prosperity, Creativity, Joy, Love, Peace and Harmony, or whatever it is that your Heart and Soul Desires.

We will Transcend our life experiences by Being Conscious Observer of our own reality. From this perspective, we Recognize when we are blocking our own Receiving. Our challenges become our Strengths and we begin to value ALL of our life experiences. Obstacles become Opportunities leading us to the next step on the Divine Path to Discovering our True Life Purpose.

On this Journey, we will begin to bypass the ego and Clear ALL pockets of fear and negative emotions triggered by the experiences of life and Emerge Reborn into the Truth of who we really ARE!

I AM Truly Blessed and I AM Grateful to All of You who have been Guided to this Wonderful place filled with Unconditional Love and Support.   I look forward to living out my Dream of being that Catalyst, the one who stepped up and Helped our planet to Emerge from the Age of Darkness and into the Age of Light and Love, Creating a more Peaceful Transition to Heaven here on Earth.  How did I get so lucky to be a part of something that is so much bigger than me?  Even though this Feels so much larger and grander than me, there is Comfort in this Sense of Oneness.  We are so diverse, an individual, a community, an organization, yet, we are the Same, We ARE One; One whose Mission it is to Nurture Unique Divinely Human Potential, Ignite New Perspectives, Increase Global Consciousness and Causing Peace on this Beautiful planet.  Who could Ask for a better life than this?  This IS Heaven on Earth.

story:
Short Summary

American Alliance Group is small group of Emergency Medical Technicians.  Who came together to teach lifesaving CPR and First Aid to schools and non-profit community groups at low to no cost.  

Members of American Alliance Group have been dedicated to servicing our community for many years and together we have over 70 years of combined Emergency Services experience.  We are authorised American Heart Association Instructors.

Our campaign is to raise money to teach local teachers and school staff CPR & First Aid in an effort to enrich the lives of the community we serve.

By helping us you will be helping give someone a second chance at life through life saving education. 

Sudden cardiac arrest can happen to anyone, young or old, at any time. It is a leading cause of death in the U.S.  The good news is that the chance of survival more than doubles with immediate and effective CPR. 

With budget cuts and reduced salaries schools and educators can no longer afford CPR & First Aid training leaving our youth vulnerable.

Our goal is to educate our educators with life saving CPR & First Aid training.  Will you help us?  All monies received will go directly to providing as many schools as possible with CPR & First Aid training.

Ultimately we would like provide this training to every school in the Los Angeles metro area.  

Please give someone a second chance at life by helping provide life saving CPR & First Aid training.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Right now we are shooting for $5000.00 which will enable our group to teach the staff at 10 schools. Every $500.00 above the initial goal will enable our group to teach another school. 
 
Each class lasts approximately 4 hours and requires 5 instructors. (1 instructor for every 8 participants and each school has approximately 40 staff members).  Each class requires 40 mannequins (1 mannequin for every 2 participants).  Each class will consist of adult CPR and child CPR along with First Aid as well as Automated External Defibulator training. Each school will recieve an American Heart Association Text book to keep on hand.  Every participant in each class will recieve a 2 year Heartsaver CPR First Aid & AED certification card.
 
We are a dedicated group of public servants hoping to make the world a better place one community at a time with life saving education, saving lives one class at a time.
 
All monies will 100% go directly to teaching school staff members CPR and First Aid.  And if available to fund our goal of starting a nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing CPR and First Aid training to school staff and eventually to communities as a whole.
 
By helping our campaign you will receive the best gift of all, knowing that you helped save lives through life saving education.
 
With your pledge of,

$10 you will recieve a certficate of apprciation naming a school you helped

$25 you will recieve a certificate and a CPR barrier mask key chain.

$50 you will recieve a certificate, and a travel first aid kit.

$75 you will recieve a certificate, and a home or auto first aid kit.

$100 you will recieve all of the above and a framed photo of the teachers you helped at a school.

$1500.00 or more we will dedicate an Automated External Defibrillator at one of the schools in your honor with your name on a plaque or in the name of your choosing and a photo of the dedication. $1500.00 will cover the cost of an AED and wall case. Every school should have one.

The Impact

Community Service

  • CPR-trained citizens contribute to their communities by being able to help out in emergencies.
    Sudden cardiac arrest does not have to result in death. If more people are trained in CPR, more cardiac arrest victims will survive. Emergency medical personnel have a better chance of saving lives if someone is able to keep the cardiac arrest victim alive until they arrive on the scene.

The Leading Cause of Death

  • According to the American Heart Association, sudden cardiac arrest is the leading cause of death for adults in the United States. While millions of people have been trained to perform CPR, most Americans do not know how to perform the technique. The American Heart Association works to increase the number of people trained in the use of CPR in order to increase the number of sudden cardiac arrest survivors.

Emergency Preparedness

  • According to the American Heart Association, people trained in CPR can save the lives of people who have sudden cardiac arrest outside of hospitals. The American Heart Association reports that each year 294,851 sudden cardiac arrests occur outside of hospitals in the United States and that about 80 percent of all sudden cardiac arrests occur in the victim's home. People may suffer sudden cardiac arrest at work or in public places. The American Heart Association reports that few people who have sudden cardiac arrest outside of the hospital receive CPR -- about 27.4 percent -- and nearly 94 percent of all cardiac arrest victims die before they reach a hospital.

The Importance of Time for Survival

  • According to the American Heart Association, CPR provided immediately after cardiac arrest can double or triple the chance that a person will survive. For each minute following cardiac arrest that a victim does not receive CPR, the chance of survival is reduced by 7 to 10 percent. Resuscitation efforts are more likely to fail if the victim does not receive CPR and defibrillation in the first few minutes after sudden cardiac arrest. The American Heart Association encourages people to learn CPR because performing CPR adds minutes to the window of time during which a defibrillator is likely to restart the victim's heart.

Preventing Organ Death

  • The American Heart Association stresses the importance of immediate CPR to prevent brain death. CPR can prevent brain death by maintaining the flow of blood to the victim's heart and brain, but only if it begins within four to six minutes following cardiac arrest. The time it takes for medical personnel to arrive may be too long to prevent brain death or permanent organ damage. Performing CPR until emergency help arrives may determine whether a victim survives or how well a victim recovers.

 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

The American Heart Association reports that each year 294,851 sudden cardiac arrests occur outside of hospitals in the United States and that about 80 percent of all sudden cardiac arrests occur in the victim's home. People may suffer sudden cardiac arrest at work or in public places. The American Heart Association reports that few people who have sudden cardiac arrest outside of the hospital receive CPR -- about 27.4 percent -- and nearly 94 percent of all cardiac arrest victims die before they reach a hospital.




The Importance of Time for Survival




According to the American Heart Association, CPR provided immediately after cardiac arrest can double or triple the chance that a person will survive. For each minute following cardiac arrest that a victim does not receive CPR, the chance of survival is reduced by 7 to 10 percent. Resuscitation efforts are more likely to fail if the victim does not receive CPR and defibrillation in the first few minutes after sudden cardiac arrest. The American Heart Association encourages people to learn CPR because performing CPR adds minutes to the window of time during which a defibrillator is likely to restart the victim's heart.




Preventing Organ Death




The American Heart Association stresses the importance of immediate CPR to prevent brain death. CPR can prevent brain death by maintaining the flow of blood to the victim's heart and brain, but only if it begins within four to six minutes following cardiac arrest. The time it takes for medical personnel to arrive may be too long to prevent brain death or permanent organ damage. Performing CPR until emergency help arrives may determine whether a victim survives or how well a victim recovers.




 



Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
THANK YOU for all of the generous support.

These donations, combined with offline funding, have secured just over $22,000 that will fund the continuation of the project for the 2013-14 school year.

Tax-deductible donations can still be made on our Fractured Atlas site: www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=8198

 

WHO WE ARE

"In 2011, digital media educator and filmmaker Diana Gross embarked upon a yearlong sabbatical to help close the global digital divide by bringing technology and training to communities often overlooked by the international community. Working as The Traveling Teacher, she visited schools throughout eastern Europe and Southeast Asia, setting up blogging and skyping connections with other students around the globe. The cornerstone of the project became her "Tell Your Own Story" workshops  - mobile media production courses focused on photo, video and blogging with devices as simple as the iPad." -- National Geographic, Dec. 2012

The 'Tell Your Own Story' workshops were highly successful in beginning to include underrepresented global citizens in the discussion of our shared political, environmental, social and educational issues. The participants began to share their ideas for solutions to the problems that impact their countries. Individuals who were once simply passive users of the internet transformed into makers of digital media. And, they began to believe that their own voices are important enough to be heard. 

After being selected as a 2011 National Geographic Traveler of the Year and receiving worldwide support for her initiative, Diana launched Global Citizen Media in order to continue the project.

MORE INFORMATION

Click HERE to visit the official website.

For more information, check out recent media coverage: HERE

PROJECT GOALS

Global Citizen Media is about teaching skills and building confidence around citizen journalism and digital arts through mobile technologies and emerging digital and online tools. We empower underserved communities to consider and speak about the complex problems in their local, national, and international communities. GCM strives to achieve sustainability through building competency within local communities through short-term onsite trainings, training of local trainers, and ongoing digital mentorship.


In the first year of the project, workshops were provided to over 100 participants throughout Southeast Asian countries to enable them to share their stories through video production, photographic series, Skyping sessions and blogs. Youth participants have produced 24 videos that offer solutions in areas such as community health care, access to education, and quality of life. These videos gained international attention, won awards and grants for the participants, and advocated for additional funding for supporting organizations. Participants have begun blogging to share their community experiences with the world.


What Global Citizen Media has demonstrated is that through technology education and internet connectivity, all individuals are able to join the global conversations and become involved advocates for the development of their country despite limited or no previous computer skills. There is a supply of bright, motivated and diligent young citizens ready to accept the challenge of strengthening their communities using digital media as the vehicle.

PLEASE SHOW YOUR SUPPORT 

These participants need your help and support to meet that challenge. Global Citizen Media wants to empower more youth and young adults in their pursuit of citizen journalism and digital learning.  We are looking for funds to support: 

  • Two to three week 'Tell Your Own Story' workshops in which participants learn visual story telling and media production skills in order to share their lives with the world; 

  • Development and implementation of community-based technology curriculum;

  • Training local trainers to assist each community with the development of their curriculum and media production;

 

To put your tax-deductible donation into perspective:

  • $50 will pay to feed one participant during a Tell Your Own Story workshop

  • $100 will provide a Global Citizen Media kit for one participant that includes a USB internet stick, flash drive and SD card.

  • $250 will provide an entry level camera for participant photographic documentation of their community.

  • $500 will provide an iPad for basic video production.

  • $750 will provide a year's worth of safe and secure Edublogs blogging platform for participants in a single community.

  • $1000 will provide a mid-level digital SLR for advanced video production and photography.

  • $2000 will provide a MacBook Air for with software for advanced video and photography editing. 

  • $2500 will provide travel and lodging expenses for one Global Citizen Media teacher and local trainer within Southeast Asia.

  • $5000 will provide travela and lodging expenses for one Global Citizen Media teacher and local trainer in East Africa.

Our fundraising goal is $80,000.This will enable a growth of the program in Cambodia, and an expansion of the program into Myanmar and East Africa. We are seeking $30,000 from this IndieGoGO campaign while pursuing grants and corporate sponsorship for the remainder of the budget.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Our Story:

In 2010 a group of parents founded Padres Organizados por la Educacion en Sunset Park (POESP), in order to build relationships with local public schools and educate other parents regarding their rights in a new school system. Over the last 3 years, POESP has organized with and supported over 30 immigrant parents to become leaders and advocates for better educational opportunities in public schools.

With a new administration in New York City, now is the time for previously marginalized parents and students to organize and bring their concerns to the table. 



This project will allow La Unión to:

-Expand capacity to reach out to new parents to bring their concerns to the new administration

-Provide leadership trainings for new members

-Develop policy recommendations and community communications to create equitable educational opportunities for all students

-Work through existing coalitions and meetings between immigrant parents and education officials to have recommendations adopted

Our Goal: $5,000

Help us start strong in 2014

1. Community Outreach Meetings: space, refreshments, materials, childcare, staff time to develop outreach materials

2. Parent Trainings through Parent Meetings, Juega y Aprende: support materials, art and educational supplies, staff time

3. Research or Consulting cost for developing policy recommendations with parents' concerns at the center

4. Media and Communication Cost to gain exposure and support for policy recommendation

**If we don’t reach our goal of $5,000 we will continue to move forward with our policy recommendations, but  we won't be able to develop as strong of a force to bring our concerns to the table. We will also be limited in our ability to reach out and engage new parents.  


Current Work Around Education:

-Padres Organizados por al Educación en Sunset Park (POESP): A weekly parent organizing meeting centered around discussions and trainings to facilitate parent involvement in their children's education. Parents develop the meeting agendas, conduct outreach, do presentations about the group and its objectives, and develop campaigns to improve schools in Sunset Park.  

-Juega y Aprenda: A bi-weekly educational play group formed by 25 parents and their 2-4 year olds in partnership with PS 24 and Morningside Center to address the lack of educational programs for young children in Sunset Park. 

-ESL Classes: Bi-weekly adult English classes  grounded in notions of liberating pedagogoy and social justice values.  ESL students are also engaging as La Unión members. 

-ESOL Program: In addition to offering ESL classes to the community, we are currently training a group of 6 members of La Unión as ESOL teachers.

-Summer Camp: A program where intergenerational dialogue and learning takes place to advance the goals of transnational families.

Recent Highlights:

*June 2013- A group of mothers prepared and presented an exhibit and panel on the role of immigrant mothers in their children's' education at the CUNY Institute of Mexican Studies Annual Conference. (photos by David Bacon)

*July 2013- We held our 5th summer camp with 15 participants giving disadvantaged youth and their parents the opportunity to learn about college options and the college process along with learning about other community issues.

* '12-'13 School Year-POESP developed strong relationships with Dual School PS 24.  We now have the full support of the principal and a group of 10 teachers.

*This Year- We held or participated in over 12 outreach sessions educating and empowering over 450 immigrant parents regarding their rights in schools.


La Unión also does a lot of great work around immigrant rights and food justice.   Check out our website to learn more www.la-union.org

“My mom is involved in everything. When we were young, she always went to talk to the teachers even though she didn’t speak English and most of the teachers only spoke English. She always looked for some form of interpreter so she could understand what the teachers were saying.  She was always there...She was always fighting for us to have a better education and so we would stay on a better path.– David Sosa, son of POESP member

story:
We’ve written a book. We think it is pretty good. It is aimed at middle schoolers. It deals with kids acting, all on their own, to battle climate change. It is entertaining, it is empowering, it is inspiring.

No one knows it exists.

It is an ebook.  It is FREE. 

And it is a secret.

Not on purpose. We want everyone to know about it. To read it. To use it as a tool, a gentle yet potent tool, in the battle against climate change.

We’d like to get it into the hands of teachers,  who will then get it into the hands of their students.

So we made a mailing. A hard copy, old fashioned, put-it-in-the-teacher’s inbox kind of mailing.

We think our mailing is pretty good, too.

Here’s the rub: with printing, postage, labels, envelopes and labor, it costs over $2.50 to mail a packet of 7 flyers to just one school.

So far, we’ve sent it to nearly 300 middle schools in Washington state. Over 2000 teachers. But Washington state alone has about 400 public middle schools, and 200 private ones. Our first goal is to get a mailing into the hands of every middle school teacher in Washington state. That’s what this campaign covers - just Washington. But if we exceed our goal, we’ll move on to Oregon, California...as far as we can take it, thanks to your contribution.

In fact, if you donate $500, we’ll send an envelope of 7 fliers to 200 schools in the state of your choice!

We do have other perks, of course. (Curious about their names? If you read the book (it IS free, after all), they'll make sense). There are some mighty cool offerings. Read all about them, pick one or more, and please donate accordingly. We also would really appreciate if you would share this campaign with your friends and relations - they'll love the perks too!

The biggest perk, of course, is that you can help us spread the word about this free and inspiring teaching tool. Our goal at Island Stewards is to empower kids to move the needle on global warming disruption. Because we want kids, and their kids, and their grandkids, our kids and grandkids, your kids and grandkids, to have a healthy and livable future.

A Vote for the Future!

You can download a copy of the book yourself from our website: www.islandstewards.org    You’ll also find our other books, videos, all kinds of stuff there.

And, since Island Stewards is a 501(c)3 non profit, your donation is tax deductible.

We appreciate you sharing the book, the website, the campaign. We—you, teachers, parents, kids—working together, each contributing in our own way, can replace confusion with action. With those kids. By those kids. For those kids.

Thank You!

story:
Help Us Remember Maddie.


Our daughter, Madeleine Jean Tippett, tragically passed away on February 18th from an infection that spread to her heart. 

Our only comfort during this difficult time has been the love and support of our amazing family and friends. So many of you have asked how to best help or contribute to Maddie's memory. After discussing it with my wife, we may have an answer.

One of Maddie's favourite activities each week was playing with her friends at Gregson Park in Hamilton. As such, we'd like to install a bench at the park in Maddie's name. This will serve as a fitting memorial for her as well as providing benefit to the park and its visitors.

Please help us provide this gift to the community and honour the life of our daughter.


Regards, 

Mick & Kez.

story:
Donate today to help children from an underserved community stay on their feet and be active!

THE GOAL:

Who: The MCAAP Medical Student Committee needs your help!
What: Raising funds and collecting sneakers to encourage active lifestyles for the underserved children of Boston.
When: Spring 2014
Why: Because kids are AWESOME, and they deserve awesome new kicks to encourage them to move!

THE MISSION:

Do you remember your favorite pair of light up sneakers with the race cars on the side? Or maybe you rocked the TMNT logo on the side of your pumps. Or perhaps, the pink sparkly princess version was more your style.

Every kid deserves a good pair of sneakers to get them excited about being active. The Massachusetts Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics (MCAAP) Medical Student Committee is teaming up with the local Boston community to help  more kids have a pair of sneakers that fit. There are many children, just minutes away from you, without a solid pair of shoes for playing outside.

Excited boys and girls are being fitted right now for their brand new kicks. Help us get them their very own pair of dino sneaks :)

story:
The purpose of The Creative and Performing Arts of South County is to offer affordable, quality arts education to Southern Anne Arundel County, Northern Calvert County, and parts of Prince George’s County, Maryland.

Education in the arts includes Dance , Music , Visual , and Dramatic Arts.

The goal of the organization is not only to provide an arts education for the community, but it would also create more employment opportunities and continuing education for professional artists.



We need to raise funds for a facility for The Creative and Performing Arts of South County. The facility will bring arts classes and performances to the community by providing a space to hold classes, rehearsals, and art showings by associated groups.

Our ultimate goal is to bring to the community a full arts center, including theater and concert hall.
