story:
Why do Kids Need to Learn How to Program?

As a society we become more and more dependant upon technology in order for our society to function properly. Our reliance on IT demands that the generation that comes after us have a solid understanding about computers. Children today grow up using technology every day. But in addition to great technology users, we also need content providers and programmers that are able to make the products of tomorrow. 

But in order to reach out to a wider audience of kids, and open their eyes to the amazing world of programming, we need to provide them with challenging, yet fun project that can spark their love for the field. 

I wholeheartedly believe that teaching programming through hands-on, exciting and real projects like this will fuel the programming-spark in the students attending the course or reading the book!

Mr. Bill Gates tweeted recently about the gap between the market need for IT professionals and the number of students that finish with an IT degree. The discrepancy can be clearly shown in the diagram to the right. There is only one way we can fix this future issue, and that is getting the kids of today interested in computers and in programming. Source: https://twitter.com/BillGates/status/410126941220790272.

Teaching Kids Programming

I am teaching a hands-on programming course for children age 11-16 from January to May 2014. This will be a hands-on programming course where the students will learn both how to interact with physical hardware and devices, as well as hone programming skills. 

The end goal of the class is for the student, in groups, to build and control a remote-controlled car, starting from scratch without any prior programming experience. The on-board computer for the car will be a RaspberryPi. The students will have performed all of the experimentation, wiring and programming themselves. The car will be controlled wirelessly either from another RaspberryPi or from a computer.

The RaspberryPi mini-computer is such a wonderful and exciting product. Sadly though, whenever I show one to kids in the ages between 11 and 16, they have either not heard about it, or have never seen or actually used one. 

This course will use the RaspberryPi for what it's worth: An awesome educational tool that will show the students, via hands-on tutorials, what a computer is actually made of, as well as how one can be used in order to build cool projects and awesome products. The fact that the computer can be held in the students hand, and played with directly is great in order to facilitate learning!

Along the way, the students will learn about LEDs, resistors, DC motors and how to design and wire basic electrical circuits. 

Compiling a Book

One to two weeks before each class, the studens will be emailed a new chapter that will detail what we will be doing in the next class. This chapter will also be used as a reference throughout the class. 

Once the class is finished, all of the chapters will be assembled and sent off to a copyeditor and a designer. The end goal is for the book to be available online as a website, as well as in PDF and mobile eBook formats.

The manuscript for the book will be written in Markdown format. This format is easy to read without any formatting, while it is also extremely easy to parse and port into other formats, such as HTML and PDF. The Markdown manuscript will form the basis for the books website.

Open Source Licencing

The books content will released under the Creative Commons licence, while any source code in the book will be released under the MIT licence. This will ensure that the books content will be free and available for everyone once the book is completed. 

Language

The book will be available in two languages. Because the course itself is held in Norway the book will initially be written in Norwegian because I think it is important for the students to have material available to them in their native language. Each chapter will then be translated into English. 

Course and Book Content

The content of the course, and this also the book, is divided up into 7 lessons. Each lesson contains the material that each day of the course will contain. 

Lesson 1

  • Introduction to the RaspberryPi
  • Introduction to Linux
  • Putting in the memory card and booting the RaspberryPi
  • Logging into the Linux shell and executing simple commands

Lesson 2

  • Introduction to Programming with JavaScript
  • Introduction to Pijs.io (or similar service) and demonstrate how the Pi can be connected
  • Writing simple programs that can be deployed via Pijs.io and executed on the Pi
  • Learn about constructs like conditionals (if, if-else) and loops (if, for, etc)

Lesson 3

  • Using electronic components through a Breadboard. LEDs, resistors, sensors, etc.
  • Learn how to form an electric circuit. Make an LED light up
  • Writing a program that makes one LED blink
  • Writing a program that shows the current minute, in binary through LEDs

Lesson 4

  • Configuring a wireless network on the Pis Operating system Raspbian
  • Writing a program that accept input over the network, so that we can trigger events on the Pi (like turning on/off an LED or take a measurement through a sensor and return the value) 

Lesson 5

  • Introduction to DC motors
  • Learn how motors can be connected through Integrated Circuits in order to control the direction of rotation
  • Writing a program that can control the DC motor to run forwards, backwards and brake
  • Introduction to step motors

Lesson 6

  • Going through the parts we need in order to build a radio-controlled car (via a kit or via seperate parts)
  • Building and wiring up the car
  • Using the RaspberryPi to control the car, backwards, forwards and turning

Lesson 7

  • Continue building the RaspberryPi Car. 
  • Write software that can accept signals wirelessly in order to control the car
  • Program the car to drive a specific circuit

What Will the Funding be Used for?

The class itself will be held at a public library, which means that there is no rent involved. However, producing a book with good quality is not free, and even through I have previous experience in writing technology books, I still need help from a copyeditor and a designer in order to create a book that people will enjoy reading. 

Also, the hardware costs involved in organizing the course plays a role, with an estimated cost at about NOK 600-800 (EUR 100 - 130) per student (15 students).

The funding goal of EUR 10000 is broken down into: 

  • EUR 2000 for the hardware for the course
  • EUR 2000-3000 for copyediting and technical proofing
  • EUR 2000 for design work
  • EUR 150-200 Website hosting and related costs
  • EUR 2500-3000 for additional costs that will creep up along the way
  • EUR 700 IndieGoGo fees

Once the funding goal is reached, work will initiated in order to get the book available on Amazon, as well as setting up a fund where groups that are interested in teaching a similar course can apply to cover hardware costs for their class. 

What Will You Get For Supporting This Project?

There are four main backing options. 

Individual backer - 10 Euros and up

Your can choose to back with any amount from 10 euros and up. Everyone who backs this project will get the opportunity to be mentioned in the books "thank you" section. 

Sneak Peak - 25 euros and up

If you choose to back this project at this level you will, in addition to the perks of the individual backer, get an invite code where you can follow along with the books progress as the book is written (both for the Norwegian and the English Version)

Hardware Backer - 1000 Euros (2 backers max)

Hardware backers will either get their name, or their company logo clearly visible on the books front page, both on the book website and in the downloadable book versions. Hardware sponsors will also get an invite where they can follow along with the books progress as the book is written.

Book Backer - 1500 Euros (4 backers max)

Book backers help sponsor the cost of producing an excellent book that will be enjoyed by many youngsters that are trying to learn programming through a fun and engaging project. Book sponsors will get their name, or their company logo clearly visible to the books front page. Book sponsors also get to include one paragraph about themselves in the books preface. In addition, Book backers will get an invite where they can follow along with the books progress and read the chapters  as the book is written.

About the fundraisers

My name is Joachim Haagen Skeie. Through this project I hope to be able to inspire kids to love technology as much as I do! Kids today are growing up with a thorough understanding on how to consume and how to use technology and devices, but few actually get the opportunity to learn at an early age how to make something with and for the technology that exists. 

I really like to teach, and I have previously held training courses for IT professionals, where I've held multiple RaspberryPi introductory courses, as well as a two-day Ember.js course through the EmberFest conference (which I organize).  

I am currently in the final phase of finishing the JavaScript book Ember.js in Action, which will be published by the respected technology publisher Manning Publication. 

Unable to Back the Project, but Want to Help?

If you are unable to back the project financially, there is still loads of help you can give! Help promote the project on social media like Twitter, Facebook and Google+. Pass along links to the project to people you think might be able and willing to support the project. Any help will be greatly appreciated! 


With the Very Best Regards,

Joachim
story_txt:
Why do Kids Need to Learn How to Program?As a society we become more and more dependant upon technology in order for our society to function properly. Our reliance on IT demands that the generation that comes after us have a solid understanding about computers. Children today grow up using technology every day. But in addition to great technology users, we also need content providers and programmers that are able to make the products of tomorrow. But in order to reach out to a wider audience of kids, and open their eyes to the amazing world of programming, we need to provide them with challenging, yet fun project that can spark their love for the field. I wholeheartedly believe that teaching programming through hands-on, exciting and real projects like this will fuel the programming-spark in the students attending the course or reading the book!Mr. Bill Gates tweeted recently about the gap between the market need for IT professionals and the number of students that finish with an IT degree. The discrepancy can be clearly shown in the diagram to the right. There is only one way we can fix this future issue, and that is getting the kids of today interested in computers and in programming. Source: https://twitter.com/BillGates/status/410126941220790272.Teaching Kids Programming
I am teaching a hands-on programming course for children age 11-16 from January to May 2014. This will be a hands-on programming course where the students will learn both how to interact with physical hardware and devices, as well as hone programming skills. The end goal of the class is for the student, in groups, to build and control a remote-controlled car, starting from scratch without any prior programming experience. The on-board computer for the car will be a RaspberryPi. The students will have performed all of the experimentation, wiring and programming themselves. The car will be controlled wirelessly either from another RaspberryPi or from a computer.The RaspberryPi mini-computer is such a wonderful and exciting product. Sadly though, whenever I show one to kids in the ages between 11 and 16, they have either not heard about it, or have never seen or actually used one. This course will use the RaspberryPi for what it's worth: An awesome educational tool that will show the students, via hands-on tutorials, what a computer is actually made of, as well as how one can be used in order to build cool projects and awesome products. The fact that the computer can be held in the students hand, and played with directly is great in order to facilitate learning!Along the way, the students will learn about LEDs, resistors, DC motors and how to design and wire basic electrical circuits. Compiling a BookOne to two weeks before each class, the studens will be emailed a new chapter that will detail what we will be doing in the next class. This chapter will also be used as a reference throughout the class. Once the class is finished, all of the chapters will be assembled and sent off to a copyeditor and a designer. The end goal is for the book to be available online as a website, as well as in PDF and mobile eBook formats.The manuscript for the book will be written in Markdown format. This format is easy to read without any formatting, while it is also extremely easy to parse and port into other formats, such as HTML and PDF. The Markdown manuscript will form the basis for the books website.Open Source LicencingThe books content will released under the Creative Commons licence, while any source code in the book will be released under the MIT licence. This will ensure that the books content will be free and available for everyone once the book is completed. LanguageThe book will be available in two languages. Because the course itself is held in Norway the book will initially be written in Norwegian because I think it is important for the students to have material available to them in their native language. Each chapter will then be translated into English. Course and Book ContentThe content of the course, and this also the book, is divided up into 7 lessons. Each lesson contains the material that each day of the course will contain. Lesson 1
Introduction to the RaspberryPi
Introduction to Linux
Putting in the memory card and booting the RaspberryPi
Logging into the Linux shell and executing simple commands
Lesson 2
Introduction to Programming with JavaScript
Introduction to Pijs.io (or similar service) and demonstrate how the Pi can be connected
Writing simple programs that can be deployed via Pijs.io and executed on the Pi
Learn about constructs like conditionals (if, if-else) and loops (if, for, etc)
Lesson 3
Using electronic components through a Breadboard. LEDs, resistors, sensors, etc.
Learn how to form an electric circuit. Make an LED light up
Writing a program that makes one LED blink
Writing a program that shows the current minute, in binary through LEDs
Lesson 4
Configuring a wireless network on the Pis Operating system Raspbian
Writing a program that accept input over the network, so that we can trigger events on the Pi (like turning on/off an LED or take a measurement through a sensor and return the value) 
Lesson 5
Introduction to DC motors
Learn how motors can be connected through Integrated Circuits in order to control the direction of rotation
Writing a program that can control the DC motor to run forwards, backwards and brake
Introduction to step motors
Lesson 6
Going through the parts we need in order to build a radio-controlled car (via a kit or via seperate parts)
Building and wiring up the car
Using the RaspberryPi to control the car, backwards, forwards and turning
Lesson 7
Continue building the RaspberryPi Car. 
Write software that can accept signals wirelessly in order to control the car
Program the car to drive a specific circuit
What Will the Funding be Used for?The class itself will be held at a public library, which means that there is no rent involved. However, producing a book with good quality is not free, and even through I have previous experience in writing technology books, I still need help from a copyeditor and a designer in order to create a book that people will enjoy reading. Also, the hardware costs involved in organizing the course plays a role, with an estimated cost at about NOK 600-800 (EUR 100 - 130) per student (15 students).The funding goal of EUR 10000 is broken down into: 
EUR 2000 for the hardware for the course
EUR 2000-3000 for copyediting and technical proofing
EUR 2000 for design work
EUR 150-200 Website hosting and related costs
EUR 2500-3000 for additional costs that will creep up along the way
EUR 700 IndieGoGo fees
Once the funding goal is reached, work will initiated in order to get the book available on Amazon, as well as setting up a fund where groups that are interested in teaching a similar course can apply to cover hardware costs for their class. What Will You Get For Supporting This Project?There are four main backing options. Individual backer - 10 Euros and upYour can choose to back with any amount from 10 euros and up. Everyone who backs this project will get the opportunity to be mentioned in the books "thank you" section. Sneak Peak - 25 euros and upIf you choose to back this project at this level you will, in addition to the perks of the individual backer, get an invite code where you can follow along with the books progress as the book is written (both for the Norwegian and the English Version)Hardware Backer - 1000 Euros (2 backers max)Hardware backers will either get their name, or their company logo clearly visible on the books front page, both on the book website and in the downloadable book versions. Hardware sponsors will also get an invite where they can follow along with the books progress as the book is written.Book Backer - 1500 Euros (4 backers max)Book backers help sponsor the cost of producing an excellent book that will be enjoyed by many youngsters that are trying to learn programming through a fun and engaging project. Book sponsors will get their name, or their company logo clearly visible to the books front page. Book sponsors also get to include one paragraph about themselves in the books preface. In addition, Book backers will get an invite where they can follow along with the books progress and read the chapters  as the book is written.About the fundraisersMy name is Joachim Haagen Skeie. Through this project I hope to be able to inspire kids to love technology as much as I do! Kids today are growing up with a thorough understanding on how to consume and how to use technology and devices, but few actually get the opportunity to learn at an early age how to make something with and for the technology that exists. I really like to teach, and I have previously held training courses for IT professionals, where I've held multiple RaspberryPi introductory courses, as well as a two-day Ember.js course through the EmberFest conference (which I organize).  I am currently in the final phase of finishing the JavaScript book Ember.js in Action, which will be published by the respected technology publisher Manning Publication. Unable to Back the Project, but Want to Help?If you are unable to back the project financially, there is still loads of help you can give! story: Dear friends, I am going to Nepal at the beginning of April to do the Everest Base Camp trek. To make this trip more meaningful, I want to raise money for school supplies and hopefully school fees for the children. The name of the school is called Shree Siddha Kali which is located in Gorkha ( Historical area of Nepal and also part of the Himalayan trail ). Any donation amount is welcomed and your support is greatly appreciated. Thank you very much Raj from Green Valley Tour for helping me to set this up.

story: As you know we are lobbying to get the 28 redacted pages on the JIS report on 911 read and declassified. While there we would like to spend a day covering the anti-AIPAC conference April 10th. I already bought 2 tickets for $106 each. To pay for another night or 2 in DC and extend the stay and change the return date to Japan ($300) we need to raise a little more money. It is well worth it. This conference is only once a year. It puts ANC in touch with a lot of heavy hitters as well.

story:
Hi everyone, This is Andy, I just want to thank you for all those who contributed to my fund raiser for my flight training.... I received $55 Total. I am very optimistic about my flight training needs and I am looking forward to more opportunities that may come! Once again I am raising funds for my flight training to finish up my Commercial Pilots License! With your help I know I can accomplish my goals in becoming a Commercial Airplane Pilot! Take care and May The Good Lord Jesus Take a Liking to you! 

Blue Skies, Andy Hall

story:
El 1978 va néixer a La Garriga El Cau, l’Agrupament Escolta i Guia Mossèn Jaume Oliveras, una entitat sense ànim de lucre. Durant 36 anys ha aconseguit aportar als nens experiències molt constructives. 

Gràcies al cau valors tan importants com el respecte, l'amistat, l'estima cap a la natura, la iniciativa personal, la creativitat i l'autoestima han estat transmesos de generació en generació. Ha portat endavant nombrosos projectes que han contribuït a sensibilitzar els infants a l'hora de lluitar per un món millor tant a nivell local com global. Un exemple seria el projecte que es va realitzar a Nicaragua, on es va ajudar a construir una escola i a proveir-la d'ordinadors i llibres. Ha sigut sempre un espai obert i innovador, i volem que continuï així. 

No obstant això, per a desenvolupar-se correctament és necessari tenir un lloc, un local on realitzar les activitats. Hem tingut la sort que l’ajuntament de La Garriga ens ha cedit una casa feta a mida per assolir els nostres objectius però la normativa no ens permet utilitzar-la: l’escala principal no compleix les condicions necessàries i això fa impossible l'ús de gran part de la casa. Cal doncs, construir-ne una el pressupost de la qual puja prop d’ 11.000 €. 

Estem esforçant-nos en arribar a la suma esmentada, tot i així necessitem la vostra col•laboració per fer perdurable aquest somni.

Moltes gràcies!!



En 1978 nació en la Garriga El Cau, el grupo scout Mossèn Jaume Oliveras, una entidad sin ánimo de lucro. Durante 36 años ha conseguido aportar a los niños experiencias muy constructivas. 

Gracias al cau, valores tan importantes como el respeto, la amistad, la estima hacia la naturaleza, la iniciativa personal, la creatividad y la autoestima han sido transmitidos, de generación en generación. Ha llevado adelante numerosos proyectos que han contribuido a sensibilizar a los niños a la hora de luchar por un mundo mejor tanto al nivel local como global. Un ejemplo sería el proyecto que se realizó en Nicaragua, donde se ayudó a construir una escuela y proveerla de ordenadores y libros. Ha sido siempre un espacio abierto e innovador, y queremos que continúe así. 

Sin embargo, para desarrollarse correctamente, es necesario tener un lugar, un local donde realizar las actividades. Hemos tenido la suerte de que el ayuntamiento de La Garriga nos ha cedido una casa hecha a medida para lograr nuestros objetivos pero la normativa no nos permite utilizarla: la escalera principal no cumple las condiciones necesarias y esto hace imposible el uso de gran parte de la casa. Por ello, debemos construir una, el presupuesto asciende cerca de los 11.000 €. 

Estamos esforzándonos en llegar a dicha suma, aún así necesitamos vuestra colaboración para hacer perdurable este sueño.

Muchas gracias!!

story:
**** Please note: The family are aware of this campaign and we have been in touch with them******

Sean's medical assistance would not have been cheap at all! Let's show how much we really DO care about people! 

Sea Shepherd Australia Limited and No Shark Cull Inc. are acutely aware that Sean and his family need all the support they can get. We have been in touch with Paul de Gelder who received similar injuries from a shark bite and he has advised that he is willing or come to Perth from Sydney when Sean is ready and if he is willing. Some of the costs donated here will go towards getting Paul over - the rest will all go to Sean to cover some of the medical costs.

Any further questions? Please email info@nosharkcull.net

story:
Me in A Nut Shell

My name's Maggie, I'm 23 and I'm the second youngest of six. In the craziness that was my house growing up books were my escape. I started reading at a young age and never stopped. Anytime I wanted to escape my brothers or avoid doing something I didn't want to do or I was going through a tough time I would read a book. So that's what I want to do with my life, books. I want to be involved in bringing a story to life, a story that will help others the way books have always helped me and I'm so close to making that dream come true. I've been accepted into City University London for their Masters degree in Creative Writing and Publishing. This is my dream come true and I'm so close to it happening that I'm practically bouncing off the walls.

The Nitty Gritty

 The money I'm asking for is going towards tuition and housing. Combined and converted into american dollars it's going to be about $50,000, the extra $4,000 is for the fees involved in making the campaign. £13,005 for the apartment and £15,000 for the course. The conversion rate at the moment is $1.68 to £1. Those two things are the main costs I have and the main hurdles I have to overcome. Should I get anything over the goal that money will be put towards my visa, my books for the course, and food. 

Currently I'm working two jobs in order to save as much as I can while still making my student loan payments and my family is offering all the support they can. The goal is to get as much of it paid for without loans as possible so I can avoid going further into debt. Every little thing helps. Any money raised, whether I reach my goal or not, is going to go to my education and fulfilling my dream.

I spent time in  London last summer for school and since the moment I got on the plane to come home I've been dying to go back. To be able to do so in order to do what I've wanted to do for years is just mind boggling. Learning about publishing and bettering my writing skills in England is indescribable and I'm so thrilled I get the chance. 


Other Ways You Can Help

I know not everyone can make a contribution and that's ok. You can still help me by spreading the news. Let other people know, use the indiegogo share tools. Follow my example and just spam the heck out of your social media pages. Thank you from the bottom of my heart. :)

story:
Summary

Hi all
As you all know the devastation of Earthquake in Nepal has been increasing day by day. Things are getting worse, people are dying in lack of basic life sustaining things like water, food  medicine and shelter. Many heart wrenching photos can be seen by clicking  here  Earthquake in Nepal photos.  Therefore, to help the victims restore and regain the physical and mental trauma, we have decided to raise the fund for and by Gothalo Nepal. The team ,which has done exceptional social contributions in the past can be trusted to channelize the funds to the actual victims. In continuation of their social engagements, the team  successfully raised funds globally last year and  provided necessities to flood victims in Far Western Nepal, in a large scale. To see the details of the previous social engagement of the group please click Here. 
  1. Gothalo nepal details
  2. Registration number - 212
  3. Adress - Kalanki 14 , Kathmandu Municipality
  4. Contact no. of Gothalo Nepal  -  + 977-9841739944. 
 Nepal has, for the past decades been struggling itself on the widespread issues of fundamental human conditions - malnutrition, clean water, sanitation, epidemics, child labor, illiteracy, human trafficking, extreme poverty, electricity, cooking gas and many more  - Poverty in Nepal . As per UN and other development organz's Nepal faces one of highest malnutrition and early infant deaths every year in the world. Earthquake disaster to Nepal means a  massive  problem to cope up with, and the supply of economic, human , medical, food and water resources  is rare, if not very hard to manage.  
How are we funded and what we are doing - 

Our fund comes from various friends situated in Australia, USA, UK  and India. They raise money and donate to us for our initiatives. We have successfully provided life necessities to 200 flood victims in the past ( food and blankets) with the donors fund. We visit child labors, kids with HIV,  childrens of poor family and distribute them educationa materials, organise classes.  For the Earthquake relief we have started with our personal contributions and existing Organizational bank balance. 

 The fund collections from abroad will be kept in the Gothalo Nepal's bank account  and then will be used gradually - as the restoration will still take a long time.  The charity will be used to restore the child's live -  help buy them book, medicines, clothes and other required necessities. We will update our daily relief activities with details and images in our face book page  Please click to see our latest updates on relief.

Our latest updates  "Mission Earthquake Relief '' - 

 Day 1. Click here Day 2. Click here Day 3. Click here Day 4. Click here
Day 5. Click here Day 6  We worked with following Organizations to distribute rescue supplies  by visiting Tekana VDC, Sindhupalchowk 1.Child welfare scheme Hongkong 2.Freeedom matters UK, 3.Right for children Nepal - Click here details.
Other Ways You Can Help - 
You all can donate at other places too the link of which are -

1) Red Cross -  https://www.redcross.org/combined-donate?donationProdId=prod9150029&retrieveData=1&flow=oc1

2) Save the children  -  https://secure.savethechildren.org/site/c.8rKLIXMGIpI4E/b.9274575/k.FD90/Nepal_Earthquake_Childrens_Relief_Fund/apps/ka/sd/donor.asp

Also, we are including dedicated volunteers to join us in our efforts. Anyone interested please get in touch with us, drop your details at our Gothalo Nepal facebook page.

People in Kathmandu can also offer help by providing food, clothes, blankets, water, tents, sleeping bags , torchlights , shoes and many other things. Please come forward to help individuals, departments, organizations, volunteers, authorities and families in the rescue operations and rehabilitation efforts. 


Thank you people,
story_txt:
Summary
Hi all

As you all know the devastation of Earthquake in Nepal has been increasing day by day. Things are getting worse, people are dying in lack of basic life sustaining things like water, food  medicine and shelter. Many heart wrenching photos can be seen by clicking  here  Earthquake in Nepal photos.  Therefore, to help the victims restore and regain the physical and mental trauma, we have decided to raise the fund for and by Gothalo Nepal. The team ,which has done exceptional social contributions in the past can be trusted to channelize the funds to the actual victims. In continuation of their social engagements, the team  successfully raised funds globally last year and  provided necessities to flood victims in Far Western Nepal, in a large scale. To see the details of the previous social engagement of the group please click Here. 




Gothalo nepal details


Registration number - 212


Adress - Kalanki 14 , Kathmandu Municipality


Contact no. of Gothalo Nepal  -  + 977-9841739944. 




 Nepal has, for the past decades been struggling itself on the widespread issues of fundamental human conditions - malnutrition, clean water, sanitation, epidemics, child labor, illiteracy, human trafficking, extreme poverty, electricity, cooking gas and many more  - Poverty in Nepal . As per UN and other development organz's Nepal faces one of highest malnutrition and early infant deaths every year in the world. Earthquake disaster to Nepal means a  massive  problem to cope up with, and the supply of economic, human , medical, food and water resources  is rare, if not very hard to manage.  


How are we funded and what we are doing - 

 Our fund comes from various friends situated in Australia, USA, UK  and India. They raise money and donate to us for our initiatives. We have successfully provided life necessities to 200 flood victims in the past ( food and blankets) with the donors fund. We visit child labors, kids with HIV,  childrens of poor family and distribute them educationa materials, organise classes.  For the Earthquake relief we have started with our personal contributions and existing Organizational bank balance. 
 The fund collections from abroad will be kept in the Gothalo Nepal's bank account  and then will be used gradually - as the restoration will still take a long time.  The charity will be used to restore the child's live -  help buy them book, medicines, clothes and other required necessities. We will update our daily relief activities with details and images in our face book page  Please click to see our latest updates on relief.

story:
Hello, I am a printmaker.  

I am excited to announce that York University, located in Toronto, Canada, has accepted my application for Graduate Studies.  It has long been my goal to return to school - that dream begins in September, 2015

With your help I will spend the next two years exploring both traditional and alternative print techniques, making a new body of work that focuses on the interplay of memory and family photographs.  How does the blending of truth with untruth shape our understanding of our past and form our identity today?  While I have saved enough funds to pay for tuition and basic expenses, I need your help to acquire the necessary materials to truly push my professional practice.

My goal is to raise $2000 and I ask you to invest in my education by pledging whatever you can afford and as a return on this investment you can choose an artwork from the selection listed here (The prints listed as your perk is at a sponsorship level that is roughly equal to it's fair market value, you aren't pledging in so much as you are buying a work of mine).  In addition to owning one of my works, I will also keep you informed of my progress throughout my studies, giving you a "sneak peak" of what I am working on in the studio along with insight into my creative process.

Of course, any amount raised will allow me to reach some level of artistic potential, but removing the constant worry of material costs will ensure that I can fully explore all creative options.  

With your support, I know I can create great works that both you and I will be proud to have been part of.

story:
Did you know...

that there are over 1,500 Intentional Communities, planned residential communities where people live together under a common vision/values, in the United States alone? Almost all of these communities have sustainability as an aspect of their focus; many create local organic farms, local businesses, and establish land trusts to protect open spaces from development.  

Many members I have already spoken to have shared how difficult it was for them to find, understand, and afford legal information, resources, and advice needed to establish their communities.  Legally Unconventional aims to fill this space, connecting the public and legal practitioners with the resources and information necessary to navigate the laws of community. 

Even if you don't live in an intentional community, the encouragement of conscious, sustainable, and local efforts will help benefit all.  The more we learn from these social experiments in collective resources, the better we can re-define and improve on the governance systems, decision making models, conflict resolution, and communication we use in our cities and our own lives.


Short Summary

My name is Jacqueline Horani and I just finished my 1L year at law school.  In response to the pressures to pursue a career that will 'get me places' I was losing faith as I saw my public interest peers succumb to the draw of firm life.  After attending the Rebellious Lawyers Conference at Yale, my salvation, I decided to take my future career into my own hands. I've discovered a movement of lawyers working to create a more integrative approach to law, who are working to shift adversarial law to a more collaborative, communicative, and peaceful approach.  Through the encouragement of an incredible mentor I've developed an externship adventure to draw awareness to Intentional Communities and the growing field of Community Law/Sharing Economics.  

What the project entails:

  • Me traveling across the U.S. to visit and interview intentional communities and meet with legal practitioners on the intersection of law & community. 
  • A website where I post my blog, interviews, photos, videos, & resources.
  • A listing of practicing lawyers communities can reach out to for legal advice.
  • A legal article on my research & findings, hopefully formally published.
  • AND Facebook, Twitter, & Instagram where YOU can follow the project live.

Please support my goal of providing the information and access to resources necessary for thousands of people across the U.S. to create stronger communities.  

The Budget

I'm asking for $1,500 so that my project can get westward bound!

* As a public-interest project, my school gives me a $4,500 stipend.

* In contrast, a Big Law firm job offers students $15,000 their 1L summer.

If my goal is met for 10% of a Firm Salary, I will be able to complete this project without going into debt (outside of my existing school loan debts).

  • I already have a computer, smartphone, and my two legs to create everything needed.  After purchasing some essentials (Travel Backpack, First Aid Kit, Sunscreen, Bug Repellent, etc.) I'm ready to get moving.  
  • Any money raised for this project will go to: 
  • Transportation: a combination of bus, train, and gas money
  • Housing: a few communities will invite me to stay for free, but others charge between $15-$65 a night.  
  • Food: luckily this should be a really small percentage as most communities include meals for visitor stays. 
  • Project Development: this includes the times I need to hire someone to help me edit my website's code to make it more reader-friendly (If you know someone please let me know!!!).  
Every dollar you give helps me reach one more community, one more state, and helps to provide a more accurate understanding of the National Intentional Community culture of law.  

    The Impact

    If you support this project you'll be encouraging myself and other law students that there really is a way to succeed outside of Big Law.  

    • You and everyone else who hears about this can discover a new way of living and we take what we can learn together from Intentional Communities to better shape our own culture. 
    • You'll be helping me to connect lawyers, organizations, and communities who are all aiming for similar goals but often have not heard of each other.
    • Already people are sending me questions and concerns they have about their legal set-ups and already lawyers are following my project, some even wanting to join the travels! 

    Risks & Challenges

    Although I took the train from Nebraska to New York when I first moved to law school, I have otherwise not travelled using bus and train as my main mode of transportation.  There is the chance that I may get delayed or miss connections from place to place.  Additionally, there is the chance that I get so much information that I can't keep up with putting it all together according to timeline.  

    Therefore:

    • I will break the trip up into smaller sections, creating a route for each section and making my arrangements for transportation in advance.  
    • I am also breaking the trip up in a way that allows for recovery days in between routes so that I can catch up on my writing and update the blog.  
    • Also, there are obvious risks of traveling to new and exotic places, but I have safety smarts that I hope will carry me well.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute dollars, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Please check out my blog and read up on the adventure!
    • Follow us on Facebook and join the conversation on community.
    • Get live feed updates of community visits on Twitter.
    • Share this campaign! If you know of someone who might be interested please email them a link! Or share it with all of your friends, flyer your neighborhood, post it in your local courthouse, etc.  (I may have to come up with a special reward for advocacy creativity…)
    • And if you're not into the social media craze, please just support your loved ones, your children, your peers to pursue what really makes them happy rather than the status quo.  

    One of the most important things is to never lose your passion, 

    so thank you for supporting mine.

I will break the trip up into smaller sections, creating a route for each section and making my arrangements for transportation in advance.   I am also breaking the trip up in a way that allows for recovery days in between routes so that I can catch up on my writing and update the blog.

Please check out my blog and read up on the adventure!

story:
Summary

This campaign is Phase 1 of 5.  We are currently raising funds so that therapeutic art facilitator, Kat Thorsen, can spend two months writing and illustrating a life skills and entrepreneurship handbook in partnership with Operation Sock Monkey (OSM). 

WHAT IS OSM?

OSM (founded by Lindsey Hodgson) is a volunteer-run initiative in support of humanitarian organizations that provide laughter, hope and healing to communities around the world affected by disease, disaster and social/political turmoil.  

WHY A HANDBOOK?

The OSM handbook will allow us to leave a lasting and empowering legacy of art-, life- and business-skills when we complete our field work.  

The target consumer of the handbook includes:

• Youth programs (youth-at-risk, inner city, rural, secondary schools, alternative schools)

• Global community groups 

• Therapeutic and Special Needs support programming

• Micro-industry development

• Intergenerational programs

Photo courtesy of Operation Sock Monkey and Help Madgascar

WHO IS KAT THORSEN?

Kat Thorsen is a therapeutic art facilitator, artist, author and craftvist.  She is passionate about the healing power of art and her mission is to awaken creative expression through local and global art initiatives. Kat has used sock monkey therapy for many years in her work with at-risk youth on Vancouver's Downtown Eastside and in the North Vancouver School District.

Kat has been an active operative of OSM since 2009.  Countless numbers of her students and colleagues have since joined the operation!

You can read more about Kat at katthorsen.com.

You can read more about the handbook plans at OSM Handbook Development.

For more on the life skills to be covered in the OSM handbook, go to: LINK

WHAT ARE THE PHASES OF THE OSM HANDBOOK PROJECT?

This campaign covers Phase 1.

Phase 1: Write and illustrate the book.

Phase 2: Implement local pilot projects at Mountainside Secondary, North Vancouver BC and Byrne Creek Secondary, Burnaby BC.  Apply for publishing grants.  Develop sponsorship partners.

Phase 3: Publish handbook and campaign for travel funds.

Phase 4: Implement program in New York City (target: Harlem Children's Zone) and San Francisco (target: Centre for Young Women's Development)

Phase 5: Implement program in South Africa (Kwa-Zulu Natal and Cape Town) in September 2015 .  

What We Need & What You Get

  • The money raised will be Kat's income for two months.  We need to have a prototype ready for when school gets back in session in the Fall.  
  • The pilot projects will allow Kat to refine the handbook and incorporate photography and to develop a website.
  • If we do not reach our goal, we will have to fundraise through alternative means so that we can complete this most important and urgent work.
  • If we exceed our goal, the funds will allow us to pay honorariums to a core group of local youth who will help implement the pilot project and to continue refining the handbook.  We will also be able to offer the pilot projects to more schools and special needs groups, and to focus on website development and printing costs.  
  • A Spring 2015 Indiegogo campaign will fundraise for the September 2015 OSM South Africa trip.
  • In the perks section, you will see some amazing rewards depending on the level of contribution!  Of course the theme is all about the sock monkey!


The Impact

  • Your contribution will allow OSM to provide sustainable programming.  OSM is already in the field around the world.  Now it's time to create a lasting and empowering educational component!

    Photo courtesy of Operation Sock Monkey 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
    • It's very easy to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    Much love and thanks,

    Operation Sock Monkey

    The handbook is dedicated to all the sock monkey makers of the world!

story:
My Story

Hello there... My name is Philippe Paul and I am a 17 ( soon to be 18) year old A-Level student studying in the northern parts of London. Oh and I am the Guy on the left side of the picture shown above!

 A few months ago, my school (Highlands Secondary School) partnered up with a company called 'Schools Worldwide' which provide "adventurous school trips and affordable overseas school expeditions, community projects and study trips for young people". The particular trip that students were offered at my school was a 17 day trip to Zambia and Botswana where we will be trekking along the Zambezi River and also helping the local community in Livingstone. 

The trip is allowing me to do what I have not done so well throughout the course my life, which is one of the greatest powers any human can hold... To GIVE! I signed up for the trip because I felt that if I can change lives for the better in this community, I can also change my life for the better and become more giving. 

I have fund raised a total of £60 so far through car washes for teachers and family and friends kindly donating to me. I am not going to lie when I say I have had a struggle so far trying to raise funds for this trip. The amount of work that needs to be put into A-Levels which decides the outcome of which university you are going to attend, can be so tough at times that the time to fund raise has been greatly reduced. This is where you guys can hopefully make an immense impact on my Fund Raising Progress...

What Will I Be Doing On The Zambia & Botswana Trip?

The trip will run over the course of 17 days which will be in Livingstone, Zambia and Chobe, Botswana and I will be documenting the moments with my camera over the duration of the trip which I will edit and upload onto YouTube once I arrive back in the UK.

The first two days are spent travelling to the airport where we will then head on a 10 hour flight and spend the day in Livingstone, Zambia where we will have a chance to relax and buy supplies before we head out on our 4 day trek!

The 4 day trek along the Zambezi River which is Africa's 4th Longest River is where we will be camping out in the open at night and seeing the beautiful wildlife and nature the Zambezi has to offer. 

We then will be spending the next 5 days working with the community in Livingstone on various projects which will be:-
-Working in a School to improve the facilities and meet some of the young students
-Visiting an Old People's home to spend time with some of the residents
-Help improve the healthcare and water resources
-Creating a community garden to help the people of Livingstone become more self sufficient 

After that we will set out to Botswana for 2 and a half days where we will be going on a safari expedition at the Chobe national park where we will be seeing herds of Buffaloes, Zebra's, Crocodiles, Lion's and a lot of the other great animals Chobe has to offer.

We then return to Zambia where we will be spending the day visiting Victoria Falls which is one of Africa's most famous and beautiful waterfalls.

The next day we will be exploring the local area in Livingstone which will give us a chance to visit some of the local businesses and celebrate what we have achieved on this trip.

The next two days will then be spent going to the airport and taking a 10 hour flight back to the UK!

What The Funds Go Towards

My School and Schools Worldwide have set us two fund raising deadlines. The first deadline is a £1096 instalment by the 21st of November and the second is a £1353 meaning the total amount I have to fund raise is £2449. 

I have decided to focus on each instalment's at a time rather than to try and raise the total amount at one time which is why I will be creating two campaigns. The first one is this one and the second one will be up around February. 

The funds goes towards many things such as Travel, Accommodation, Vaccinations, Equipment and resources to give towards the community in Livingstone, 

If I am able to raise more than £1096 in this campaign, I will be contributing the rest of the money towards my second deposit which deadlines in April. If I am able to raise over £2449 (which I would be eternally grateful for!) the money left over will go towards other students instalment's so they are able to have the chance to embark on this journey with me!

If however, I fail to reach these targets, I will give all funds that have been raised to other students embarking on the trip to Zambia and Botswana.

 I wish to mention as well that fund raising efforts will not be totally reliant on this campaign as I will be fundraising through various other ways such as setting up school disco's for the year 7's in my School, Cake sales, car boot sales and various other ways. This campaign will just be a huge help towards fundraising efforts as it will allow me more time to study for my A-levels and for that, I will be grateful if you wish to donate or simply spread the word of this campaign. 

    The Impact

    I have never been a part of a project nearly similar to this and me going on this trip will not only have a massive impact on my life but you will be glad to know that you contributing for this trip will also affect the lives of the residents of Livingstone in Zambia.


      New Perks Available!!!


      Other Ways You Can Help

      I understand not everyone can afford to donate which is 100% understandable but I will be very grateful even if you are just spreading the word and making some noise about my campaign.

      Contact

      Email - Philippe_29@hotmail.co.uk

      For more information Visit http://www.schoolsworldwide.co.uk/home.html
story_txt:
My Story Hello there... My name is Philippe Paul and I am a 17 ( soon to be 18) year old A-Level student studying in the northern parts of London. Oh and I am the Guy on the left side of the picture shown above!
 A few months ago, my school (Highlands Secondary School) partnered up with a company called 'Schools Worldwide' which provide "adventurous school trips and affordable overseas school expeditions, community projects and study trips for young people". The particular trip that students were offered at my school was a 17 day trip to Zambia and Botswana where we will be trekking along the Zambezi River and also helping the local community in Livingstone. 
The trip is allowing me to do what I have not done so well throughout the course my life, which is one of the greatest powers any human can hold... To GIVE! I signed up for the trip because I felt that if I can change lives for the better in this community, I can also change my life for the better and become more giving. 
I have fund raised a total of £60 so far through car washes for teachers and family and friends kindly donating to me. I am not going to lie when I say I have had a struggle so far trying to raise funds for this trip. The amount of work that needs to be put into A-Levels which decides the outcome of which university you are going to attend, can be so tough at times that the time to fund raise has been greatly reduced. This is where you guys can hopefully make an immense impact on my Fund Raising Progress...   
What Will I Be Doing On The Zambia & Botswana Trip?

The trip will run over the course of 17 days which will be in Livingstone, Zambia and Chobe, Botswana and I will be documenting the moments with my camera over the duration of the trip which I will edit and upload onto YouTube once I arrive back in the UK.

The first two days are spent travelling to the airport where we will then head on a 10 hour flight and spend the day in Livingstone, Zambia where we will have a chance to relax and buy supplies before we head out on our 4 day trek!

The 4 day trek along the Zambezi River which is Africa's 4th Longest River is where we will be camping out in the open at night and seeing the beautiful wildlife and nature the Zambezi has to offer. 

We then will be spending the next 5 days working with the community in Livingstone on various projects which will be:-
-Working in a School to improve the facilities and meet some of the young students
-Visiting an Old People's home to spend time with some of the residents
-Help improve the healthcare and water resources
-Creating a community garden to help the people of Livingstone become more self sufficient 

After that we will set out to Botswana for 2 and a half days where we will be going on a safari expedition at the Chobe national park where we will be seeing herds of Buffaloes, Zebra's, Crocodiles, Lion's and a lot of the other great animals Chobe has to offer.

We then return to Zambia where we will be spending the day visiting Victoria Falls which is one of Africa's most famous and beautiful waterfalls.

The next day we will be exploring the local area in Livingstone which will give us a chance to visit some of the local businesses and celebrate what we have achieved on this trip.

The next two days will then be spent going to the airport and taking a 10 hour flight back to the UK!
What The Funds Go Towards My School and Schools Worldwide have set us two fund raising deadlines. The first deadline is a £1096 instalment by the 21st of November and the second is a £1353 meaning the total amount I have to fund raise is £2449. 
I have decided to focus on each instalment's at a time rather than to try and raise the total amount at one time which is why I will be creating two campaigns. The first one is this one and the second one will be up around February. 
The funds goes towards many things such as Travel, Accommodation, Vaccinations, Equipment and resources to give towards the community in Livingstone, 
If I am able to raise more than £1096 in this campaign, I will be contributing the rest of the money towards my second deposit which deadlines in April. If I am able to raise over £2449 (which I would be eternally grateful for!) the money left over will go towards other students instalment's so they are able to have the chance to embark on this journey with me!
If however, I fail to reach these targets, I will give all funds that have been raised to other students embarking on the trip to Zambia and Botswana.
 I wish to mention as well that fund raising efforts will not be totally reliant on this campaign as I will be fundraising through various other ways such as setting up school disco's for the year 7's in my School, Cake sales, car boot sales and various other ways. This campaign will just be a huge help towards fundraising efforts as it will allow me more time to study for my A-levels and for that, I will be grateful if you wish to donate or simply spread the word of this campaign. 

  The Impact I have never been a part of a project nearly similar to this and me going on this trip will not only have a massive impact on my life but you will be glad to know that you contributing for this trip will also affect the lives of the residents of Livingstone in Zambia.

  
New Perks Available!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

 I understand not everyone can afford to donate which is 100% understandable but I will be very grateful even if you are just spreading the word and making some noise about my campaign.
Contact
Email - Philippe_29@hotmail.co.uk
For more information Visit http://www.schoolsworldwide.co.uk/home.html

story:
There have been 67,000+ Foreclosures in Massachusetts since 2005... and the nonprofit Massachusetts Alliance Against Predatory Lending (MAAPL) can prove that almost all of them were illegal. We teach foreclosed homeowners how to expose banks' illegal activities, come together to fight, and win!

With your generous investment, MAAPL and its homeowner-members will:

• Stop future foreclosures and their destruction of families and communities;

• Contact the thousands of illegally foreclosed homeowners who don’t yet know their rights, give them the legal and organizational support to keep or regain their homes, or to win just compensation for their loss; and

• Bring home the billions of dollars in wealth that the banks’ greedy foreclosures stripped from our communities and local economies.

Our homeowner-members support others also facing foreclosure. Our proven methods are winning against big banks and their predatory tactics. Your tax-deductible donation will help us win justice for foreclosed homeowners!


Help Us Turn the Tide!

Contrary to the headlines, foreclosure activity in Massachusetts and the nation is again on the rise. September 2014 saw a 68% increase in the first step of the foreclosure process over a year earlier. 

This is where we as a community – people who care about our neighbors, and our children’s and grandchildren’s economic future – come in. This is where you come in.

Support MAAPL to defeat this new wave of foreclosures!

With...

✓  Your first $3,000 raised, using bank-published auction notices, MAAPL will email or text the 225+ Massachusetts homeowners whose homes are scheduled for auction each month over the next year.

✓  Your next $5,000, MAAPL will coordinate calls by homeowner-members – who know the personal struggle to save a home – to each homeowner pre-auction with detailed steps they can take, and personally reply to each email from those seeking to save or recover their homes.

✓  Your next $10,000, MAAPL will host regular webinars and interactive educational conference calls open to all homeowners, pre- and post-foreclosure, fighting for their homes... supporting hundreds to learn, work together and, yes, keep or regain ownership of their homes!

✓ The full $30,000, MAAPL will get its message out in newspapers, radio, and social media: Homeowners can stay in their homes post-foreclosure and fight any eviction in court. We will hold Homeowner Foreclosure Defense workshops in each region of the state for those foreclosed from the beginning of this crisis through the present.

With your help, Massachusetts homeowners and communities will win! And what we win will be copied across the nation.

In addition to the great feeling that comes from helping your neighbors stay in their homes while fighting back against the big banks' predatory practices, we are offering some great perks to our supporters: ringtones and  desktop wallpapers, a delicious bread recipe, postcards, and more!

The Impact of Our Work and Your Support

Your generous donation supports our efforts on behalf of Massachusetts residents like Rochelle! The local MAAPL chapter found her in the court hallway–in the next hour, the bank would have evicted her from her illegally-foreclosed home. She had no lawyer. We showed Rochelle how to get her case re-started. With support from other MAAPL-member homeowners working to save their own homes, she fought through until... Today, Rochelle has her home back in her own name, and can afford her mortgage!

15 million US homeowners did not suddenly turn stupid early in the 2000s–the banks changed how they sold mortgages. This created a huge housing price bubble. Big banks made trillions. When the bubble burst, homes lost as much as half their value. Foreclosures then drove job losses and fueled the Great Recession.

But big banks often don’t play by the rules. In case after case after case, they don’t have title to the mortgage. Yet they foreclose anyway. By themselves, homeowners find it hard or impossible to fight the shame, get the information they need, and defeat the tricks of the wealthiest businesses in the world.

That’s why MAAPL was born in 2007. We began as a small band of grassroots housing and legal activists hearing strange tales of broken promises: homeowners finding interest rates and fees far higher than their initial offer, banks unwilling to refinance to lower rates at the promised time, and renters evicted with little notice.

We are now a statewide coalition of more than 70 diverse organizations concerned about the tsunami of foreclosures devastating our families and communities. We have helped the public understand that the nation’s foreclosures – particularly in neighborhoods of color – are in most cases due to big banks, not homeowners.

What’s more, MAAPL’s small paid staff, with legal and other volunteers, leverages every donation by showing homeowners facing foreclosure how to help themselves.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are grateful for every dollar we receive to help win the fight against illegal foreclosures in Massachusetts. But we know that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially to this campaign. There are other important ways you can help....

Spread the word about this campaign to your friends and networks! Please feel free to link to this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and other platforms. The more people who know about this campaign, the more likely it is that we will reach our funding goal!

Don't forget that you can use Indiegogo's Sharing tools to help us get the word out.

Thank you for your support! Every donation counts!

When we fight together, we WIN!

Your contribution to MAAPL is tax-deductible to the full extent of the law.

NOTE: The acknowledgement notice for your contribution lists MAAPL member organization and fiscal sponsor, Four Corners Action Coalition. However, MAAPL is the actual recipient of your generous donation.

For more information on MAAPL's initiatives and resources for homeowners, please visit our Web site at MAAPL.info

story:
Meet LOODI

Ludiwine Clouzot, also called “Loodi”, is the founder of Ecoloodi, a bilingual non-profit organization that provides tools and educational services to teach children the importance of protecting our water resources and aquatic ecosystems. Ludiwine moved to Canada from France in 2010, with a passion for water and a love for children. She had just earned her PhD in Water Engineering and was already thinking of her next step: “How can I use my skills to make sure that everyone, and especially children, have access to clean water?”.   

In 2012, Ecoloodi was born. Ludiwine decided to build on the idea of small drop of water, creating a character named “Loodi”,  to connect with children. Now, Ecoloodi needs support to reach its goal of empowering the decision-makers of tomorrow to increase chances of protecting our most precious resource. Using water as a unifying experience, Ludiwine wants to turn education into action. 

 

What have we done so far?

Ecoloodi has achieved some pretty awesome things over the past year! We have worked with great organizations including Ecologos (Water Docs film festival), Engineers Without Borders, the Royal Ontario Museum, the Toronto Public Library, and the French Consulate in Toronto. We have been featured by media outlets, both in print (Le Métropolitain and the Express) and on television and radio (CBC). We developed many educational games and, last but certainly not least, we have been building a community of passionate individuals working towards a common goal.

What are the next steps?

We are convinced that play is the key to learning, since it helps us be receptive to new ideas. Ecoloodi’s approach is to create tangible education experiences in Canada and in France, while developing hands-on water solutions where they  needed. As a starting point, we have 3 simple memory games that are teaching children (and playful adults) some water issues using pictures from Canada, France and South Africa. We have tested the games many times during various events and have received great feedback. It’s time to get them into people’s hands!

We’ve been so lucky to have met Melaine one year ago in Montreal, while she was doing an exchange between Canada and Benin. She is an extraordinary young woman from Benin who wants to make a difference in her country’s sanitation and water supply conditions. She has been organizing Ecoloodi’s first trip to Benin over the last 6 months. We will be in Benin from January 8th to the 29th, 2015, to work with village leaders, schools, orphanages and local organizations.



We need your help to shape the future of Ecoloodi

Because we are growing quickly, we need your support to shape the future of Ecoloodi. First, we need to print and sell our memory games, called “MEMO-LOODI”, and use the profits to organize educational community events and help improve the water situation in Benin, with a focus on local children’s education.

The more games we print, the less expensive they become; and the more of them we sell, the more impact we will have. That’s where we need you! We have partnered with Warren’s Waterless Printing to stay consistent with our mission to preserve water resources and offer high quality printing.

We are organizing our first-ever fundraising event, and we hope you’ll join us!

Here are the details:
Games 4 Water
November 24th, 2014, 6 to 9 pm
Snakes and Lattes, 600 Bloor St. W, Toronto
$10, included with your donation to this campaign ($12 at the door).

It will be a great opportunity to gather with like-minded enthusiastic individuals who are passionate about water issues and education. You will have a chance to hear from experts in the field during our panel discussion, play board games you’ve might never tried before, and participate in a silent auction with amazing prizes.

How funds will be used?

Transparency is one of our most important objectives. We want to develop a trustful relationship with you and we work hard on using the donations directly and solely for our social action. Thus, we rely on your generosity to increase our scope!

Funds from the Indiegogo campaign will be used for MEMO-LOODI games (design, printing, boxes) and supplies we want to offer in Bénin to the schools (games & school kits) and orphanages (diapers & milk for the most vulnerable children, between 0 and 2 years old) we're visiting. We will also use the collected funds to create a montage from the photos and videos we’ll take there. Our long-term objective is to develop a long-term program in Benin to contribute to improving their water situation.

Risk and challenges

We’ve worked very hard to limit risk and challenges. One of our favorite sayings is “step by step”! Along with a lot of passion, love and patience, we’re convinced that’s the key of success. However, the next challenge we’re soon going to face will be in Benin, while working with a new culture. That’s why we decided to focus for now on Benin alone, in order to build strong partnerships.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, My name is Craig Stark and I have started this campaign to fund my dream to become a professional musician. I have spent the past 15 years in public safety working as a Firefighter and a Paramedic, helping the people of my community. A little over a year ago I sustained a career ending injury and have not been able to further myself in public safety, and have been stuck behind a desk, This is not me!

For as long as I can remember I have had a passion for music. I am a novice guitar player and singer and currently play in a cover band as a hobby. My goal is to attend a local music collage to increase my skill and proficiency and to also learn modern production technique to become a professional musician and teacher.

What I Need 

What I need is simple, money! I will spend 100% of all funds on Tuition, Books, and required equipment for me to succeed the program. The cost for the program is $22,000 and that will get me a degree in music and the required equipment.

The Impact

I understand that what I am asking for is a lot of money, but every little bit that I can raise will be much appreciated. Due to the injury and the subsequent financial strain that put on my family I will not be able to qualify for the loans that I need. I work full time and do everything that I can to feed my family. If I can reach my goal and become what I have always wanted to do, I will fill the life of everyone around me with music. I will also teach future generations to do the same! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute money please help me out by using the share tools and spreading the word. This means a lot to me and you will help me with my dream! 

Thank you!

story:
We have no 3-D printers at our campus.

This is a problem for students who are expected to meet the technical demands of tomorrow's scientific applications.
  • Without any means to create prototypes students would be forced to shoulder unimaginable machining costs.
  • Being able to work with 3-D printers would give valuable hands on experience that would benefit everyone involved.  

Why 3-D Printers?

I see 3-D printing as the future, for most fields including the fastest growing fields of nano-medicine and nanotechnology. 


  • 3-D printers can signifigantly decrease prototyping times
  • This is an opportunity to allow students to hone skills that will lead tomorrow's engineers 
  • If our desired goal is not reached the money will still go towards the acquisition of 3-D printing equipment for the campus. 

Who will benefit from 3-D printers at LAMC?

This will benefit the surrounding community of Sylmar greatly. It will open the minds and imaginations of youth and experienced learners alike. 

  • We will attract great minds with unparalleled skills only to use our printers.
  • Our campus will have a decisive edge over other campuses that do not have 3-D printing capabilities 
  • Everything from prosthetic to electronics can be created for fractions of the cost of typical machining costs. 

Please help us, spread our hope

I understand that it's difficult or even impossible for many to contribute. But you're attention so far along with your enthusiasm is fantastic and can be of great help to our campaign. 

  • Even if posting this on your facebook page seems awkward, you can send us a message just wishing us good luck. We appreciate all the time and attentino you have given this campiagn so far. 
  • Thank you thank you thank you a million times thank you for helping us.
