story:
7.8 magnitude scale earthquake that shook Nepal on April 25th has been one of the most destructive natural disaster the country has ever faced.  By now you may have already seen on TV the earthquake has already claimed over 8,600 lives (and counting), destroyed thousands of houses, flattened centuries old world heritage sites, wiped out entire villages, and made millions of people homeless overnight.  Devastation of such scale is a major challenge to any nation, and Nepal being one of the poorest countries in the world makes it even worst.  It is really hard warming to see that already many developed nations have poured help by sending rescue teams, medical supplies, food and millions of dollars.  Yet there are many people, especially in the remote villages, who still need help desperately. 
Over the past few weeks many of my friends from around the world who are very keen to make their generous contribution to help Nepal have been asking me which is the most reliable charity organisation.  Their main concern is making sure every penny of their donation goes to the earthquake victim.  My answer to them is, “I really don’t know – maybe Unicef, Oxfam, Red Cross… ” I am sure there are many charity organisations and individuals who are raising fund in a good faith with full intention to help victims.  And again, I am sure there are people who are planning to get rich by taking undue advantage of this vulnerable situation.  How to set them apart?  Most of the time you cannot and usually it is already too late when truth comes out.

So, to make easier for my friends who do not want to go through big organisations I have decided to collect the fund by myself.  According to my research and reports from earthquake ravaged villages in Nepal there is a dire need for the restoration of educational infrastructure and reestablishment of healthy learning environment.  If educational development is not prioritized then in the long term Nepal would suffer even bigger devastation than this earthquake as it would deprive the growth of whole nation.  After careful consideration I have pledged my support to two different local registered Nepalese organisations in child education sector that have promising long term visions for rebuilding Nepal.

The first on is "EGBOSA", my high school alumni association, which is working hand in hand with regional educational board of Nepal to rebuild a school in one of the villages in Gorkha region where the earthquake was most destructive. The educational board will be constructing the school building and EGBOSA, on an ongoing basis, will be creating environment for the kids to attend school by providing text books and stationeries, school uniforms, school lunch, and lodging and fooding for students during final high school exam at far away centers.

The second one is "Saarathi" that is working on child Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) awareness in Nepal. In our society PTSD is not taken seriously thinking that it will get better over time by itself.  Consequently help and treatment for PTSD are not readily available. Especially after this massive earthquake PTSD cases have skyrocketed and parents do not have any clue on how to handle it. Saarathi, which is initiated by one of my dear friends, works with professional in the field to provide proper resources and education to parents and teachers on how to deal with child PTSD.

You can rest assure that 100 percent of your contribution would be utilized for the rebuilding of Nepal. You can check the progress of these projects at https://www.facebook.com/egbosanepal and https://www.facebook.com/SaarathiNepal

So, if you are interested to help us guide Nepal to the road of development by giving the generous “Gift of Education” then please click the link provided. 

Thank you very much for all your generous contribution, thoughts and prayers.

Sincerely,

Roshen Pun

story:
Nepal continues to struggle in the aftermath of the tragic 7.8 magnitude earthquake. Aftershocks continue to undermine recovery efforts and the death toll is now over 4000, a number that is expected to rise further as search teams reach more remote areas.  The full extent of devastation is yet to be known as many areas in Nepal are still not accessible.

I would like to reach out to my friends and family to help out in any way possible to raise funds for basic necessities such as food, water, medicine, blankets, etc. for those who most need it right now. 

**I expect to gain authorization from Oxfam America by tomorrow, a worldwide organization dedicated to fighting poverty so that they  receive 100% of funds. Indiegogo Life collects no fees.  

Thank you for all your help in advance. Every penny counts.

story:
Short Summary

I completed school in 2012. After 2 non-profit jobs, I am still struggling to get ahead. At this point, in order to get my official transcripts, I must pay for my final semester.

What I Need & What You Get

The $7250.25 is solely to pay UC Berkeley.

For donations over $25, I will send you a CD of my new venture in poetry and ukulele.

    The Impact

    Being able to hand my mother my diploma is really the goal.  I would love to go to grad school, however, I can not if I can not prove I finished. I can actually get a "real" job.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Encouraging words are always welcome!

story:
You can still donate at www.earthcarenm.org to support these young leaders and their projects! Thank you so much to everyone who gave! 

The funds we raised will help keep our garden projects going through the summer ! Get updates on our projects and events on our Facebook page.

Who We Are 


Our world is in trouble. If we want things to change for the better we need all hands on deck.
We need new inspired leadership.  We need to invest in the emerging generation of change-makers. We need to empower young leaders TODAY. 

 Youth Allies recruits, trains, and mentors young people from Native, Hispano, Latino Immigrant, Anglo and other diverse backgrounds to take leadership in the movement for social justice and environmental sustainability. Participants develop leadership and organizing skills while becoming  role models and change-agents. Youth leaders work across cultural lines to develop projects that improve the environment, benefit our community, and educate their peers. They receive ongoing training & mentorship as they work with one another, teacher sponsors, and community partners to create youth-led Community-Change Projects which meet real community needs and have tangible outcomes.

Youth Allies is a program of Earth Care, a non-profit based in Santa Fe, NM which educates and empowers youth to create healthy, just and sustainable communities. Your donation is tax deductible. Visit www.youthalliesnetwork.org or www.earthcarenm.org for more info and Like Youth Allies on Facebook!

“Youth Allies has given me an outlet for my ideas about how the world can be if we all work together, respect one another and consume only what we need. Youth Allies has helped me find a community of young people who care about the world the way I do…Out of all the youth groups I’ve been a part of, YA has been the most effective.” 

                – Marco Campos, Youth Allies Senior Organizer and Advisory Board Member

 

The Impact

Since 2006 hundreds of young people have participated in Youth Allies programming. Every year we impact over 500 local teens. Youth leaders receive over 50 hours of training and complete over 50 hours of service. Youth organizers volunteer over 300 hours on their projects. Youth Allies leaders have helped to pass a New Mexico Carbon Cap law, showcased youth arts for social change, eliminated Styrofoam in Santa Fe Public School cafeterias, fed hundreds of hungry community members, participated in local government, staged youth rallies and marches, and taught hundreds of students about important environmental and social issues and how they can make a difference.

“Through Youth Allies I have discovered my true passion – making a difference in the world and helping other young people put their skills and talents to use to create a healthier community. Youth Allies has given me amazing opportunities to lead and teach others.”         

                – Grace Martinez, Youth Allies Advisory Board Member 

The Stakes

More than ever we need our whole community to support youth development. In this economy traditional foundation funding has been steadily dwindling and is no longer enough to sustain the operation of our program. Our goal for this campaign is to raise at least $10,000 toward meeting our program budget for THIS year. 


The Youth Allies Program COSTS  $85,000 to run annually.

    

Funding for Youth Allies supports:

Trainers and Adult Mentors $35,000

Youth Staff $22,000

Youth Organizers $15,000

Campaign & Project Supplies $4,000

Meeting Space, Equipment, & Office supplies, $9,000


There are so many young people in our community who know that we can and must change the ways that we relate to the human and biotic communities to which we belong.  They are willing to step up and work hard to make a difference if they are just given support, encouragement, and tools for change.

 

 

We empower and train young people to be the kind of leaders our rapidly changing world needs RIGHT NOW. Your tax-deductible donation helps grow people who know how to make the world better and are ready to act on that knowledge.


 “Youth Allies has inspired me to take leadership at home, at school, and in the community. Since I joined Youth Allies I’ve found all kinds of ways to make a difference and make my voice heard.”                                                                        

                – Magaly Campos, Former Youth Allies Organizer


More Ways You Can Help

Beyond donating to our campaign, you can help by spreading the word about our campaign and the important work we do. Please use our widget and share tools!  

THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING OUR FUTURE!

 

More from Our Young Leaders

“Youth Allies has not only helped me to learn about and get active in my community, it has helped give my life new direction and meaning. Through Youth Allies I have been able to do all kinds of things I would’ve never imagined possible at my age. I have spoken in front of rooms full of adults about my vision for a better future; I have written press releases; and registered people to vote. I have also discovered that I am passionate about ecological restoration and equal rights. I joke with my fellow Youth Allies that I wish we could come to Youth Allies every day instead of school because the program teaches us about the things that really matter to us, the kinds of things we really want to know, that will help us do things in the world that we really care about, that will make people proud of our generation.”                                                             

                         –Avree Fe Koffman, Youth Allies Senior Organizer and Advisory Board Member

 

“I believe my calling is to get people involved in their community and to inform as many people as possible about ways we can work better together and make things more equal. Through Youth Allies I am making my dream a reality by educating people and letting them know how much better life can be if we all collaborate with each other and work together to come up with solutions. 

                        –Jose Vasquez, Former Youth Allies Organizer

 

“Youth Allies has helped me connect with kids my age who also care about the world and our future… I have never had so many different friends from so many different backgrounds and I think this is really good for me because we all see the world a little differently, have different experiences, and different ideas about how to improve our community.”                                                                    

                       – Mexica Calderon, Former Youth Allies Organizer
story_txt:
You can still donate at www.earthcarenm.org to support these young leaders and their projects! Thank you so much to everyone who gave! 

The funds we raised will help keep our garden projects going through the summer ! Get updates on our projects and events on our Facebook page.
Who We Are 


Our world is in trouble. If we want things to change for the better we need all hands on deck.
We need new inspired leadership.  We need to invest in the emerging generation of change-makers. We need to empower young leaders TODAY. 

 Youth Allies recruits, trains, and mentors young people from Native, Hispano, Latino Immigrant, Anglo and other diverse backgrounds to take leadership in the movement for social justice and environmental sustainability. Participants develop leadership and organizing skills while becoming  role models and change-agents. Youth leaders work across cultural lines to develop projects that improve the environment, benefit our community, and educate their peers. They receive ongoing training & mentorship as they work with one another, teacher sponsors, and community partners to create youth-led Community-Change Projects which meet real community needs and have tangible outcomes.


Youth Allies is a program of Earth Care, a non-profit based in Santa Fe, NM which educates and empowers youth to create healthy, just and sustainable communities. Your donation is tax deductible. Visit www.youthalliesnetwork.org or www.earthcarenm.org for more info and Like Youth Allies on Facebook!
“Youth Allies has given me an outlet for my ideas about how the world can be if we all work together, respect one another and consume only what we need. Youth Allies has helped me find a community of young people who care about the world the way I do…Out of all the youth groups I’ve been a part of, YA has been the most effective.” 
                – Marco Campos, Youth Allies Senior Organizer and Advisory Board Member
 
The Impact
Since 2006 hundreds of young people have participated in Youth Allies programming. Every year we impact over 500 local teens. Youth leaders receive over 50 hours of training and complete over 50 hours of service. Youth organizers volunteer over 300 hours on their projects. Youth Allies leaders have helped to pass a New Mexico Carbon Cap law, showcased youth arts for social change, eliminated Styrofoam in Santa Fe Public School cafeterias, fed hundreds of hungry community members, participated in local government, staged youth rallies and marches, and taught hundreds of students about important environmental and social issues and how they can make a difference.
“Through Youth Allies I have discovered my true passion – making a difference in the world and helping other young people put their skills and talents to use to create a healthier community. Youth Allies has given me amazing opportunities to lead and teach others.”         
                – Grace Martinez, Youth Allies Advisory Board Member 
The Stakes
More than ever we need our whole community to support youth development. In this economy traditional foundation funding has been steadily dwindling and is no longer enough to sustain the operation of our program. Our goal for this campaign is to raise at least $10,000 toward meeting our program budget for THIS year. 

The Youth Allies Program COSTS  $85,000 to run annually.
    
Funding for Youth Allies supports:
Trainers and Adult Mentors $35,000
Youth Staff $22,000
Youth Organizers $15,000
Campaign & Project Supplies $4,000
Meeting Space, Equipment, & Office supplies, $9,000

There are so many young people in our community who know that we can and must change the ways that we relate to the human and biotic communities to which we belong.  They are willing to step up and work hard to make a difference if they are just given support, encouragement, and tools for change.
 
 
We empower and train young people to be the kind of leaders our rapidly changing world needs RIGHT NOW. Your tax-deductible donation helps grow people who know how to make the world better and are ready to act on that knowledge.

 “Youth Allies has inspired me to take leadership at home, at school, and in the community. Since I joined Youth Allies I’ve found all kinds of ways to make a difference and make my voice heard.”                                                                        
                – Magaly Campos, Former Youth Allies Organizer

More Ways You Can Help
Beyond donating to our campaign, you can help by spreading the word about our campaign and the important work we do. Please use our widget and share tools!  
THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING OUR FUTURE!
 
More from Our Young Leaders
“Youth Allies has not only helped me to learn about and get active in my community, it has helped give my life new direction and meaning. Through Youth Allies I have been able to do all kinds of things I would’ve never imagined possible at my age. I have spoken in front of rooms full of adults about my vision for a better future; I have written press releases; and registered people to vote. I have also discovered that I am passionate about ecological restoration and equal rights. I joke with my fellow Youth Allies that I wish we could come to Youth Allies every day instead of school because the program teaches us about the things that really matter to us, the kinds of things we really want to know, that will help us do things in the world that we really care about, that will make people proud of our generation.”                                                             
                         –Avree Fe Koffman, Youth Allies Senior Organizer and Advisory Board Member
 
“I believe my calling is to get people involved in their community and to inform as many people as possible about ways we can work better together and make things more equal. Through Youth Allies I am making my dream a reality by educating people and letting them know how much better life can be if we all collaborate with each other and work together to come up with solutions. 
                        –Jose Vasquez, Former Youth Allies Organizer
 
“Youth Allies has helped me connect with kids my age who also care about the world and our future… I have never had so many different friends from so many different backgrounds and I think this is really good for me because we all see the world a little differently, have different experiences, and different ideas about how to improve our community.”                                                                    
                       – Mexica Calderon, Former Youth Allies Organizer

story:
Our Story

Our school's after-school dance program has been cut and we're doing our best to raise the funds and make it happen. Manhattan’s Muscota New School (PS 314) has no physical education program for its students due to budget cuts--that's right, no gym class! In 2010 the modern dance company, Fly by Night Dance Theater, did a twelve-week residency at the school teaching movement improvisation to Kindergarten and First Grade. The 2011 program is ready to go. Only catch is, 2011’s government funding for the program was cut by 100%. If we are able to raise the money to cover liability and teaching artists, fifty students will get a chance to move constructively and creatively once a week.

The program is considered vitally important by the parents and students alike, so Fly-by-Night and the school have joined forces to find a way to keep the program alive. The Parents Association and Administration of Muscota are committed to providing improved access to physical education. Because the program is classified as an after-school elective, it is not covered by the school’s general liability-- and this is a BIG expense. 

If we can pay liability and the teaching artists, we can offer the children the residency again this spring. All administrative work (including grant writing and this campaign) is done on a volunteer basis. With your help, the children can continue to dance, draw, and think in ways that aren’t taught through classroom academics.


The Impact

Fly by Night Dance Theater will provide 12 weeks of after school dance classes that are free for the students at Muscota New School. Each age group receives an hour long class once a week. During class, the children learn both body discipline and how to interpret and express the world around them. For example, we can start with something from everyday life -- a New York City Pretzel -- what does it look like? how does it fold over itself? how we can make them with our bodies? Students explore how to twist their bodies like a pretzel, and then work in groups to create their own group pretzels.

As our residency progresses, we begin to comment on what we see, expanding our vocabulary and finding new ways to express ourselves and to create what we see in our world. The children draw each others dances and dance each others drawings. Students work together in small groups to create their own dances which fosters their cooperation skills as they listen to others' ideas and incorporate them into the dance of the day. The 12-week residency culminates in a demonstration for family members and friends. The demonstration allows parents to see the students' progress and skill as well as how dance fosters growth intellectually, artistically and physically.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to continue offering this FREE program, we need to cover the liability insurance costs for an after-school program as well as the teaching artists salaries. Your money will pay off the liability coverage we need in order to offer the program. The teaching artists are highly qualified and experienced. The head teacher has a Masters in Dance & Dance Education from Teachers College, Columbia University and the teaching assistant has a BFA in Dance from Rutgers University. Both teachers have extensive experience working with students of this age. The children who participate in the dance program are also working to pay for the program -- they will be selling re-usable eco shopping bags. Teaching artists are paid for their teaching hours only (lesson planning, administrative hours, and grant writing are done on a volunteer basis). Your financial support goes directly to the project  - not into desk hours or coffee breaks.

We have also been pursuing other sources of funding - corporate contributions from our neighborhood and a foundation grant. If we don't meet our goal from this Indiegogo campaign, we will still be offering the program but it will be shorter with less impact. With your full support we can offer the program for 12 weeks. The school these children attend is in the poorest district of Manhattan. By offering our program after school, we can serve the students who would not otherwise experience a dance program.

story:
Greetings dear Reader, kudos to You for taking the time to read this.

As You already may know, there is a lot of suffering in the world, primarily in the form of:

1.) famine
2.) thirst
3.) disease
4.) poor living conditions

Now I would like You to stop for a minute and really think about it: People are dying from the above mentioned; in huge numbers! And this is all my fault :(

The purpose of this project is to gather enough resources to open a research center dedicated to making the world a better place.

Here are the basic details of the plan:

1.) Establish a base of operations
There is an abandoned research center some 80km/49miles away from my location. I intend to colonize it. If that doesn’t work out, any hangar will do.

2.) Gather all my colleagues friends there
Self-explanatory.

3.) Get to work on projects that benefit mankind.
Using our scientific and technical “knowledge” we would work day and night non-stop 24/7 on creating solutions for the worlds problems.

4.) Distribute the solutions from 3.) to those who are in the greatest need.

So far, I hope You are seeing the potential of this and approve of my plan. Again, kudos to You for taking the time to read this.
Now, prepare Yourself to be blown away; here comes the list of specific projects I intend to do and would have done a long time ago, if only there were enough resources :( They might seem a bit far-fetched to You, but please bear with me.

(I) A more efficient energy source
Everything needs power. If we are to make eg. accelerated plant growth or water “makers”, then we need an energy source that is more efficient, greener and cheaper than oil, uranium or coal.

Proposal 1
Proposal 2

(II) A more efficient mode of transport
Think flying-saucers style here. Using (I) we will make an aerial vehicle capable of transporting supplies to the ones in need.

(III) Water “generating”
Imagine putting a device in the desert that takes the water from the air and converts it into liquid form… Using (I) and (II) that is easily possible.

(IV) Accelerated plant growth
The goal is to accelerate plant growth by at least a 1000% using cutting edge hydro/aero-ponics AND growing huge plants by simulating the conditions in which they grew and flourished (Remember the time of the dinosaurs? Neither do I :P )

(V) Cure for ALL diseases
Based on the works of Hippocrates himself and dr. Beck. The main focus here is on prevention; making it almost impossible for the body to “become” sick. The secondary focus in on curing the “incurable” diseases. Do you believe that eg. AIDS is incurable? Well I don’t and I can’t wait to prove it to You.

(VI) Advanced housing
Based on the works of Jacques Fresco and other pioneers, we can make cheap and efficient housing. These types of houses use less material than regular housing, completely recyclable and can be used in a modular pattern (building cities).

I can’t do this alone, but we can do it together! It is our duty as humans to reduce the suffering of other humans. One will never be happy when he/she knows for a fact that others are not.

Please pledge some $, even $0.01 if You can. If You would like to pitch in, but simply can’t afford it, then please help by spreading the word to Your friends, family, colleagues…

Thank You in advance!
Ante Iličić

story:
Hi my name is Jaqueline Flores. I am a high school graduate, I am originally from Tijuana, Mexico have been living in the United States for almost 13 years.

I have an interest in photography and plan to attend the Kansas City Art Institute. As many of you might already know, art school doesn't come cheap. I received KCAI's highest merit scholarship for my portfolio but unfortunately I still don't have enough money. 

I have partnered with Garcia Squared contemporary, a gallery that is helping me raise money for college. We decided to make an Indeigogo campaign where people can donate from as little as $15 . 

Based on your donation, I will personally send you a special perk, which will include a hand written Thank You note. 

I hope you checkout my IndieGoGo campaign, so you can help fund my journey through college.

If unfortunately you cannot donate make sure to share my link on any media sites so that someone else can donate for you. :D

story:
Campaign Summary

Enthusiastic salutations! My name is Aerie Shore, and I’m a passionate student of marine biology at Santa Barbara City College. My profound love of the aquatic environment and the myriad creatures dwelling within prompted me to return to college to pursue this particular degree. Marine biology is important to me because there exists a dynamic, complex, fragile interdependence between the aquatic and terrestrial realms. In addition to the abundant food resources the ocean provides, 50% of the oxygen we breathe is produced by phytoplankton living within it. This is no exaggeration. The ocean is a deep, vast, mysterious place, filled with many creatures yet to be observed and cataloged by man. To my profound honor and privilege, I’ve been awarded a summer internship at the University of Auckland. The research I’m participating in specifically endeavors to create databases and catalogs of marine organisms that will be useful to students and researchers alike - comprehensive databases that are sadly lacking from the library of human knowledge. This type of research aims to give humankind a greater understanding and appreciation for the abundance of important organisms dwelling in the world ocean. Conditions are rapidly changing in the ocean environment (rising temperatures, increasing acidification, rising sea levels), at a historically unprecedented rate and magnitude. Grim predictions cast an unfavorable light on the evolutionary capacity for creatures of the sea to adapt to these rapid changes. It’s important to achieve an accurate census of the types of organisms currently dwelling in the ocean, for historic record and also to create a comparison baseline.

What I Need & What You Get

I’m launching this campaign with a rather modest goal in mind. I’m endeavoring to raise enough funds to cover my airfare and accommodation costs. Any funds I receive beyond the goal will be applied to living and travel expenses incurred while conducting the internship. The perks I’m offering consist of art and performance inspired by my marine biology education, field research, and an insatiable hunger for weird knowledge of the uncanny creatures populating the watery realm. It would be splendid indeed to gain an understanding of the creatures living in the ocean before they are lost from the living record. Here’s your chance to get involved! Active participation! Science is supremely awesome!

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you tremendously for taking time to read about my campaign. Every donation is enthusiastically, gratefully received. Even if you aren’t in a position to donate, please pass the word along to anyone you know who appreciates the abundant splendors of the ocean. Or anyone who appreciates at least 50% of the oxygen they breathe. I exuberantly encourage you to contact me with any questions, suggestions, or highly creative feedback. Supernova!

story:
Heven Rooks is a 10 year old that wants to help other kids that are in need of school supplies. She has enlisted the help of her friends to collect schools supplies. She would like to help as many people as she can so she needs your help:

Your donation will help purchase pens/pencils, spiral notebooks, crayons/markers/colored pencils, glue sticks, pencil boxes/pouches, loose leaf paper, paper folders, 3 ring binders, scissors, and calculators/graphing calculators.

Thank you for your help!

Your donation will help purchase pens/pencils, spiral notebooks, crayons/markers/colored pencils, glue sticks, pencil boxes/pouches, loose leaf paper, paper folders, 3 ring binders, scissors, and calculators/graphing calculators.
Thank you for your help!

story:
Consider teachers like Krista, who will start her first year of teaching this fall. She’s spending her summer intensively training to be the best teacher ever for students in a school where 99 percent of the students live at or below the poverty line. Books at home are scarce and many parents struggle with reading.

Krista cannot wait to meet her students, but worries that she won’t have access to all the resources required to support their academic and developmental needs.

The reality - kids need new books to go back to school.  But, in some low-income communities, there is one book per 300 children compared to middle-income communities where there are 13 books per child.  And, over the summer, students from low-income families fall behind an average of two months in reading compared to their middle-income peers, making it all the more critical for these kids to start the year with new books.

The good news? Krista and many teachers like her will register with First Book to receive free books for the children in their classrooms - books that teachers can carefully select from the First Book Marketplace, where every award dollar from First Book – South Florida is stretched even further thanks to the national publishing partner relationships. 

First Book - South Florida is an all volunteer Advisory Board of national non-profit First Book, a literacy organization that provides new books to children in need, addressing one of the most important factors affecting literacy - access to books. Since its founding in early 2012, First Book - South Florida has granted nearly 650 brand new books to children in need.  By building relationships with schools and programs like Achievement Centers for Children & Families, First - Book South Florida is expanding its reach and needs your help to serve children who have few or no books in the home.

Join us in welcoming 250 students back to the classroom this fall with 3 brand new books.  Every $2.50 you give represents a new book for a child in need.  That’s 10 books for $25!

But, we have to hurry because many schools are back to school already, and we want to raise $1,875 by October 15th to start a home library for 250 Palm Beach County students with 3 brand, new books of their very own.  No donation amount is too small.  Give $5 for two books, $25 for 10, or $50 to give 20 brand new books to kids in need.

Want to help us in other ways? Spread the word about First Book – South Florida’s Back to School campaign by sharing this link on your social media pages, like Facebook and Twitter.

partner relationships.  
First Book - South Florida is an all volunteer Advisory Board of national non-profit First Book, a literacy organization that provides new books to children in need, addressing one of 
the most important factors affecting literacy - access to books. Since its founding in early 2012, First Book - South Florida has granted nearly 650 brand new books to children in need.  By building relationships with schools and programs like Achievement Centers for Children & Families, First - Book South Florida is expanding its reach and needs your help to serve children who have few or no books in the home.
Join us in welcoming 250 students back to the classroom this
fall with 3 brand new books.  Every $2.50 you give represents a new book for a child in
need.  That’s 10 books for $25!
But, we have to hurry because many schools are back to school
already, and we want to raise $1,875 by October 15th to start a home library for 250 Palm Beach
County students with 3 brand, new books of their very own.  No donation
amount is too small.  Give $5 for two books, $25 for 10, or
$50 to give 20 brand new books to kids in need.
Want to help us in other ways? 
Spread the word about First Book – South Florida’s Back to School
campaign by sharing this link on your social media pages, like Facebook and
Twitter.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sam Gerstein and I have spent years in the health care field helping people with many physical ailments. About 10 years ago I grew frustrated because I suspected something more was going on with these physical illnesses. I began to ask people about their stress levels while treating them. Interestingly, work stress topped the list of stressors in people's lives.

Work stress not only stresses people but it makes many physically sick. Over two thirds of people going to family practice offices have stress related illnesses! I was very motivated to get to the root cause and find ways to help these people decrease all this work stress. I figured if people loved what they were doing at work their work stress would fall and their overall satisfaction and happiness would improve.

 

I studied people in their Dream Careers for over 3 years and learned how they did it. I then created a program to help others do it too. I have been using this program successfully for 6 years in my private practice and now want to make it available to a larger audience. 

 

This program is a passion for me because I switched my career and discovered my Dream Career - It is helping people find theirs! I am absolutely enthused when I help someone overcome self-limiting beliefs and see their own potential. That is what this program does.

You will be doing an incredible service by contributing to this campaign. It can make a huge difference in people's lives. It can give people meaning to their work instead of just putting in time. It can make them happier and healthier. I want to thank you in advance for helping to make this dream a reality.    

 

 

 What We Need & What You Get

We need $50,000 for post-production costs. We estimate that the huge amount of video we shot will require over 130 hours of editing. We will be hiring a professional speaker to add in specific learning points along the way, to help people get the most out of each week.

We need the funds to create a website and market this program. We feel that this is truly a unique program that speaks to many different learning styles and we will need to get the word out so people understand just what we have here.

Here are some perks that you will get when you help us make this dream a reality:

For helping us with this campaign we will be giving specialty Dreams For Real Calendars with inspirational quotes, T-shirts with slogans that are used in the Discovery program itself,

on-screen video program credits

  

Some other perks include complimentary passes to the program and a one year membership in the Dreams For Real membership site. In addition if you represent a group involved in career change, such as students, educators, or people in mid-life crisis, I will deliver a one-day introductory seminar on how to get started in discovering your Dream Career and how to begin dealing with the biggest obstacles in your way.

 

If we don't reach our entire goal we will use whatever funds we have to move this project forward. It may be delayed but I am determined to make it. So many people suffer needlessly in jobs they dislike and tolerate at best. We feel this program will go a long way to helping those people get unstuck and find a career they always wanted but didn't know how what it was.

 

 

The Impact

I have found that so many people are dissatisfied with their work. This has led to high work stress and many illnesses including chronic neck and back pain, headaches, frequent colds, high blood pressure, depression, burnout and many more. It is a silent epidemic that affects over two-thirds of workers worldwide.

You may ask why do people put up with this if it is making them sick. I have found that the number one reason is that most people do not know what they want to do in life! This is because no one has ever guided them in the right way.

People get messages like:

·         Get a good education or get a degree

·

story:
As those of you that know me have come to understand- helping others is what drives me and inspires me.  I really believe that our children ALL over the world are our future!

With this in mind, for spring break this year I have decided to committ my time and energy to helping those in need through the University of Wyoming's Alternative Spring Break program. For one week in March I will glady be spending my break working with children in an education based setting in Costa Rica. 

The Alternative Breaks (AB) Program will provide me a unique opportunity to address local and global issues through direct service and education. 

Furthermore, AB will provide an outlet for me to develop leadership skills and a continued commitment to service, something near and dear to my heart.   

What's Needed:

These trips are made to be as affordable as possible for students. However with the cost of gas and airline tickets the trips tend to be expensive. The total cost of my service project trip is $1650.00. 

By participating in this service project I will:

1. Gain a deeper understanding of issues facing our world

2. Develop meaningful relationships

3. Gain a greater appreciation for diversity

4. Gain a sharpened sense of civic duty

 

By donating to this service project YOU will:

1. Probably get a lot of the money back!

The program is TAX EXEMPT, therefore any contributions can be applied as a tax write off... so there's nothing to lose and LOTS to gain. I'd be happy to talk with you more about this or link you to the SLCE office for more info!  

2. Make a DIFFERENCE.   

All of the money donated will go to a community that needs the help. Can you make any more of a difference than that?

3. Help yourself at the same time.

Studies show that when individuals spend money on charitable organizations or service projects, their happiness increases....Everyone wins!

Other Ways To Make A Donation:

You may feel more comfortable donating directly to the SLCE office at the University of Wyoming.  If so, their address is:

Alternative Spring Break Coordinator
Dept. 3625  1000 E. University Ave.
Laramie, WY 82071

Make sure to attach a note (or write on the check) my name: Lindsay N. Stoffers


Unable to make a financial donation but still want to help?

I'd love for you to MAKE SOME NOISE about this incredible service project! Spread the word to family and friends and link them to this website or feel free to contact me directly at: Lindsaystoffers@gmail.com 

I'm so blessed to be a part of this project and to be in a position, surrounded by the love and support of friends and family, that I can give back to our big beautiful world. 

Thank you for supporting me.

 

With all my love-
Lindsay

 

(The pictures shown were from my time teaching in Kerala, India- 2009)

story:
Short Summary

In order to maximize the quality of the educational experience provided to members of our team, I need to diversify the tournament opportunities available for students. The only way to do that is through traveling to compete in circuits that do things differently than we do here in the Nebraska/Iowa area.

This season, I hope to be able to take the team to tournaments in California, Colorado, Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, and Missouri. Through competition at tournaments in those regions, our students will grow and learn more about communication, debate, and adaptation than I could ever hope to teach them by limiting our travel to tournaments in our comfort zone.

Our $2000 goal is a modest one when compared to what we'll spend, but your support - whether it be $1, $1000, or your help in publicizing our team/fundraiser - is instrumental to our success in competition and education in general. Thank you for checking us out!

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Meeting a minimum of our $2000 will be an enormous shot in the arm for our team, and your help will get us to outstanding tournaments all over the country and incredible national level competition.
  • Donors will receive: honorary status as a supporter published on our team website for any donation; a resilient, gray silicone bracelet debossed with "MILLARD NORTH DEBATE" for a minimum donation of $25; a 2013-2014 Millard North debate team t-shirt in the donor's preferred size for a minimum donation of $100.
  • Whether or not we achieve our entire funding goal, your donations will be put to use in helping expand educational opportunities for some great kids that truly care about learning and growing as students and people. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you still want to help but you can't donate to our fundraiser:

  • Please help us spread the word about this funding drive through Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, the sharing tools on Indiegogo, and/or any other social connection you're able to utilize. Any organization is only as great as the people that support it, and we know we owe you for the fact that Millard North Debate is awesome.

Thank you for supporting our team and education in general.

story:
"In slums, we live by SMS. It is the only way we can use to report news. People living outside do not know some of the lives people live in these areas. As a citizen reporter, I believe I will be an eye witness to the stories as they happen" - Mohamed Camara, Freetown, Sierra Leone.

Your money will directly support Mohamed, and other citizen reporters all over the world, to report injustice and help create a more open and fair society.

Our project: a snapshot 

Radar is international organisation that trains citizen journalists to report from the most isolated and under-represented communities in the world, using basic mobile phones. Our work stretches across Sierra Leone, Kenya, India and the UK.

We work with vulnerable populations who are often excluded from mainstream media, including people with disabilities, rural villagers and slum dwellers, particularly women and girls, and minority groups helping them tackle more sensitive subjects - including corruption, gender violence and slavery. We need to protect them further and help them share their stories to an even wider audience.

To do this, we have teamed up with a small group of web developers to design what is essentially a new mobile app. This will allow our reporters to send us information for the price of a local text without needing internet access. It means we will get more news from them and even faster.

We have built a prototype and now need to raise £11,500 to take this onto the next stage. This will be match-funded by a donor, giving us the full £23,000 needed to trial and launch by the end of this year.

Our project: the long version

The problem 

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights protects the right of every individual or community to speak and be heard. Yet those who are most vulnerable in our world are also the least likely to have the tools needed to record or report their experiences. With two thirds of the world still not online and 1.7 billion people living off-grid, digital connectivity is still the privilege of an elite few. Access to communication tools is largely determined by gender, class and location. When large percentages of populations cannot communicate, democracy is diluted and development is stunted. Corruption and abuse go unreported, successes and innovation go unnoticed and opinions remain undocumented.

Radar aims to challenge stereotypes in the media, open up the flow of critical news and give more people a chance to engage in meaningful dialogue. We champion the voices of the people being heard.

The solution

Mobile is the most accessible tool for communication worldwide. More than three quarters of the world’s people have access to mobile phones. It is cheap, available and can be used by people with low levels of literacy or disabilities.

When accompanied by training and support, mobile offers a powerful opportunity to bridge the digital gap and source news from different areas.

Radar works with community groups and local organisations to deliver training workshops that offer core journalistic skills, geared towards mobile reporting. Trainees learn the basic principles of sourcing and verifying information, and producing balanced, impartial news. Each reporter is then connected to Radar’s central news hub via mobile. The hub can verify reports, offer editorial support, and then share their news online and with leading media outlets. We link reporters with editors and journalists who can offer mentoring and collaborate with them to produce high quality media from their communities .

Within our first year, Radar has covered two African elections and supported more than 250 citizen mobile reporters to share more than 2,000 mobile reports across social media sites. Their work has been published by leading media outlets including the Guardian, the New Internationalist and the Ecologist with others contributing to the BBC World Service and international television features. The media they produced has been seen by over a million people. We regularly pitch reporters' stories and win them paid commissions and work as fixers.

Many of the stories uncovered by our reporters have been picked up by major institutions including the EU election observation teams, advocacy organisations and policy networks. Most of the communities we work with live off grid, in slums or rural areas. Over half are women or girls, and over a third have a physical or sensory disability.

Who are we? 

Radar was founded by Alice Klein and Libby Powell, freelance journalists with extensive experience of running projects in hostile environments and producing media for the international press.

In its first year, Radar won the Guardian Tech Talent competition and was shortlisted for the Nominet Trust NT100 longlist of 100 Top Social Innovations with Digital Technology. The organisation and its founders were recently named in journalism.co.uk's Top 50 Female Innovators in Digital Journalism.

How can I help?

100% of the money you donate will go towards the development of a new digital platform that will connect our reporters to Radar's central news hub as swiftly and securely as possible. It will allow us to work with a greater number of reporters simultaneously. Most importantly, their data won't be owned by an external group - which could potentially remove the software and cut off our lifeline to our reporters, or access the information they are transmitting and compromise their security.

We need a total of £23,000 to finish the development, test it and launch it by the end of the year. But we are lucky! A previous donor has offered to match whatever amount we raise, so we only need to reach £11,500 here on Indiegogo – they will give us the other £11,500. This is an incredible opportunity and we hope our supporters can help us reach our goal, so that we can take advantage of our donor's generous offer and complete the project.

Even if you can't donate money, you can still like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and keep spreading the word about Radar and our crowdfunding campaign.

Thank you!

story:
What is Skeptech? 

We're a collective of science geeks, history nerds, and tech-obsessed activists. We're students and soon-to-be students. We're award-winners, idealists, pragmatists, skeptics, and, more than anything, obsessed with the world of tomorrow. We run a free conference called Skeptech, held the first weekend each April.

Skeptech explores the intersections between science, critical thinking, and innovation in addressing some of the most pressing societal and environmental problems humanity faces today. It's an accessible space for students, bloggers, activists, scientists, engineers, and other geeks to network, see some pretty awesome talks, and meet some pretty cool people. Skeptech is fundamentally a balance between a desire to inspire people and offering them practical information with which to act upon that inspiration. Held at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, this three-day conference aims to spark ideas, foster questions, and start conversations on the role of technology in improving, and ensuring there is, a tomorrow. 

So we're like TED, but with attitude. 

The Details

Website: skep-tech.com

Date: April 4-6th, 2014

Location: University of Minnesota campus, Minneapolis, MN

Our History

The first Skeptech was awesome and we couldn't have done it without our community's support. Here are some numbers:

  • 202 registered attendees (many were unregistered) 
  • 15 speakers 
  • 6 panel discussions
  • 1 kick-ass blood drive
  • $0 attendance fee for everyone
  • 1,000,000,000+ salacious postures (ok, that *might* be a stretch) 

And exactly one piece of badass swag:

(image is of the 2013 Campus Affiliate Group Award for Best Educational Event from the Center for Inquiry)

Help us build off a great year and make this conference even better! We can do it (we have before) and all we need is your help. 

What Your Money Buys

Thanks to the support of Campus Atheists, Skeptics, and Humanists, we've been able to secure a fantastic lineup of speakers, including internationally-known secular activists and science educators. Our schedule is fantastic and we'll be releasing speaker names shortly. Unfortunately, what we have doesn't cover everything. Between the cost of improvements and rented space, we're going to need some help. 

This is what we'll spend that money on:

  • speaker honorariums 
  • facility rental
  • conference supplies (schedules, name tags, flyers, etc.) 
  • improved A/V equipment so we can turn this:


into this:


In order for this conference to be free and accessible, every penny needs to come from a donor (whether an academic institution or individual). You can have a direct impact on keeping Skeptech free and open to everyone. 

There are perks to giving, too. This is but a small selection of the cornucopia of goodies that await you under Select a Perk:

  • We'll follow you on twitter!
  • Pet rocks
  • Want to get hitched? We think you're devilishly charming and would totally e-marry you.
  • An overly-dramatic doodle of you riding a dinosaur of your choice. Over a mutherfuckin' volcano. With multiple rainbows. 
  • A Skeptech coffee lackey to make Starbucks/Caribou runs during the conference. 
  • A custom cupcake and our musical organizer, Xandra, will perform a little jingle about how you are the most awesome person of awesome. Because you're awesome, duh.   
  • Our beardly organizer, Brendan, will dye his beard a color of your choosing!
  • Donate $1000 or more and you can request a speaker for next year. We'll work with you to find a set of candidates who match our goals and you fangirl/boy over. Everybody wins!

Important Note: Some of these gifts are too expensive or delicate for us to ship. Those gifts will be available at the conference. If a shipping address is required, we are able to ship your gift to you. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

No money? No problem! Spread the word through twitter, facebook, or your preferred social outlet. We're always looking for volunteers at or before the event, too! Contact us at skeptechcon@gmail.com if you want to help. We can use all sorts of types and talents--don't be shy! Skeptech is a grassroots conference and we're all volunteers.
story_txt:
What is Skeptech? We're a collective of science geeks, history nerds, and tech-obsessed activists. We're students and soon-to-be students. We're award-winners, idealists, pragmatists, skeptics, and, more than anything, obsessed with the world of tomorrow. We run a free conference called Skeptech, held the first weekend each April.Skeptech explores the intersections between science, critical thinking, and innovation in addressing some of the most pressing societal and environmental problems humanity faces today. It's an accessible space for students, bloggers, activists, scientists, engineers, and other geeks to network, see some pretty awesome talks, and meet some pretty cool people. Skeptech is fundamentally a balance between a desire to inspire people and offering them practical information with which to act upon that inspiration. Held at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, this three-day conference aims to spark ideas, foster questions, and start conversations on the role of technology in improving, and ensuring there is, a tomorrow. So we're like TED, but with attitude. The DetailsWebsite: skep-tech.comDate: April 4-6th, 2014Location: University of Minnesota campus, Minneapolis, MNOur HistoryThe first Skeptech was awesome and we couldn't have done it without our community's support. Here are some numbers:

202 registered attendees (many were unregistered) 


15 speakers 


6 panel discussions


1 kick-ass blood drive


$0 attendance fee for everyone


1,000,000,000+ salacious postures (ok, that *might* be a stretch) 

And exactly one piece of badass swag:(image is of the 2013 Campus Affiliate Group Award for Best Educational Event from the Center for Inquiry)Help us build off a great year and make this conference even better! We can do it (we have before) and all we need is your help. What Your Money BuysThanks to the support of Campus Atheists, Skeptics, and Humanists, we've been able to secure a fantastic lineup of speakers, including internationally-known secular activists and science educators. Our schedule is fantastic and we'll be releasing speaker names shortly. Unfortunately, what we have doesn't cover everything. Between the cost of improvements and rented space, we're going to need some help. This is what we'll spend that money on:
speaker honorariums 
facility rental
conference supplies (schedules, name tags, flyers, etc.) 

improved A/V equipment so we can turn this:

into this:In order for this conference to be free and accessible, every penny needs to come from a donor (whether an academic institution or individual). You can have a direct impact on keeping Skeptech free and open to everyone. There are perks to giving, too. This is but a small selection of the cornucopia of goodies that await you under Select a Perk:
We'll follow you on twitter!
Pet rocks
Want to get hitched? We think you're devilishly charming and would totally e-marry you.

An overly-dramatic doodle of you riding a dinosaur of your choice. Over a mutherfuckin' volcano. With multiple rainbows. 


A Skeptech coffee lackey to make Starbucks/Caribou runs during the conference. 

A custom cupcake and our musical organizer, Xandra, will perform a little jingle about how you are the most awesome person of awesome. Because you're awesome, duh.   
Our beardly organizer, Brendan, will dye his beard a color of your choosing!
Donate $1000 or more and you can request a speaker for next year. We'll work with you to find a set of candidates who match our goals and you fangirl/boy over. Everybody wins!
Important Note: Some of these gifts are too expensive or delicate for us to ship. Those gifts will be available at the conference. If a shipping address is required, we are able to ship your gift to you. Other Ways You Can Help No money? No problem! Spread the word through twitter, facebook, or your preferred social outlet. We're always looking for volunteers at or before the event, too! Contact us at skeptechcon@gmail.com if you want to help. We can use all sorts of types and talents--don't be shy! Skeptech is a grassroots conference and we're all volunteers.

story:
Thank you so much to all of our supporters for getting us to 100% funded in just 8 days! We're really humbled at how the local developer community has stepped up to help us make Columbus' Open Device Lab the best it can be—let's see how much more we can do! Help us push on and add even more devices to our lab so we can make it an even more awesome resource for the Columbus design and developer community!

What do you want to see in Columbus Open Device Lab next? A Microsoft Surface? A four-inch iOS device? More obscure, older Android 2.0 phones? Maybe you're itching to develop for the new Amazon Fire TV; You tell us what you would find most useful and as the funding grows, we'll add them to the list!

Thanks again so much for your incredible support—let's keep this thing going and make Columbus' Open Device Lab the test lab that Columbus designers and developers deserve!

You know the current HTML5 specification proposal by heart. Every one of your websites validate W3C clean on the first try. And you dream in perfect CSS3—compiled from LESS, of course. You pride yourself on your semantically perfect web sites, designed to be responsive and beautiful on any device. But then you get a call from the client: Something isn't right in Opera Mini on their 2006 Blackberry Curve. What now?
When it comes to testing your responsive web sites and native mobile apps, desktop browsers and emulators can only take you so far. The Salt Mines Device Lab is a collection of Internet connected devices—mobile phones, tablets, video game consoles, and other hardware peripherals—that is made available to the central Ohio design and developer community for testing and development purposes, absolutely free. We launched in late 2012 with a three devices and, with the help of local developers and manufacturers, quickly grew to a collection of more than two dozen devices. It was the first device lab of its kind in Ohio, and it remains the largest Open Device Lab in the state.

A year later, however, we're noticing that technology has advanced at a pace that our lab hasn't kept up with; Our first-generation iPad is looking pretty old, we have no modern Android tablet, and the only Samsung product in the collection is a four-year-old Samsung Galaxy S. Local designers and developers have been enthusiastic about the availability of this resource, but more frequently we're finding that the collection is lacking a few key devices.

Specifically, with a successful funding, we are planning to add the following devices:

  • Apple iPad 3—Funded!
  • Samsung Galaxy S4—Funded!
  • HTC One—Funded!
  • Google Nexus 4—Donated!
  • Google Nexus 5—Funded!
  • Google Nexus 7—Funded!
  • What's next? You tell us what we should add!

Just like the rest of our existing lab, these devices will be made available for the local design and developer community absolutely free of charge for on-site testing and development purposes. With successful funding, we will also build a replacement display and storage stand for these and any future devices. This device lab has been an incredible resource for local designers and developers and we hope you will help us bring it up to speed so it can become even more valuable for our community. 

This initial funding goal is just the beginning, though—we're already working on some awesome ideas for stretch goals should we exceed our target; We don't want to get too specific with it just yet, but let's just say that we're excited for you to see what we have in mind.

Supporter Perks: Great Swag

Our device lab is hosted in The Salt Mines coworking space, and we've partnered with Outfit Good to offer some great Salt Mines swag for our supporters. Backers of the SUPPORTER levels will receive a Salt Mines laptop sticker, and contributors at the T-SHIRT SUPPORTER level will get a Salt Mines t-shirt.

We're also excited to offer our custom designed responsive Salt Mines Device Lab pint glass! Never be unsure exactly how much to pour again with our clearly delineated shot, shot@2x, and drink markers. 

        


We've also added an upgrade to our existing COWORKING SUPPORTER level, the COWORKING+ SUPPORTER. Get a month of The Salt Mines' Part-Time coworking membership for free with your $50 contribution. This is a huge savings of the normal monthly rate, so if you're interested in giving coworking a serious try, this is a great way to do it.

Sponsor Perks: Show your support

Of course, we're still offering our higher SPONSOR level perks. Every backer at the STAND SPONSOR level and above will have their name, or company name, engraved right into our device lab stand, and backers at the PREMIER SPONSOR level can have a 2" x 4" logo engraved prominently into the device lab stand. This is a great way to show the Columbus design and developer community that your organization cares about promoting testing on real devices.

We think testing web sites and native apps on real, physical devices is the only way to make sure our work is the best it can be, and The Salt Mines Device Lab is the best way for central Ohio designers and developers to do that testing across the widest range of devices possible. We hope you'll help us ensure that this invaluable resource stays up-to-date so we can help central Ohio designers and developers for years to come.

story:
Who is driving this project?

The building of Sulangan School is spearheaded and led by the efforts of Philippine surfers & their international friends, namely the surfing community of Siargao Island who were first to respond and aid Samar by raising funds, purchasing relief supplies and delivering them personally by boat soon after the typhoon devastation. You can find them on Facebook under Siargao Helps Samar & Siargao Inn Friends Helping Samar 

Balikbayod Returning Wave & Surf for Life are headed to Guiuan, Samar in February to aid in the rebuild of Sulangan School. Balikbayod Returning Wave will be starting an after-school surfing program to bring surfing to the kids. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We hope to raise $1000 to help finish the school's build and purchase any needed building materials and pay for carpenters
  • If we don't reach our goal, the funds will still be donated towards the building of Sulangan School or any other items the school needs such as desks, tables, chairs
  • You will get a thank you keepsake for making a donation

The Impact

You contribution will help Yolanda typhoon survivors attend the June 2014 school year when classes commence.

  • Many towns were destroyed in the path of the typhoon, help keep the momentum of aid on the ground by funding the people and projects who are directly working to help the effected communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Share this link with friends and family through your email or social networking tools like Facebook, Twitter, etc. 

Thank you for your support! Some of you have already donated to this specific cause and we hope you will continue to see the value of your donation money put to work.
