story:
Who We Are

Our mission is to stimulate children's imagination, curiosity, and love of learning.

  • Our goal is for all visitors to learn amazing things about themselves and the world in which we live through informal, playful, hands-on and child-directed experiences.
  • We serve any child and their adult company, ages 1-10.
  • Currently, 24% of our admissions are given at free or reduced cost. We want to work toward providing 50% of all admissions at free or reduced cost.

We need your help.  Ask yourself: don't all children deserve to play and learn? 

What We Need & What You Get

By supporting The Children's Museum, you will help us make the following happen:

  • $2,500 will provide for 20 Anytime Memberships for 20 deserving families.
  • You will get a special gift if you donate, from the children we serve!
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will provide as many Anytime Memberships as we can with the funds raised.

9 Daily Programs, Free with Admission

We offer 9 programs during the week that are free with the cost of admission, and focus on the variety of age groups we serve:

  • Little Sprouts Storytime Mondays at 10:00am
    • Little Sprouts is for our preschoolers. Each week we'll read a new story and do an activity inspired by the book.
  • Go Green Engineer Team Mondays at 3:30pm
    • Activities are hands-on challenges that focus on the engineering design process. Using simple materials with multiple solutions, is ideal for ages 5-9.
  • Kids Cooking Club: Going Global Tuesdays at 3:30pm
    • Learn new skills and explore fun seasonal recipes. Then savor the flavor of your hard work. Kids Cooking Club is sponsored by Harris Teeter.
  • Preschool Science Wednesdays at 10:00am
    • Hands-on activities geared towards little ones and encourages them to explore the world around them.
  • Discover Science Wednesdays at 3:30pm
    • This program encourages children to explore and learn about the scientific process while developing critical thinking skills.
  • Mini Math Wednesdays at 4:00pm
    • This program uses easy games and fun activities to practice simple math concepts that help make children comfortable with mathematics and familiarize them with concepts they are just starting to learn.
  • StoryCOOKS Thursdays at 10:00am
    • Cooking club for our preschoolers. Each week we'll read a new story and create a dish inspired by the book. StoryCOOKS is sponsored by Harris Teeter.
  • stART with a Story Thursdays at 3:30pm
    • Start with a story and then add ART! It’s the perfect way to connect literacy with the arts. Join us each week to create a masterpiece that reinforces a fun book.
  • Toddler Time Fridays at 10:00am
    • Projects and activities for our youngest visitors (ages 4 and under) and their special grownups to work on  together.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute today, you can still help:

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn accounts.
  • Visit www.playwilmington.org and share the site with your friends.
  • Call us at 910-254-3534 and volunteer your time.
  • Have something you don't need?  We might need it - give us a call to find out.

Your support will help children whose parents cannot afford to visit the Museum.  

What better way to use your holiday dollars than that?

Contribute and allow all children the right to play and learn.  Today.

Contributors

Elizabeth and William Cosper

Sharon White

William Atwill

Atlanta Carrera

story:
To my beloved family, beautiful friends, partners in crime, and fellow dream seekers . .

My whole adult life up to this point has been one big adventure. I've gone where the wind has taken me from various locations and experiences within this country and others. My gypsy ways have earned me the moniker "unicorn" because you basically never knew where you will see me or when. I've realized that in order to keep helping my amazing community keep build the festivals and dreams that I've been apart of for so many years that I need to evolve myself. Being a gypsy unicorn is a largely solitary life and while I give so much during the Summer months I realized that I'm wasting my potential the rest of the year. So it seemed time for a new adventure . .

I began thinking of ways that I can give back and be of service. Not just to my community at large but on a global scale. 

My friend Josh told me about NOLS/WMI years ago, maybe 3 years to be exact. I've rolled the information around in my head for this long because I wanted to make sure that this was the right choice and now I believe it is. The plan has been slowly unfolding in my head. Getting my EMT certification is the first step with a degree in nursing as the final frontier. So not only will I be the heavy machinery operator on site I will also be the one that can patch you up when your day might go south due to an angry skill saw. After my entire education is complete I'd like to take my skills world wide, helping where help is needed in countries that don't have the resources we do. Especially where it concerns medical care.

About NOLS/WMI

"This intensive course combines wilderness medicine with urban medical care practices into a single month-long program that includes clinical rotations helping to provide care for real patients. After four weeks of classroom education, practical skills, scenarios and full-scale mock rescues, you will be ready to handle medical emergencies, in the wilderness or right in town." (taken from the NOLS website: http://www.nols.edu/wmi/courses/wemt.shtml)



What I need

I've taken care of the tuition costs with the help of a generous scholarship from NOLS. 

Now comes the fun part, getting there.

Clinical Uniform: $200

analog watch, waterproof(all fluids) boots, white collard shirts, stain resistant pants

Gas: $400

With the rising gas costs it seems that getting anywhere these days is a small fortune. I've calculated the roundtrip miles including a little extra from commuting to town and back in this estimate.

Life Expenses: $500

Just because I'm in Wyoming on an adventure doesn't mean the rest of the world stops turning. This is an estimate of my expenses while I'm away since I won't be able to work while I'm in school. Rent, Cell phone, insurance

Car Maintenance: $300

My chariot in all things, Ishtar, needs a little work before the big trip. She's taken me many places but she's old and a little TLC would do her good. Also breaking down in Nevada would be a bummer.


If funding exceeds my expenses then the remainder of the balance will be donated to the NOLS/WMI scholarship fund


What You Get

Beside the knowledge of my helping  the injured . . .

There's PERKS!

With the help of my friends, generous contributors, and my love for the beauty of Humboldt County I've come up with some incentives to thank you for your generous donations.

Other Ways To Helps

Donations of any amount is greatly appreciated. I also know that there are so many of us artist types out there that are living simply and might not have the extra funding for a donation. What would be a tremendous help is sharing this fundraiser anyway you can. Email lists, Social media, word of mouth. Every little bit helps. Indiegogo makes sharing simple.

Questions? Concerns? Want to know more about me? About NOLS/WMI? Want to say hi?

Don't hesitate to email me: palinor.rising@gmail.com

Paypal: palinor.rising@gmail.com

Thank you all so much for even taking the time to read this. I am extremely blessed to have such a loving community. I look forward to being able to give back.

Love,

Shannon (Palinor) Velasco 

(your future mouth to mouth administrator) 


“Tell me, what is it you plan to do 
with your one wild and precious life?” 
― Mary Oliver
story_txt: To my beloved family, beautiful friends, partners in crime, and fellow dream seekers . .My whole adult life up to this point has been one big adventure. I've gone where the wind has taken me from various locations and experiences within this country and others. My gypsy ways have earned me the moniker "unicorn" because you basically never knew where you will see me or when. I've realized that in order to keep helping my amazing community keep build the festivals and dreams that I've been apart of for so many years that I need to evolve myself. Being a gypsy unicorn is a largely solitary life and while I give so much during the Summer months I realized that I'm wasting my potential the rest of the year. So it seemed time for a new adventure . .I began thinking of ways that I can give back and be of service. Not just to my community at large but on a global scale. My friend Josh told me about NOLS/WMI years ago, maybe 3 years to be exact. I've rolled the information around in my head for this long because I wanted to make sure that this was the right choice and now I believe it is. The plan has been slowly unfolding in my head. story:
Short Summary

I have been accepted to an ECELA program that takes college students from around the country to South America for 6 weeks to learn spanish while volunteering their time at local charity hospitals. These hospitals give free care to those who cannot afford hospital fees and therefore would otherwise not receive the care they need.This is a great opportunity, as I could begin to earn meeical volunteer hours, which I will need to apply to medical school in the future, but I will also benefit greatly from the immersion in a new culture.

What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, this program is a little pricy. Let me break it down:

  • Tuition alone is $2,500
  • My room and board costs nearly another $1,000
  • There are various other fees, totaling $500
  • This puts my expected cost at around $4,000.
Every little bit helps, and I would greatly appreciate all your help. I cannot offer much, but I can assure you that I will make a total fool of myself or give other small tokens of my gratitude. The following are just some of what you could get, simply for helping me reach my goal
  • A Silly doodle
  • Personalized video
  • Pictures from Peru
  • Email updates of my adventures
  • VIDEO diary of my adventures
  • Many others

The Impact

Contributing can have the following effects:

  • I will gain a deeper understanding of a new culture
  • I will be able to help those that desperately need help
  • I will gain applicable knowledge, so that I may help many more people in the future

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that money is tight these days. If you cannot donate, please help get the word out by:
  • Sharing this page with friends, family, and co-workers
  • Checking back frequently
Thank you for all of your help.

story:
PRI®: Connecting people to their world for over 30 years.

Public Radio International (www.pri.org) is a non-profit media organization that engages people though powerful stories, connects people and cultures around the globe, and seeks to affect positive change.  For the past 30 years, we at PRI have prided ourselves in being dynamic and innovative, and in creating unique content.

Our mission is to serve audiences as a distinctive content source for information, insights and cultural experiences essential to living in our diverse, interconnected world. PRI offers the largest portfolio of programs in public radio. Our programs are heard on almost 900 radio stations across the U.S. and on digital platforms that reach millions around the globe.

April 15th is our 30th anniversary, and we’re celebrating by enhancing our unique international coverage by building our Global Reporting Fund, which will ensure that PRI continues to connect people to important global voices and tell vital international stories.

 

PRI's Global Reporting Fund

Media coverage about issues of special concern to women - such as gender-based violence and women's economic participation - make up less than 1.5% of news worldwide. At PRI, these stories make up least 5% of our coverage.

Immigration is rarely addressed apart from public policy and political rhetoric. At PRI, we highlight the voices of first-and second-generation immigrants who tell their stories of making a life in the U.S.

More people die from cancer in low and middle-income countries than from TB, HIV, AIDS, and malaria combined. At PRI, our Global Health and Development coverage highlights disease and healthcare in other countries.

We tell these stories through our daily global news program, “PRI’s The World®”. Launched in 1996, "PRI's The World" (www.theworld.org), the first public media program explicitly designed to bring global news to U.S. audiences. PRI’s The World recognizes that global stories are not “foreign” and separate from our experience as Americans, but rather a piece of the story which is common to us all. By embracing contributions from its fans around the world to enhance its coverage, and by proving on-going context to understand broader global themes, The World inspires us to respond to global events as we would to those in our immediate neighborhood.

 

Global News: Important stories need to be told.

  • At PRI, we believe that news plays a singularly crucial role in shaping the way that Americans view and interact with the world.
  • Coverage of major global issues has never been more vital. In our increasingly networked and globalized society, what happens in far-flung communities in places like Brazil, China Dubai and Zimbabwe is connected to, and matters for what happens where you live.
  • Journalism in the U.S. has drastically decreased its coverage of international news in the past 10 years. News networks have reduced their foreign bureaus by at least 50% in recent years. Media has been reshaped by consolidated ownership, the drive to increase profits, and reduced opportunities for in-depth coverage. Consequently, the news is less able than ever, to deliver the diverse voices and global perspectives you need to negotiate an interdependent world. (Read the Pew Research Center's Annual Report on American Journalism)
  • Americans know less about global news than they did 30 years ago. At the same time, we eagerly consume information about celebrity exploits and the latest dramatic scandal and domestic criminal trials. Why? Filling broadcast and digital space with reports on “Brangelina”, Lindsey Lohan and Jodi Arias, is much cheaper than reporting on Syria’s civil war, or reproductive health issues in Sub-Saharan
    Africa. (PRI's President and CEO Alisa Miller spoke at TED about this phenomenon.)

 

PRI's Global Reporting Fund: PRI tells these stories.

PRI's Global Reporting Fund (GRF) will support reporting and international coverage that reaches beyond the headlines. The support that we receive from this campaign will help people connect to global issues, and understand their connection to international news. The GRF will:

  • Support the production of in-depth reporting by providing critical resources for journalists in the field.
  • Fund the placement of award-winning journalists in critical locations, to cover important stories, worldwide.
  • Enable the editing, promotion, and distribution of PRI’s content via radio, podcast and multiple digital platforms.

The Global Reporting Fund will help us tell stories related to the following topics (click to see stories that PRI and "The World" have already reported on these topics):

  • Global Health
  • Human Rights
  • Immigrants and Refugees
  • Religion
  • Science and Technology
  • Women and Girls
  • Regional Interests: Africa, Asia, Latin America, China, and the Middle East
  • Arts and Culture

 

What We Need & What You Get

To launch PRI's Global Reporting Fund, and ensure that PRI can continue to provide high quality and in-depth, international news coverage, we need your help to raise $25,000. With this amount, PRI will be able to:

Produce and publish 11 of “The World’s” international news stories for broadcast and digital distribution. These stories will reach 2.4 million people by broadcast alone.

You can do the math. That’s $2,400 per story. Expensive? Well, yes, because the kind of high quality and insightful reporting “The World” does involves impeccable  editorial, digital and broadcast staff, plus computers, microphones, digital media staff, studio space, phones, travel, light bulbs . . . you get the idea. Remember, celebrity gossip is cheap to cover, quality international news is not.

Your support of the GRF will be rewarded with exclusive and limited edition perks for our Indiegogo supporters, which reflect and celebrate PRI’s unique perspective and voices.

 

What story will you make possible?

PRI takes very seriously its public service responsibility of bringing objective and important information to the attention of people who are concerned about their world. We’ve done so for 30 years.

With your support of the Global Reporting Fund, PRI will continue to produce probing coverage that informs you and helps you become an engaged citizen.

Help PRI shift the media landscape in the U.S. and anticipate and adapt to our changing world. Whether covering global health rights or arts and culture, PRI tells the stories that are important and meaningful to you. You can help make sure they will be told.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

To learn more about PRI visit our website.

Listen to "PRI's The World" and the excellent international stories we tell by visiting www.theworld.org.

Follow the progress of PRI's Global Reporting Fund's Indiegogo campaign on Facebook and Twitter, and spread the word to you friends! 

With you investment, PRI can continue to tell the important stories that need to be told.

story:
What is SUPOCHO?

SUPOCHO (Support the Poor Charity Organization) was started in 2010 and is a non-profit located in Nkhata Bay, Malawi. SUPOCHO began from a vision by a local Malawian, Webster Nyirenda.  He saw the need to help orphans and vulnerable young people become computer literate.

The average Malawian earns only $178 dollars per year.  In a country where the vast majority of the population has no computer skills, SUPOCHO is empowering 13-22 year olds orphans and other vulnurable young people with the ability to differentiate themselves and secure employment.  By gaining employment and becoming economially self-reliant, these young people will have a much better chance at improving their quality of life. 

SUPOCHO has classes on basic computing skills, typing, Microsoft Office Suite, and lessons on using the internet. We also provide free access to computers and the Internet for the local community.  

We Need Your Help!

The school at SUPOCHO was openend in January 2013.  Great progress has been made, but to ensure the success of the program we need your help.  In Malawi, a little bit of money goes a long way.  The funds go directly to the operating expenses and towards more equipment for SUPOCHO. 

  • A $15 dollar donation (or the price of a meal and a drink) covers all operating costs for a day
  • A $25 dollar donation covers power or internet for an entire month
  • A $40 dollar donation covers building rent for a whole month
  • A $75 dollar donation ensures SUPOCHO can keep one of their two teachers staffed for another month.

If we meet our fundraising goal, SUPOCHO will be able to continue teaching vulnurable young people for another 6 months. 
If we surpass our fundraising goal, the money will go into a fund to build our own building.  Currently, SUPOCHO is operating at capacity.  With a new building and more equipment we can impact more and more vulnurable youth in the community. 

No Cash?  No Problem! 

Please spread the word! Like us on Facebook

We are still in desperate need of equipment.  Any old laptops, computers, or any other equipment you may not be using would be greatly appreciated! Please send any extra equipment to:

SUPOCHO

Attention:  Webster Nyirenda

P.O. Box 111, Nkhata Bay, Malawi

Visit our website for more information
 
SUPOCHO is always looking for volunteers! Nkhata Bay is a beautiful place to stay, and any and all skills are needed to continue growing SUPOCHO.  Short and long term opportunites are available.

story:
S.T.A.R.S School for Autism needs your help! 

S.T.A.R. School for Autism is a non-profit school with a commitment to provide a tailored learning experience for children with autism. Through our program, our students will be prepared to excel in their continued education and will have a solid foundation for a smoother social life. S.T.A.R.S. opened its doors on August 22, 2012 as one of the few schools in the State of Florida to incorporate holistic methods as part of the school’s curriculum and is the first school in Miami-Dade to offer early intervention catered to preschool children living with autism. 

Our programs are currently targeted for early intervention for children 2-5 years of age. Our students are provided with individualized learning plans that incorporate a a specialized curriculum and therapies throughout the school day. The curriculum and therapies we implement include a variety of scientifically based and innovative methods that foster positive development and are customized to meet the unique wellness needs and goals of each parent and child. All our teachers are certified by the state of Florida and they teach our students using a relevant and adapted curriculum, which is based in developmental sciences. Therapeutic services at S.T.A.R.S. include natural therapies, nutrition, floor-time therapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy. 

In total, we are a team of four Hispanic women trying to make a change in the way children with autism are educated in our community. We have each had loved ones or have been personally involved with and seen that the current system in place is not conducive to the manner in which these children would be able to thrive. We all share a collective dream to enhance the current system to be able to give these children and their parents a much-needed full-service holistic environment. We also want families to have an alternative to the current system, without the astronomical cost of what a program and facility like ours goes for in the South Florida area.

It is one of our top priorities to keep costs low enough that low-income families will have the chance to provide their children with the educational and therapeutic environment that they need. We enacted this because we want parents of school-aged children to have the option of bringing their child here knowing that their child will receive personalized services and education as an alternative to the default of admitting them into a public school, where luck of the draw indicates what quality of service and care their child will receive. 

Our school runs on primarily private donations and grants. Grants we were expecting to receive months ago have been delayed and private donations have slowed to come in. We continue to maintain the level of excellence that we set out to employ and are stretching our resources in all areas not related to education and therapy, to continue to maintain that level of excellence. However, as funds have slowed to come in, our growth and plans to do more have come to a stand still.

Our little STARS are growing, learning, and progressing each and everyday with the programs and resources that we currently provide. But there is so much more we have planned and can do... but we need help. In order to move into our next phase of development for our students, we need support from the community. 

Our goal with this campaign is to raise $50,000 to help us open an additional classroom and continue build other learning areas that are underdeveloped. We are a non-profit and we are doing everything we can to keep costs low enough so that families don't need to struggle to provide for their children. The highest tuition price for our school is $1,200 dollars per month per student.  More than half of the tuition expense goes toward each child's therapies and the rest is used to cover faculty & staff, and typical facility expenses. Though our tuition charge might seem a bit steep, it is nothing in comparison to the handful of other facilities that provide similar services in the South Florida region that charge approximately $3,000 dollars per month.

Remember - our students are receiving therapy throughout the school day. That means that mom and dad don't need to run around town and constantly shift their schedules to take their child to school and various therapy sessions around town, they don't need to fight with insurance companies to ensure they get coverage for an autism diagnosis, they don't need to worry about the inconsistencies with the personnel that are treating and providing care for their child, they don't need to worry about sudden and unexpected out of pocket expenses, and they are given reasonable payment options and opportunities for aid. 

All the money raised in this campaign will go toward taking our school and programs to the next level so that these children and future students will get more than the minimum in care and education. These are some of our plans: 

- Open two more classrooms and expand our program for older children living with autism in the community to get the care and education they deserve.

- Provide a greater variety of therapeutic programs during school hours, but also before and after school, such as; a reading dog program, HIPPO therapy, aquatic therapy, therapeutic athletic programs. We also would like to enhance some of our current therapies; like provide instruments to our children during music, provide a greater range of levels in our art programs, and more.

- Set up an in-house nutrition program to ease the need for families to prepare lunches and ensure that our students are getting proper nutrition during school hours.

- Purchase SMART Board interactive whiteboards for our classrooms to porvide our student with interactive group lessons. 

- Enhance our multisensory room to include interactive components for sensory therapy and continuous aromatherapy. 

- Enhance our indoor-gym to include more interactive sensory components, install blinds on the windows, incorporate greater safety features (i.e. padding on the walls), paint the walls to be more stimulating through the eyes.

- Begin building our outdoor-gym that will feature an enhanced playground that is fully interactive and integrates multisensory stim, a water boards and other textural stim, and socially engaging activities.   

- Begin growing our therapeutic garden. We want to utilize a garden area for two reasons 1. To build the association of food, from plant-to-plate, while encouraging wholesome nutrition and 2. To provide our students with a tranquil and therapeutic outside environment.

- Provide better and more in-depth workshops and facilitate support groups and adult events for parents. 

- Provide transportation as an option to families that struggle with getting their children to school.

- Take our children on more field trips; which are more costly than the typical fieldtrip because we need to have closer chaperone to student ratio.

- Set up a scholarship fund for current and future students whose families have financial difficulties.

We at S.T.A.R.S. don’t want to only take; we want to give in any way that we can, especially to those who help support our students. We can offer promotion for you or your organization through our social media, our newsletter to a mailing list of about 1,500 from mainly the South Florida community, and at our events. We can also offer our time should your organization need some volunteers for a few hours on a given day. The packages on the right are just some ideas we had. If you would like for S.T.A.R.S. to do something further for you – let us know and maybe we can make it happen!

Sometimes donating money isn't an option and we understand that. Even if you can't support us through this financial campaign, if you believe in our dream and want to make it your own, there are lots of other ways to help! We can definitely take donations of goods or services. So if there is anything you have that you would be willing to offer; like school supplies, toys, IT services, technology, facility equipment, food and drink for special occasions, or anything else you could think of. We can also use gift donations that maybe wouldn’t be used in the school necessarily – we hold fundraising efforts like auctions and raffles, so we could always use prizes for these to help us raise funds. However, probably the best way anyone could help us is to spread the word that we are here! Share our campaign through social networks, face-to-face, etc. Tell people that have children with autism that S.T.A.R.S. is here to help children like theirs learn and grow in a holistic environment. Moral support is always needed too, so send us a message or give us a call to let us know that you support our school and its essential undertaking!

In just six months our students have made huge strides. One student that had a delay in speech is now saying words! Another student that would not interact with other children is now hugging his friends goodbye! Many of our parents tell us how proud and relieved they are to see their children growing in independence and sociability. We also hear our parents telling us about how their children go home and teach them the lessons of the day! In just a short time our parents and we have seen our children grow so much… and it’s only the beginning! We want to make our program more impactful and expand to be able to give the same opportunity of growth to other families in our community who are frustrated with the inefficiency and lack of quality care within the current alternatives for education of children with autism. By donating you are giving these children and their families the ability to utilize resources that they would normally not have such easy access to. Help us help them!

For more information about S.T.A.R.S. School for Autism visit our website at www.starsautism.org.
story_txt:
S.T.A.R.S School for Autism needs your help! 
S.T.A.R. School for Autism is a non-profit school with a commitment to provide a tailored learning experience for children with autism. Through our program, our students will be prepared to excel in their continued education and will have a solid foundation for a smoother social life. S.T.A.R.S. opened its doors on August 22, 2012 as one of the few schools in the State of Florida to incorporate holistic methods as part of the school’s curriculum and is the first school in Miami-Dade to offer early intervention catered to preschool children living with autism. 
Our programs are currently targeted for early intervention for children 2-5 years of age. Our students are provided with individualized learning plans that incorporate a a specialized curriculum and therapies throughout the school day. The curriculum and therapies we implement include a variety of scientifically based and innovative methods that foster positive development and are customized to meet the unique wellness needs and goals of each parent and child. All our teachers are certified by the state of Florida and they teach our students using a relevant and adapted curriculum, which is based in developmental sciences. Therapeutic services at S.T.A.R.S. include natural therapies, nutrition, floor-time therapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy. 
In total, we are a team of four Hispanic women trying to make a change in the way children with autism are educated in our community. We have each had loved ones or have been personally involved with and seen that the current system in place is not conducive to the manner in which these children would be able to thrive. We all share a collective dream to enhance the current system to be able to give these children and their parents a much-needed full-service holistic environment. We also want families to have an alternative to the current system, without the astronomical cost of what a program and facility like ours goes for in the South Florida area.
It is one of our top priorities to keep costs low enough that low-income families will have the chance to provide their children with the educational and therapeutic environment that they need. We enacted this because we want parents of school-aged children to have the option of bringing their child here knowing that their child will receive personalized services and education as an alternative to the default of admitting them into a public school, where luck of the draw indicates what quality of service and care their child will receive. 
Our school runs on primarily private donations and grants. Grants we were expecting to receive months ago have been delayed and private donations have slowed to come in. We continue to maintain the level of excellence that we set out to employ and are stretching our resources in all areas not related to education and therapy, to continue to maintain that level of excellence. However, as funds have slowed to come in, our growth and plans to do more have come to a stand still.
Our little STARS are growing, learning, and progressing each and everyday with the programs and resources that we currently provide. But there is so much more we have planned and can do... but we need help. In order to move into our next phase of development for our students, we need support from the community. 
Our goal with this campaign is to raise $50,000 to help us open an additional classroom and continue build other learning areas that are underdeveloped. We are a non-profit and we are doing everything we can to keep costs low enough so that families don't need to struggle to provide for their children. The highest tuition price for our school is $1,200 dollars per month per student.  More than half of the tuition expense goes toward each child's therapies and the rest is used to cover faculty & staff, and typical facility expenses. Though our tuition charge might seem a bit steep, it is nothing in comparison to the handful of other facilities that provide similar services in the South Florida region that charge approximately $3,000 dollars per month.
Remember - our students are receiving therapy throughout the school day. That means that mom and dad don't need to run around town and constantly shift their schedules to take their child to school and various therapy sessions around town, they don't need to fight with insurance companies to ensure they get coverage for an autism diagnosis, they don't need to worry about the inconsistencies with the personnel that are treating and providing care for their child, they don't need to worry about sudden and unexpected out of pocket expenses, and they are given reasonable payment options and opportunities for aid. 
All the money raised in this campaign will go toward taking our school and programs to the next level so that these children and future students will get more than the minimum in care and education. These are some of our plans: 
- Open two more classrooms and expand our program for older children living with autism in the community to get the care and education they deserve.
- Provide a greater variety of therapeutic programs during school hours, but also before and after school, such as; a reading dog program, HIPPO therapy, aquatic therapy, therapeutic athletic programs. We also would like to enhance some of our current therapies; like provide instruments to our children during music, provide a greater range of levels in our art programs, and more.
- Set up an in-house nutrition program to ease the need for families to prepare lunches and ensure that our students are getting proper nutrition during school hours.
- Purchase SMART Board interactive whiteboards for our classrooms to porvide our student with interactive group lessons. 
- Enhance our multisensory room to include interactive components for sensory therapy and continuous aromatherapy. 
- Enhance our indoor-gym to include more interactive sensory components, install blinds on the windows, incorporate greater safety features (i.e. padding on the walls), paint the walls to be more stimulating through the eyes.
- Begin building our outdoor-gym that will feature an enhanced playground that is fully interactive and integrates multisensory stim, a water boards and other textural stim, and socially engaging activities.   
- Begin growing our therapeutic garden. We want to utilize a garden area for two reasons 1. To build the association of food, from plant-to-plate, while encouraging wholesome nutrition and 2. To provide our students with a tranquil and therapeutic outside environment.
- Provide better and more in-depth workshops and facilitate support groups and adult events for parents. 
- Provide transportation as an option to families that struggle with getting their children to school.
- Take our children on more field trips; which are more costly than the typical fieldtrip because we need to have closer chaperone to student ratio.
- Set up a scholarship fund for current and future students whose families have financial difficulties.
We at S.T.A.R.S. don’t want to only take; we want to give in any way that we can, especially to those who help support our students. We can offer promotion for you or your organization through our social media, our newsletter to a mailing list of about 1,500 from mainly the South Florida community, and at our events. We can also offer our time should your organization need some volunteers for a few hours on a given day. The packages on the right are just some ideas we had. If you would like for S.T.A.R.S. to do something further for you – let us know and maybe we can make it happen!
Sometimes donating money isn't an option and we understand that. Even if you can't support us through this financial campaign, if you believe in our dream and want to make it your own, there are lots of other ways to help! We can definitely take donations of goods or services. So if there is anything you have that you would be willing to offer; like school supplies, toys, IT services, technology, facility equipment, food and drink for special occasions, or anything else you could think of. We can also use gift donations that maybe wouldn’t be used in the school necessarily – we hold fundraising efforts like auctions and raffles, so we could always use prizes for these to help us raise funds. However, probably the best way anyone could help us is to spread the word that we are here! Share our campaign through social networks, face-to-face, etc. Tell people that have children with autism that S.T.A.R.S. is here to help children like theirs learn and grow in a holistic environment. Moral support is always needed too, so send us a message or give us a call to let us know that you support our school and its essential undertaking!
In just six months our students have made huge strides. One student that had a delay in speech is now saying words! Another student that would not interact with other children is now hugging his friends goodbye! Many of our parents tell us how proud and relieved they are to see their children growing in independence and sociability. We also hear our parents telling us about how their children go home and teach them the lessons of the day! In just a short time our parents and we have seen our children grow so much… and it’s only the beginning! We want to make our program more impactful and expand to be able to give the same opportunity of growth to other families in our community who are frustrated with the inefficiency and lack of quality care within the current alternatives for education of children with autism. By donating you are giving these children and their families the ability to utilize resources that they would normally not have such easy access to. Help us help them!
For more information about S.T.A.R.S. School for Autism visit our website at www.starsautism.org.

story:
We reached our funding goal on Wednesday, September 11th, a full 8 days before the end of the campaign! The response has been amazing, lets keep it up for the final week! To help do that, we've got a stretch goal to offer you, read on...

What are stretch goals?

Stretch goals expand the campaign to help it continue to get traction. The nice thing about a stretch goal is that if we meet this goal, you will get the reward, even if you already donated! But we need to make it to that goal for that to happen.

So... with that in mind, we are excited to announce this crazy stretch goal to continue raising funds for Riseup.net! 

Getting funded on the anniversary of the Pinochet coup is a bittersweet victory. So to help offset the bitter, we've teamed up with allies in Chile, who are part of the political photo collective Our War, to be able to offer to everyone who gives $50 or more a choice of one of 20 different 11x14 color matte prints! 

But only if we can make the stretch goal of $12,500! So, help us get there!

Note:

If you donate $50 or more, please add your address, if you are comfortable with disclosing it, and we'll contact you about picking the photos. If you already donated $50 or more and havent added your address, please do!

Hey! Just so you know, shipping outside of the US digs really deep into your donation, so if you can add $14 more to cover the shipping, we'd love you all the more.

About Our War

Founded 7 years ago, and rooted in the Chilean student movement, Our War is a political photo collective from Chile, created to show to the universe stories about repression, resistance and struggle. 

Thank you for all your support! 


Riseup.net has been obsessed with providing secure and surveillance-free services since 1999. It is a nonprofit, volunteer-run email and mailing list provider that needs your help.

Historically, Riseup has provided services to a relatively small amount of environmental, human rights, and social justice activists worldwide, but since this summer's revelations about the NSA's massive spying programs, Riseup has been flooded with a whole new generation of users. 

This is excellent! But it's struggling to keep up with the demand. The small group of hackers needs more hands and more hardware. It needs cash to buy new servers and disks, and funding to hire someone to meet the growing demands. 

[Riseup just posted a passionate reminder of what it stands for and why we need services we can trust.]

What is Riseup.net?

Riseup.net is a different kind of email provider. It believes: "There is no such thing as free email. Services like gmail, hotmail, and yahoo make their money from surveillance: they build a profile on your behavior and your desires, and then bombard you with advertising specifically targeted to you."

So, instead of mining your data, Riseup.net exists to serve you, the user. Unlike big email providers (cough, Google) Riseup does not:

  • Log your IP addresses
  • Sell your data to third-party marketers you've never heard of, or
  • Hand over your data to the NSA.

Riseup provides email service with a unique level of security and privacy. Unlike almost all other email providers, logs and email headers contain no personally identifiable information. Additionally, all mail is stored on encrypted partitions and transmitted over encrypted connections whenever possible.

Additionally, Riseup is the largest non-profit mailing list hosting service, with nearly 6 million subscribers to over 14k lists; a VPN service'; and has one of the most heavily used hosted collaborative etherpad service. They also contribute heavily to a number of different Free Software projects. They fund all this by being run largely by volunteers, and relying heavily on donations.

Great. Riseup is awesome.  But why are you telling me this?

Right here and now, having Riseup.net existing and growing is more important than ever. Here's an example why.

In response to the leaks about the NSA's blanket surveillance programs, a bunch of organizations — Access, Demand Progress, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Fight for the Future, Free Press, Mozilla and others — launched the StopWatching.Us campaign. We called for Congress to hold the NSA accountable and to reform the laws that made such widespread spying possible. Within a few weeks, more than 560,000 activists and hundreds of organizations and companies had signed on.

We used a Riseup mailing list we knew we could trust to keep our data secure while we organized grassroots opposition to government and corporate surveillance. If we had not, every piece of our organizing and communication would have been tracked, stored, and likely examined by the very powers that we are organizing against. We were so lucky to have Riseup's tools and expertise to help us.

But Riseup is a small shop. It's run mostly by volunteers using donated hardware and open source software. After the NSA's recent shutdowns of other email services, it has been overwhelmed by people wanting an alternative, and by coalitions like us that want to use its mailing list service instead of Google Groups.

People using alternative technology and services is great. But the not-so-great part is that Riseup's servers have struggled to keep up with the new users and traffic, so there's been more downtime. And when things get really busy — like they did recently — server hiccups can results in hundreds of emails being delayed for hours. Riseup needs new software and a troubleshooting hacker to keep this from happening.

We need independent, privacy-loving and STABLE technology

Given the StopWatching.Us coalition is doing to restore privacy protections in the U.S., we simply can't afford these outages and hiccups. But we love Riseup, the people behind it, and the model of an independent email and mailing list provider.

What can we do?

The solution is easy: Riseup needs more hardware and labor. With just a little bit of cash, they can buy a new server, a few hard drives, and pay someone to help run it all and troubleshoot problems as they occur. We need to make sure that important mailing lists like ours stay up when they're most needed.

The breakdown

Specifically, Riseup needs a low power Quad server with 16gb RAM and six SSDs:
  • Case: SC113MTQ-330B — $273.50
  • Mainboard: X10SLM-F — $167.50 
  • CPU: 1265LV3 4 core (8 thread) 9MB cache 45W — $311.50
  • RAM: DDR3-1660 ECC/Reg, 2x 8gb — $143
  • Heatsink: SNK-P0046P — $19.25
  • SATA controller: Supermicro AOC-SAS2LP-MV8 — $107.50
  • Disk: 6x Samsung 840 EVO 250gb SSDs — $1281 (one spare) 
  • 2x Samsung 840 EVO 750gb SSDs — $530 → $1060
  • Miscellaneous cabling and shipping — $150
  • Total parts: $3,513.25
In addition, it needs resources to pay a dedicated human to help maintain the systems and troubleshoot issues. Estimated cost to get a contractor started: $7,000

Total need: $10,500

And, of course, if more money is raised for Riseup, they will buy and host more servers and become even more stable and great.

If you don't have a credit card, but would still like to help, there are many other ways you can help Riseup. Just pick your preferred method, be it Bitcoin, PayPal, dwolla, or wepay. More possibilities are available on the donate page.
