story:
If you've ever been to Uganda or other countries in Africa, you'll know what a welcome you receive from the children that live there! Their zest for life is so great and their enthusiasm for activities second to none.

Channelling this vibrancy and passion into learning how to be better citizens of Uganda, this project will help young people of Uganda to discover how they can become powerful change agents for themselves and their communities.

What We Do

Everything about what we do is geared towards positive-thinking, empowerment, capability, talent-development. Skills developed include:

  • Exploration and development of community-based initiatives for alleviating poverty;
  • How to each other help themselves;
  • The importance of equal opportunity;
  • How we can connect what we each have to give;
  • Vision and leadership skills for a better tomorrow.

Where Your Donation WIll Go

Previously housed through a small centre based in Kampala, Uganda, The Chrysalis Centre presently has 40 - 50 members and last year worked with over 200 students. This facility will only be available to us until December this year.

Your support will afford the build of the The Chrysalis Campus – a new facility enabling us to not only continue our work, but to more than quadruple the number of those we can support within the next year. To learn more about what the campus will look like, check out the drawing below.

Help Young People of Africa Help Themselves

Each adeptly named after a species of butterfly, SPREAD YOUR WINGS by supporting a perk! (For details on each perk, scroll down.)  

If you support the project, where does your money go?

Money buys so much more in Uganda and, where in the UK, you would spend millions of pounds on such a project, in Uganda we can build out whole campus for just £150,000 ($240,000) and we can start our first phase with just £32,000 ($50,000), which will help us acquire the land, the headquarters and training buildings, residential accommodation and activity provision, which will enable us to provide the means to train young people to create change.  If you cannot contribute money, then see below for other ways that you can contribute.

Tell me about the plan - why the focus on green issues?

A professional architect company has provided us with the plans and visuals and we will be building to this specification, with an aim to deliver a completely self-sufficient site, which collects its own water from rain and electricity through solar panels.  We intend to make the water jars, favoured by Water Aid, a part of the learning process for rural children that visit the Centre, so we can underpin what is regarded as good practice around the world.  Our gutters will enable us to collect rainwater - it rains a lot in Kampala) that will refill these.  We plan also to include training in solar energy as part of our training course strategy, which will in time enable children to develop a career in this area and rural children to be able to assess how solar power can make an impact in their village.

So, what are our credentials?

The Butterfly Project is a project designed by Social Enterprise Africa CIC, a UK-based community interest company that encourages the development of social enterprise in Africa and Ashoka Fellow, Emmanuel Nehemiah.  In Uganda, the project is run by Chrysalis Limited, an organisation set up specifically to deliver the project in Uganda.  The team contains a wealth of experience - Grace Ayaa, founder of Life in Africa, which were one of the first organisations to support the Northern Ugandan people during and post the war, Dr Solomon Nkesiga, Principal at Kampala Evangelical School of Theology for many years and practising social entrepreneur, James Wire, founder of Barefoot Power, which delivers solar power solutions but also an ethical entrepreneur and changemaker, Peter Ndelo, Manager at the Butterfly Project Kireka, but also an expert in international crafts sales, Alex Obeki, our Youth Activities Manager, but also the Kampala coordinator for HIV/AIDS prevention activities, Ahmed Ahaad, a national taekwondo coach and head of our sports provision and Bruno Ruganzu, TEDx award-winner and founder of Eco Arts Uganda, who works with us on our art provision.  I was CEO for five years at Jericho CIC, a UK organisation set up to empower long-term unemployed people into work before I started up Social Enterprise Africa.

Who are your end users?

Primarily in the Butterfly Project we train young social entrepreneurs - these are young people from the most disadvantaged backgrounds that are interested in making a difference to the lives of others in Uganda.  We help them achieve their aims through training and giving them a range of experience that children in Uganda usually can only dream of - you can see the kinds of things we do below.  We support children 12-15 who live in remote rural villages and also urban slum areas.

Secondly, because we strategically locate our project in a slum district of Kampala, then we have a catchment of many thousands of families.  This means that we can serve the most disadvantaged children in thse slum districts and we do this by encouraging the  Butterfly Project members to run activity projects with these local children.

Tell me more about the Butterfly Project

The Butterfly Project was launched in Uganda in 2009 after a small pilot in rural Nigeria.  In practice, it is a methodology for creating a momentum for change in communities, by training up young people interested in serving their communities to be a catalyst for change.  We find young people (aged 12-15) from remote villages, interview them and then offer them a chance to be part of our Butterfly Programme, which supports their education, but also trains them how to develop their vision, how to manage a project and how to be a leader.  In return we expect them to deliver their own social project in a community, based around what they are good at.  For instance, if they are a good artist, then they can run an art project, if they show aptitude in computers, then they run a computing project.

Let me give you an example of Francis Ssuuna, now one of our oldest members at 17, but was found, aged 14 in a remote village in Western Uganda.  Francis had developed a level of self confidence at his village school, because he was always near the top of the class, but his parents were subsistence farmers, with very little land.  Teachers at his school were very poor, so we agreed to upgrade his schooling and have him join the Butterfly Project.  In 2010, when he moved to our slum located centre in Kireka to join a secondary school, Francis decided to start an athletics project, which he called Project Circulate.  This project involved many local children from age 7 and upwards, involved them in athletic events, mainly running, and also taught them how to look after themselves.  The project grew dramatically and this year, Francis decided to run some special events for the Olympic Games in London, but back in the slum area where he was now living.  He called it the Slum Olympics and it was to include a special 10,000m run for his members, which we called "The Slum Run".  This project raised enough money to support 17 children into school and even develop an Emergency Fund for children living in the slum area.  We hope that the Slum Run will become an annual event, each time growing and bringing in more and more children.

Francis has already been recognised for his selfless work in the Razor National Newspaper:

So, every member of the Butterfly Project, has a social project like this that they are working on, whether it is in the village where they live or in the slum district, where the centre is being located.

You say you have a centre already, so why build a new one?

Our current Centre is quite small and is rented.  At the end of this year the owner will be moving into the site himself.  Through our experience of working on the Butterfly Project, we believe we have discovered a unique way of developing Africa from the inside out, through empowering its capable and inspiring youth.  Our new campus will give us a chance to upscale the work that we are doing and expand our reach into many more rural areas.  The campus will quadruple our current capacity for Butterfly Project trainees but also allow us to train many thousands of other young people at the new training centre facilities.  Also, the project can become sustainable, by starting to include school and ethical business facilities, which would allow us to build further campuses in the future.

These are the different elements we will be including in our campus:

So, why is this needed?

In the world we live, we expect people to help themselves - "not a hand out, but a hand up" is often quoted.  Sometimes we hear others saying that "they grew up in a bad environment, that's why he turned out as he did".  Well, this is exactly the problem - village and slum environments are bad places to grow up.  What is bad about them?

1. Children's rights are frequently abused.  This means children are beaten and abused for no reason, sold, neglected, subjugated, forced to do hard labour.  There is no one around to take their side, so they put up with it.   

2. They live in a lawless environment.  Any crime that can be committed is committed, especially in rural areas, where policing does not exist.  Children sit and watch these things happen and believe that there is no alternative.

3. There is almost nothing around to stimulate their development to be good citizens.  In villages, children work in the fields routinely - there are few books, computers - and in the slum district, these types of activities exist, but the children have no access to them, due to poverty.  Even sport is rare.

4. Poverty means no knowledge of entrepreneurship.  Most children grow up with some knowledge of business, if they have been educated, but the businesses are not creative and they are often performed unethically.

Children living in villages tend to grow up in an information-less void.  Their slum-based counterparts grow up under the pressure of food poverty, which means that money is not available for anything else and starvation permeates daily life.

We believe that none of this is necessary and that the Campus can provide what is missing from the lives of these young people, enabling them to economically empower either themselves and their families or the village where they live, as they become part of the Butterfly Project, developing and implementing a vision for their community.

Every child attending the Chrysalis Campus will be taught their rights, what is right and wrong, given interesting activities to stimulate their development and given training in how to be an ethical entrepreneur.

Give me some more detail on where the money will go?

The building of a project like this needs a great deal of effort and support and we are looking at every means to find the money to make this project happen.  We know we need at least $50,000 to acquire land and complete phase one of the building.  Here's the plan of the whole campus:

 

For $50,000, we can build the following elements of this plan:

 Kitchen, Office A, 1 x training and Activity Room, Dormitory 1 & 2 (Boys and Girls), Male and Female Adult Room, Sports Space, Perimeter Wall and Latrines.

For a further $65,000, we can build the Chrysalis School for Young Social Entrepreneurs, which includes the Multimedia Library, Computer Room, Storage and Agricultural areas.

For a further $55,000, we can build the remainder of the Campus.  This includes two extra Dormitories, the International Accommodation for visitors, the additional office, the Art and Music Rooms and connecting corridors.

A more detailed budget of the individual buildings can be found here.

This is permanent provision for ever, so what we build we be there providing services to children living in the nearby slum and in remote rural areas into the foreseeable future.

What sort of things will you be doing at the Campus, even at the minimum level?

Most of the activities that are run at the Centre are designed and implemented by members of the Butterfly Project.  They are taught to provide a service to the local community.  In the photographs below you can see the Acholi Quarter News, a youth-written newspaper, which presents the issues faced by the children living in the  Acholi Quarter, Kampala.  Their next issue is being fundraised for here.  The second photo is of Project Circulate already described above.  Here they are racing at the Mandela Stadium.  In the bottom left photograph, you see a campaign that was run to raise the issue of poor food for children in schools, which was presented through art.  Lastly, the fourth photograph is a project to empower local girls through dance.  This is especially important as the girls are able to get away from imposed household chores for a time and start to develop their confidence and talents.

In the training centre, we have been offering a range of specialist training.  In the first photograph is Patrick, who, as a Maths teacher, developed himself a Maths curriculum, which was more applied to real life, as we found that children seemed unable to use their knowledge of Maths practically.  The second photograph is of the Ethics Class, where we discuss children's rights, jealousy, punishment, family values and many other issues.  Thirdly is the team who learnt how to produce liquid soap.  Winifred in the middle went on to develop her own business to support slum children, which she recently presented at TEDx Makerere Hill.  Lastly, we train on specific agricultural techniques and discuss how they can be used to economically empower a rural area.  Practical training in the field is crucial.

As an example of how we work, the pictures below represent the values and life skills we instil into the young people.  "Initiative" - when the kids volunteered to paint the Chrysalis Centre - was rewarded by a chocolate treasure hunt.  We also reward caring actions, creativity and empathy for others.

Lastly, "stimulus" and "experience" are very important, as development tools for children and this is a key area, where disadvantaged children out.  Food is a key issue in the slums, so by introducing them to a broader range of food, they can develop self confidence and also develop their aspirations for a better life.  In the second photo, the group were taken to the National Theatre and were exposed to the creative art that was there.  Children living in dusty and dirty areas enjoy the freedom of swimming and so this was a good reward for their performing well.  Lastly, travel is a very good means of broadening experience and this is the group of Butterfly members at the Source of the Nile.

About The Perks!

By supporting this campaign, you will be joining in a unique and long-term movement to create a better Africa.  If you want to be part of this, you will join us observing the talented young people, as they grow in their ability to create change and you may even be able to advise them personally how best they can achieve the greatest social impact.

If you are interested in art, maybe you could help Joel, who is using art to tell the stories of children living in rural villages and urban slums.  Read about him here. 

Confidence is a big issue for girls in Africa, as they grow up in impoverished settings.  Maybe you could help Nancy achieve her aims and objectives, as she states them here.

Eunice is a composer and choreographer or some talent, which she uses to train small children.  Her project was recently featured on the front cover of Update Magazine. 

Gilbert is an immensely talented creative designer, in art, dance, fashion design, who wants to use these talents to transform the lives of children in his community.  You can see his latest blog here.

If you know about business, then you could support Manisuli with his tree planting project or Samuel as he devises a new card game.

If you have always been interested in education, then maybe you could help Charles in his quest to support education development in rural Africa. Listen to what he has to say here.

Mercy has recently been appointed an HIV/AIDS ambassador by the New Vision in Kampala, even though she is just 13 and you could be the one that help guides her in becoming a public speaker that impacts on millions.  You can see her in the video at the top of our appeal.

If you've read this far, then you've also read about Francis, who devised the Slum Olympics and Slum Run, which raised almost $1,500 for some of the most disadvantaged children in Kampala.  If you're an athlete, you could be the one to help him turn this small idea into a worldwide concept.

You can see some photos of the members and their projects here.

We have 20 members in total, though numbers are gradually expanding.  With your help too, we would like to have 50 young social entrepreneur trainees by the end of 2013.

Most of our rewards engage with these young social entrepreneurs and the work they do and you will likely be surprised by their commitment to what they do and their positive aspirations for the future. 

He is some more information about the rewards that we are planning:

CABBAGE WHITE - Look in the mirror and see the pride at what you have helped to build - there's your reward!

PEACOCK - We made a whole bunch of beautiful pictures last year of butterflies for a calendar and here's your chance to get your own copy of one.

If you are interested in this option, then you can view the butterflies available at this link.

BRIMSTONE - for this option we will give you a link on Google Docs to the file, with 40 full colour Top Trumps-style cards.  If you would like to have a hard copy of the cards, then we will print and despatch them to you, at the $15/($20 outside UK) additional cost, as stated.  You can see an example card below.  If you have a school or would like to encourage your own children to become social entrepreneurs and changemakers or simply want to learn a bit more about the members of the Butterfly Project, then this pack of cards is for you. 

Sample card (not actual size)

Reverse of card

(Note that scores on the cards are for fun and don't reflect the differing abilities of the members.)

BIRDWING - In the main training room, we plan that every brick will have an inspirational message (and your name, if you wish) built into it and we are opening this up to you to choose that message, that you personally feel is important for young people as they grow up.  When it's built, then we'll photograph every wall, so you can scan to find your individual message.

PAINTED LADY - A Facebook caricature of you will be painted, scanned and emailed to you.  An example of the work will shortly be displayed below.  As soon as you donate, then send an email to ben@socialenterpriseafrica.org with the photograph that you would like us to use. We will respond as soon as we can and send it back, so you can feature it in your own profile to encourage others to take part.  This first 100 is at an early bird price, so to take advantage, donate now!

SWALLOWTAIL - You will be able to choose either a bracelet or necklace, made primarily from the Acholi Paper beads and to a colour scheme of your choice.  Part of the money you donate will go to the local slum-based artisan that produced the work for you.

CAMBERWELL BEAUTY - You can take this reward multiple times, if you would like to talk with different members of the Butterfly Project on Skype. In time, this channel will link you to our internation network of youth social entrepreneurs, hosted by the The Citizens Media. This is a rare opportunity to meet young people in the world who have experienced life in an entirely different way to you or I.  Expect some surprising responses. Every member of the Butterfly Project speaks good English and is very used to talking over Skype.

TORTOISESHELL - We are learning to be film makers at the Chrysalis Campus and soon you will be able to commission us to make films about a variety of subjects and we will be entertaining you with the films we make, some of which have perhaps never before been made into a film.  This will be our first "official" film and we will be proud to have you on our list of credits at the end.  If we raise enough money, we'll even play this film in the newly-built outdoor cinema.  We'll upload the film onto Google Docs, when it is complete and give you the link.

ORANGE TIP - We thought that some of you might be interested in commissioning an original painting.  We work not just with Kids, but also some of Uganda's most well known international artists.  The kids love painting the butterflies, so you should choose which butterfly that you would like them to paint for you and then we will scan and send you their painting for review ahead of sending it to you.  If you choose to have a professional paint for you, then we will pay them for their time on the picture, hence the increased price.

Choose your butterfly from this website. Here is the quality that the professionals can produce, if you ask them to paint for you:

MONARCH - We want to capture the moment the Chrysalis Campus is built and record it for posterity.  This Campus represents the skills and abilities of a new generation of young Africans, who refuse corruption and believe that they are there to create a new caring world, where people are concerned for their communities, not just themselves.  To celebrate this moment, we will capture it through a photograph and have each young Changemaker sign it.  If even just one of these young people makes it to be a famous social entrepreneur, then you will have the moment, which catalysed this.  With your Skype credits, you can talk to the young people that were there and how the event changed their lives.

RED ADMIRAL - The Red Admiral is our favourite butterfly and we want to reward people who are prepared to support our groundbreaking project with something significant and memorable.  So, you'll be thanked personally by the Butterfly Project Team on video and your name will be inscribed on the Inauguration Plaque, which will be in the entrance hall of the Chrysalis Campus.  We'll also send you a framed copy of the special photograph that Monarch supporters receive, as a special thank you, as well as some Skype credits.

PURPLE EMPEROR - As our top reward, we would like to offer you the chance to name one of the rooms in the Chrysalis Campus after you, so we will be referring to you by name every day at the Campus!  Everything from Red Admiral is also on offer, but we won't limit you (within reason) in your Skype access.  We'll even host you at the Campus for a few days, if you choose to come and visit us in Uganda!

Hold on, what are Skype Credits?

The members of the Butterfly Project enjoy talking to people from around the world and also like to give their perspective of their lives and what they want to achieve.  It's very rare that people have a chance to talk directly to someone who has grown up in an African village or slum, so we wanted to give this opportunity for those that are interested.

Time is limited, of course and members have to focus on their studies and projects.  Skype conversations are also monitored by an adult, so this requires our management time.  EACH SKYPE CREDIT gives you 10 minutes of talk time with a member of the Butterfly Project.

What happens if we don't make it to $50,000?

We are raising funds from all sorts of places - charity runs, EBay sales, friends of friends and we just don't know how much we are going to be able to raise from each place.  We'll keep you informed here, as to how things are going.  What we can say is that if we reach $50,000, then we will be able to build a Chrysalis Campus and then over time we will complete the whole project (which needs closer to $150,000).

If we don't make it to the target, then we will use the money to relocate our Centre and relaunch our project there, renting our new site until we can raise enough for the Campus.  We can still provide all of the rewards, as we launch in our new Centre.

If we reach our target early, then we will add a stretch target to add a school to the campus, then extend again for expanded the training facilities - the details are all here.

If I don't want to contribute, can I still help?

The answer to this is a big YES!  Here are some of the ways that you can make a real difference:

  • Spread the word!  We're not a big charity with a big mailing list and so we start at a disadvantage.  You can help off-set this by telling people about this groundbreaking project, which has already proved its success
  • You can help by fundraising for us independently of Indiegogo.  A number of people have now done charity runs for us.  Other have given us items we can sell on EBay.
  • Comment on our postings at ChrysalisUganda and Follow the blog and us on Twitter @socentafrica
  • Join our Facebook Group at: http://www.facebook.com/ChrysalisCentre
  • If you like art and would like to feature the children's art at your gallery, then let us know.
  • If you are an athlete and would like to help support our Slum Run 2013, then get in touch with us
  • If you are a construction organisation and can give us some in-kind support, such as materials or labour, then please contact us
  • If you are a university, that would be interested in staying at the campus, when it is built, then please let us know
  • If you are a Ugandan organisation that would like to have an office in the new campus, then we would love to hear from you
  • As an organisation, we value your input and ideas, so regardless of whether you decide to support us, we'd love to hve you on our mailing list and this way you can keep in touch with ny new initiatives we are working on; just mail my direct contact email.

My direct contact is: ben@socialenterpriseafrica.org

The future of Uganda and Africa is with these young people, who have given their hearts into making this project a success.  In return, we have taught them how to be role models to other youth and how to create a better and fairer society for their own futures.  We need to build on what has been achieved, continue to support hundreds of slum-based children and create many new young Butterfly social Entrepreneurs.  Help us achieve this aim and our world will be a better place.
story_txt:
If you've ever been to Uganda or other countries in Africa, you'll know what a welcome you receive from the children that live there! Their zest for life is so great and their enthusiasm for activities second to none.

Channelling this vibrancy and passion into learning how to be better citizens of Uganda, this project will help young people of Uganda to discover how they can become powerful change agents for themselves and their communities.
What We Do
Everything about what we do is geared towards positive-thinking, empowerment, capability, talent-development. Skills developed include:


Exploration and development of community-based initiatives for alleviating poverty;

How to each other help themselves;
The importance of equal opportunity;
How we can connect what we each have to give;
Vision and leadership skills for a better tomorrow.

Where Your Donation WIll Go
Previously housed through a small centre based in Kampala, Uganda, The Chrysalis Centre presently has 40 - 50 members and last year worked with over 200 students. This facility will only be available to us until December this year.
Your support will afford the build of the The Chrysalis Campus – a new facility enabling us to not only continue our work, but to more than quadruple the number of those we can support within the next year. To learn more about what the campus will look like, check out the drawing below.
Help Young People of Africa Help Themselves
Each adeptly named after a species of butterfly, SPREAD YOUR WINGS by supporting a perk! (For details on each perk, scroll down.)  


If you support the project, where does your money go?
Money buys so much more in Uganda and, where in the UK, you would spend millions of pounds on such a project, in Uganda we can build out whole campus for just £150,000 ($240,000) and we can start our first phase with just £32,000 ($50,000), which will help us acquire the land, the headquarters and training buildings, residential accommodation and activity provision, which will enable us to provide the means to train young people to create change.  If you cannot contribute money, then see below for other ways that you can contribute.
Tell me about the plan - why the focus on green issues?
A professional architect company has provided us with the plans and visuals and we will be building to this specification, with an aim to deliver a completely self-sufficient site, which collects its own water from rain and electricity through solar panels.  We intend to make the water jars, favoured by Water Aid, a part of the learning process for rural children that visit the Centre, so we can underpin what is regarded as good practice around the world.  Our gutters will enable us to collect rainwater - it rains a lot in Kampala) that will refill these.  We plan also to include training in solar energy as part of our training course strategy, which will in time enable children to develop a career in this area and rural children to be able to assess how solar power can make an impact in their village.
So, what are our credentials?
The Butterfly Project is a project designed by Social Enterprise Africa CIC, a UK-based community interest company that encourages the development of social enterprise in Africa and Ashoka Fellow, Emmanuel Nehemiah.  In Uganda, the project is run by Chrysalis Limited, an organisation set up specifically to deliver the project in Uganda.  The team contains a wealth of experience - Grace Ayaa, founder of Life in Africa, which were one of the first organisations to support the Northern Ugandan people during and post the war, Dr Solomon Nkesiga, Principal at Kampala Evangelical School of Theology for many years and practising social entrepreneur, James Wire, founder of Barefoot Power, which delivers solar power solutions but also an ethical entrepreneur and changemaker, Peter Ndelo, Manager at the Butterfly Project Kireka, but also an expert in international crafts sales, Alex Obeki, our Youth Activities Manager, but also the Kampala coordinator for HIV/AIDS prevention activities, Ahmed Ahaad, a national taekwondo coach and head of our sports provision and Bruno Ruganzu, TEDx award-winner and founder of Eco Arts Uganda, who works with us on our art provision.  I was CEO for five years at Jericho CIC, a UK organisation set up to empower long-term unemployed people into work before I started up Social Enterprise Africa.
Who are your end users?
Primarily in the Butterfly Project we train young social entrepreneurs - these are young people from the most disadvantaged backgrounds that are interested in making a difference to the lives of others in Uganda.  We help them achieve their aims through training and giving them a range of experience that children in Uganda usually can only dream of - you can see the kinds of things we do below.  We support children 12-15 who live in remote rural villages and also urban slum areas.
Secondly, because we strategically locate our project in a slum district of Kampala, then we have a catchment of many thousands of families.  This means that we can serve the most disadvantaged children in thse slum districts and we do this by encouraging the  Butterfly Project members to run activity projects with these local children.

Tell me more about the Butterfly Project
The Butterfly Project was launched in Uganda in 2009 after a small pilot in rural Nigeria.  In practice, it is a methodology for creating a momentum for change in communities, by training up young people interested in serving their communities to be a catalyst for change.  We find young people (aged 12-15) from remote villages, interview them and then offer them a chance to be part of our Butterfly Programme, which supports their education, but also trains them how to develop their vision, how to manage a project and how to be a leader.  In return we expect them to deliver their own social project in a community, based around what they are good at.  For instance, if they are a good artist, then they can run an art project, if they show aptitude in computers, then they run a computing project.

About The Perks!
By supporting this campaign, you will be joining in a unique and long-term movement to create a better Africa.  If you want to be part of this, you will join us observing the talented young people, as they grow in their ability to create change and you may even be able to advise them personally how best they can achieve the greatest social impact.
If you are interested in art, maybe you could help Joel, who is using art to tell the stories of children living in rural villages and urban slums.  Read about him here. 
Confidence is a big issue for girls in Africa, as they grow up in impoverished settings.  Maybe you could help Nancy achieve her aims and objectives, as she states them here.
Eunice is a composer and choreographer or some talent, which she uses to train small children.  Her project was recently featured on the front cover of Update Magazine. 
Gilbert is an immensely talented creative designer, in art, dance, fashion design, who wants to use these talents to transform the lives of children in his community.  You can see his latest blog here.
If you know about business, then you could support Manisuli with his tree planting project or Samuel as he devises a new card game.
If you have always been interested in education, then maybe you could help Charles in his quest to support education development in rural Africa. Listen to what he has to say here.
Mercy has recently been appointed an HIV/AIDS ambassador by the New Vision in Kampala, even though she is just 13 and you could be the one that help guides her in becoming a public speaker that impacts on millions.  You can see her in the video at the top of our appeal.
If you've read this far, then you've also read about Francis, who devised the Slum Olympics and Slum Run, which raised almost $1,500 for some of the most disadvantaged children in Kampala.  If you're an athlete, you could be the one to help him turn this small idea into a worldwide concept.
You can see some photos of the members and their projects here.
We have 20 members in total, though numbers are gradually expanding.  With your help too, we would like to have 50 young social entrepreneur trainees by the end of 2013.
Most of our rewards engage with these young social entrepreneurs and the work they do and you will likely be surprised by their commitment to what they do and their positive aspirations for the future. 
He is some more information about the rewards that we are planning:
CABBAGE WHITE - Look in the mirror and see the pride at what you have helped to build - there's your reward!
PEACOCK - We made a whole bunch of beautiful pictures last year of butterflies for a calendar and here's your chance to get your own copy of one.

If you are interested in this option, then you can view the butterflies available at this link.
BRIMSTONE - for this option we will give you a link on Google Docs to the file, with 40 full colour Top Trumps-style cards.  If you would like to have a hard copy of the cards, then we will print and despatch them to you, at the $15/($20 outside UK) additional cost, as stated.  You can see an example card below.  If you have a school or would like to encourage your own children to become social entrepreneurs and changemakers or simply want to learn a bit more about the members of the Butterfly Project, then this pack of cards is for you. 

Sample card (not actual size)

Reverse of card
(Note that scores on the cards are for fun and don't reflect the differing abilities of the members.)
BIRDWING - In the main training room, we plan that every brick will have an inspirational message (and your name, if you wish) built into it and we are opening this up to you to choose that message, that you personally feel is important for young people as they grow up.  When it's built, then we'll photograph every wall, so you can scan to find your individual message.
PAINTED LADY - A Facebook caricature of you will be painted, scanned and emailed to you.  An example of the work will shortly be displayed below.  As soon as you donate, then send an email to ben@socialenterpriseafrica.org with the photograph that you would like us to use. We will respond as soon as we can and send it back, so you can feature it in your own profile to encourage others to take part.  This first 100 is at an early bird price, so to take advantage, donate now!

SWALLOWTAIL - You will be able to choose either a bracelet or necklace, made primarily from the Acholi Paper beads and to a colour scheme of your choice.  Part of the money you donate will go to the local slum-based artisan that produced the work for you.

CAMBERWELL BEAUTY - You can take this reward multiple times, if you would like to talk with different members of the Butterfly Project on Skype. In time, this channel will link you to our internation network of youth social entrepreneurs, hosted by the The Citizens Media. This is a rare opportunity to meet young people in the world who have experienced life in an entirely different way to you or I.  Expect some surprising responses. Every member of the Butterfly Project speaks good English and is very used to talking over Skype.
TORTOISESHELL - We are learning to be film makers at the Chrysalis Campus and soon you will be able to commission us to make films about a variety of subjects and we will be entertaining you with the films we make, some of which have perhaps never before been made into a film.  This will be our first "official" film and we will be proud to have you on our list of credits at the end.  If we raise enough money, we'll even play this film in the newly-built outdoor cinema.  We'll upload the film onto Google Docs, when it is complete and give you the link.
ORANGE TIP - We thought that some of you might be interested in commissioning an original painting.  We work not just with Kids, but also some of Uganda's most well known international artists.  The kids love painting the butterflies, so you should choose which butterfly that you would like them to paint for you and then we will scan and send you their painting for review ahead of sending it to you.  If you choose to have a professional paint for you, then we will pay them for their time on the picture, hence the increased price.
Choose your butterfly from this website. Here is the quality that the professionals can produce, if you ask them to paint for you:

MONARCH - We want to capture the moment the Chrysalis Campus is built and record it for posterity.  This Campus represents the skills and abilities of a new generation of young Africans, who refuse corruption and believe that they are there to create a new caring world, where people are concerned for their communities, not just themselves.  To celebrate this moment, we will capture it through a photograph and have each young Changemaker sign it.  If even just one of these young people makes it to be a famous social entrepreneur, then you will have the moment, which catalysed this.  With your Skype credits, you can talk to the young people that were there and how the event changed their lives.
RED ADMIRAL - The Red Admiral is our favourite butterfly and we want to reward people who are prepared to support our groundbreaking project with something significant and memorable.  So, you'll be thanked personally by the Butterfly Project Team on video and your name will be inscribed on the Inauguration Plaque, which will be in the entrance hall of the Chrysalis Campus.  We'll also send you a framed copy of the special photograph that Monarch supporters receive, as a special thank you, as well as some Skype credits.
PURPLE EMPEROR - As our top reward, we would like to offer you the chance to name one of the rooms in the Chrysalis Campus after you, so we will be referring to you by name every day at the Campus!  Everything from Red Admiral is also on offer, but we won't limit you (within reason) in your Skype access.  We'll even host you at the Campus for a few days, if you choose to come and visit us in Uganda!
Hold on, what are Skype Credits?
The members of the Butterfly Project enjoy talking to people from around the world and also like to give their perspective of their lives and what they want to achieve.  It's very rare that people have a chance to talk directly to someone who has grown up in an African village or slum, so we wanted to give this opportunity for those that are interested.
Time is limited, of course and members have to focus on their studies and projects.  Skype conversations are also monitored by an adult, so this requires our management time.  EACH SKYPE CREDIT gives you 10 minutes of talk time with a member of the Butterfly Project.
What happens if we don't make it to $50,000?
We are raising funds from all sorts of places - charity runs, EBay sales, friends of friends and we just don't know how much we are going to be able to raise from each place.  We'll keep you informed here, as to how things are going.  What we can say is that if we reach $50,000, then we will be able to build a Chrysalis Campus and then over time we will complete the whole project (which needs closer to $150,000).
If we don't make it to the target, then we will use the money to relocate our Centre and relaunch our project there, renting our new site until we can raise enough for the Campus.  We can still provide all of the rewards, as we launch in our new Centre.
If we reach our target early, then we will add a stretch target to add a school to the campus, then extend again for expanded the training facilities - the details are all here.
If I don't want to contribute, can I still help?
The answer to this is a big YES!  Here are some of the ways that you can make a real difference:

Spread the word!  We're not a big charity with a big mailing list and so we start at a disadvantage.  You can help off-set this by telling people about this groundbreaking project, which has already proved its success
You can help by fundraising for us independently of Indiegogo.  A number of people have now done charity runs for us.  Other have given us items we can sell on EBay.
Comment on our postings at ChrysalisUganda and Follow the blog and us on Twitter @socentafrica
Join our Facebook Group at: http://www.facebook.com/ChrysalisCentre

If you like art and would like to feature the children's art at your gallery, then let us know.
If you are an athlete and would like to help support our Slum Run 2013, then get in touch with us
If you are a construction organisation and can give us some in-kind support, such as materials or labour, then please contact us
If you are a university, that would be interested in staying at the campus, when it is built, then please let us know
If you are a Ugandan organisation that would like to have an office in the new campus, then we would love to hear from you
As an organisation, we value your input and ideas, so regardless of whether you decide to support us, we'd love to hve you on our mailing list and this way you can keep in touch with ny new initiatives we are working on; just mail my direct contact email.
My direct contact is: ben@socialenterpriseafrica.org

The future of Uganda and Africa is with these young people, who have given their hearts into making this project a success.  In return, we have taught them how to be role models to other youth and how to create a better and fairer society for their own futures.  We need to build on what has been achieved, continue to support hundreds of slum-based children and create many new young Butterfly social Entrepreneurs.  Help us achieve this aim and our world will be a better place.
